Salcuni; Rome// Purpose: The inadequancy of acoustic signals in TCCS can explain why it is becoming a general practice to use ecographic contrast media thanks to their ability of increasing the acoustic signals to obtein the visualizzation of a greater number of vascular structures and their better definition. Methods and Materials: We have performed TCCS on 20 patients affected by carotid stenosis, cerebral arteriovenous malformations, arterial spasm due to ESA. Quantitative, qualitative doppler parameters have been investigate for each patient in basal condition and then repeated after the injection of Levovist 300 mg/I, recording even the signal enhancement time. Results: The signal enhancement time for a single dose (270-440 sec), was long enough to investigate the flow direction in the vessels belonging to the circle of Willis and its validity, assess the morphology and the direction of flows in cerebral aneurysm, outline the vascular structures forming a MAV and study low-flow vascular structures. Conclusion: The advantages of Levovist are certainly numerous but its use is limited by the high price, by the few successfull application in cases of MAV because of the distortion of the signal amplified and the poor definition of the vessels of the circle of Willis and the posterior cirele in their wholeness. 10:35 725 The role of Levovist™ in the assessment of hepatic arterial complications following Iiver transplantation S.M. FIGREF208.text: Reduced patient dose in CT-examinations with a new on-line anatomically adapted tube current modulation M. Krauss, I. Bär, C. Scherf, D. Hentschel; NürnberglD Purpose: Evaluation of the effectiveness of a new system for dose reduction in CT-examinations by modulating the tube current adapted to the individual patient geometry without impairing image quality. Methods and Materials: 21 patients were scanned at different anatomical regions with a Siemens Somatom Plus 4 CT-scanner using the Siemens works-in-progress dose adaption system CAR.E.-Dose modulating the tube current during gantry rotation. At angular positions with small patient diameter the tube current is reduced. The modulation function is calculated from the attenuation online during scanning, the Chairpersons: D. BALERIAUX (Brussels/B) S. EKHOLM (Gothenburg/S) function is sent to the generator control for tube current modulation with a delay of half a rotation. Nominal and effective tube current values were compared after CT-examination and image quality was evaluated by 5 independent radiologists. Results: The on-line adaptive dose modulation lead to dose savings of 0% to 51% depending on the anatomical region examined with a mean dose reduction of 24%. Due to the limitation of maximal tube current no increase in patient dose was observed. The evaluation of the spiral-CT images showed no significant decrease in image quality. Conclusion: The on-line adaptive dose modulation CAR.E-Dose optimally exploits the asymmetry of anatomical regions for considerable dose savings of up to 51% without compromising image quality. -dose reduction without loss of diagnostic quality by means of patient size computation from single scanograms A. Artaud; U/le/F Purpose: To evaluate the clinical efficacy of anatomically adapted tube current modulation in HRCT of lung parenchyma. Methods and Materials: 202 consecutive patients underwent a HRCT examination (1-mm collimation; 20-mm intervals) of lung parenchyma with and without tube current modulation at: (a) 140 kV, 170 mA (Group 1; n =52); (b) 120 kV, 170 mA (Group 2; n =77); or (c) 120 kV, 130 mA (Group 3; n =73).Results: In the absence of significant difference in the mean weight and size between the 3 groups, the mean dose reduction was: (a) 15.80% (Group 1), 16.31% (Group 2) and 14.9% (Group 3) over the entire thorax; (b) significantly higher in the upper lung zone (Group 1: 23.40%; Group 2: 23.40%; Group 3: 22.80%) compared with the mid (Group 1: 13.30%; Group 2: 13.40%; Group 3: 11.70%) and lower (Group 1: 6.80%; Group 2: 11.70%; Group 3: 10.50%) (p < 0.001) lung zones. Despite increased image noise in the upper lung zone (Group 3), no significant difference was seen in detection of lung parenchymal abnormalities on images acquired with tube current modulation in the three groups. Conclusion: The anatomically adapted tube current modulation at 120 kV, 130 mA provides good image quality in patients of average weight.747 3D reconstruction of cerebral vessels based on a rotational angiography with aC-arm T. FIGREF217.text: Brain and skull ChA Raybaud, N. Girard; Marseille/F The brain development proceeds in a orderly fashion from differentiation of the neural plate (3rd week) to the completed organ at term (350 g). For c1arity, two (overlapping) phases are classically distinguished -organogenesis covers the embryonie period. Malformations then include: closure disorders or dysraphic states (Chiari 2 and 3, encephaloceles); diverticulation disorders or holoprosencephalies (alobar, semi-Iobar, lobar) with related facial defects; rhombencephalic cysts (Dandy Walker, Dandy Walker variant, Blake pouch). -histogenesis covers the fetal period. Malformations are abnormalities of: the multiplication (micrencephaly), the premigratory differentiation (focal cortical dysplasia, tuberous sclerosis, hemimegalencephaly), the migration (nodular/laminar heterotopias, agyria/pachygyria), or the organization (Walker-Warburg, micropolygyria, schizencephaly) of the neuroblasts. -commissural development is part of both organogenesis and histogenesis. It may affect all or selected commissures (anterior, hippocampal, callosal), in part or globally. A specific type associates dysplasia of meninges. MRI (T1, T2, OP, flair, millimetric, multiplanar reformattings... ) brings out a superb anatomy of the disorders, idenlifies the nature of tissular abnormalities, allows recognition of potentially all types of maIformations, makes characterization of new nosologie entities possible, in close confrontation with the known morphogenetic and pathologie data. 798 B. Spine and spinal cord P. Tortori-Oonati, M.P. Fondelli, A. Rossi; Genoa//

FIGREF229.text: MannheimlDPurpose: Ta evaluate characteristics of experimentally induced and post mortem histological proven angiosarcomas (AS) and hepatocellular carcinomas (HCC) by means of blood pool images and functional maps using a real-time interface. Methods and Materials: We investigated 20 male rats with HCC and and 10 with AS using a T1-weighted 3D-GE sequence (TR = 5 ms, TE =2 ms, FA =30, TA =66 sec) on a 1.5T Vision System. After 4 baseline measurements and a bolus injection of 15 !lmol/kg USPIO 15 further multislice measurements of the liver were done. A real-time interface generates functional maps that contain combined information of blood pool values and elimination characteristics. Results: Angiosarcomas showed a 300% higher blood pool value than liver and a faster elimination. HCC showed a lower blood pool value than liver and a slow elimination or an ongoing uptake during measurement time. Using this knowledge, an adequate lesion characterization can be done in real-time, especially to discuss suspect lesions.Conclusion: Blood pool maps often exhibit non-expected behaviour of alesion and yield new implications. FIGREF230.text: (Submitted by Internet)Purpose: Ta determine the efficacy of Multihance® enhanced MRI in liver lesion detection in camparisan to unenhanced MRI and dynamic CT based on a independent image evaluation.Methods and Materials: In a multicenter german phase 111 trial with 151 patients investigated, image sets of 148 patients were evaluated by 2 independent radiologists unaffiliated to the investigating centers. Patients underwent a routine MRI-protocoll including T2-and T1-W-SE and T1 W GE sequences pre and 1 hour post 0.1 mmol/kg Multihance® (CM) (Bracco-Byk; Konstanz, Germany). Additionlly aserial T1W GE scan was performed with the first half of the dose. All patients underwent dynamic contrast-enhanced C'T, The evaluation was performed with regard to the number and size of lesion detected per patient in each modality or sequence. Furthermore, the pre CM and pre + post CM image sets were analysed for lesions per patient. Results: Both readers detected significantly more lesion in the contrastenhanced image set (32% and 39%; p < 0.0001). While contrastenhanced CT detected the same number of lesion as unenhanced MRI, it was c1early inferior in lesion detection to contrast-enhanced MRI (Reader 1: p = 0.0117 + reader 2: p = 0.0225). Of the T1W scans performed, the dynamic and late T1W GE exams contributed most to the increased lesion detection rate (p = 0.0007 + P = 0.0037). The size of the smallest lesion detected by means of MRI was sigificantly lower in the pre CM image sets than in the pre + post CM image sets (p = 0.001 + P < 0.0001). Contrast-enhanced MRI reavealed after application of Multihance® significantly smaller lesion than contrast-enhanced CT (p =0.0117 + P =0.0925).

Georgi; MannheimlD Purpose: To evaluate the accuracy of MRI and 3D-MRA in preoperative stag ing of liver tumors in correlation to intraoperative and histological results. Methods and Materials: In 50 Patients with focalliver lesions axial and coronal MR sequences unenhanced and contrast-enhanced (T1w-Flash 20, T2w-TSE , EPI-IRM, TRUE FISP) as weil as dual phase coronal ultrafast MRA were performed. Techn ical parameters of MRA were as folIows : TRITE =3.8/1.4 ms, FA 300 , 80 partitions, matrix 128 x 256, aquisition time 18 sec.Results: In 41/50 patients Iiver resection was performed. Correct prediction of segmental localisation in MRI in 96% . Histology was correct in 38/41 patients (92%), predicted dignity was correct in all cases . Evaluation of hepatic vascular structures for resectability of liver lesions was correct in all patients, infiltration of vessel wall in absence of a tumor thrombus could not be c1early identified. By use of multiplanar reconstruction and single image view of the 3D-data base add itional informations could be obtained in 21 patients . Conclusion: Dual-phase 3D-MRA and MRI give accurate information on local isat ion of focal lesions and their relationship to important intrahepatic vessels, especially on prese ntation of portal venous structures. FIGREF250.text: To compare the effectiveness of Ultrasound and MRI in the evaluation of rotator cuff tears using Arthroscopy as gold standard.Methods and Materials: Shoulders of 45 patients (M = 28, F = 17; ages 17-66) were evaluated with ultrasound and correlated with arthroscopy. Of these, 27 patients also had MRI (interpreted by another radiologist) whose results were correlated separately with arthroscopy. Results for the detection of both full-thickness tears (FTT) and partial-thickness tears (PTT) were derived.Results: In comparison with shoulder arthroscopy, Ultrasound correlation for FTT resulted in Sens = 100%, Spec = 94%, PPV = 90% and NPV = 100%. For PTT, the results were: Sens = 100%, Spec = 78%, PPV = 83% and NPV = 100%. The presence of a large caleification resulted in one false-positive for FTT. In the subset of 27 patients who also had MRI, ultrasound vs. arthroscopy evaluation for FTT yielded: Sens = Spec = PPV = NPV = 100%; whereas with MRI vs. arthroscopy: Sens = 33%, Spec = 91%, PPV =67% and NPV =70%. For PTT, ultrasound values were: Sens = 100%, Spec = 86%, PPV = 83%, NPV = 100%; whereas MRI values were: Sens = 40%, Spec = 83%, PPV = 67%, NPV = 63%. Conclusion: Ultrasound is superior to MRI in rotator cuff evaluation and should be considered the new diagnostic imaging standard. The find ings were categorized in 5 groups by using the method ofPennes (A J R 153:1017-19, 1989) : 1-only visible on internal rotation; 11visua lized best on internal rotation ; 111 -seen equally weil on internal and external rotation ; IV imaged best on external rotation ; V -only imaged on external rotation. Results: The lesions of anterior labrum and capsule were caterogized: I group: 8 labrallesions (LL) and 27 abnormalities of anterior capsule (AAC) ; 11 : 8 LL and 10 AAC; 111: 22 LL and 9 AAC ; IV and V: 5 LL. The lesions of posterior labrum and capsule were categorized: 111 group: 4 LL and 3 AAC : IV and V: 3 LL and 5 AAC. Conclusion: Arthro-CT with scans in external rotation showed lesions inapparent on internal rotation in 5 cases out of 62 patients (8%) with anter ior instability, and in 6 cases out of 8 patients (75 %) with posterior instability ot shoulder. Lang ; Stanford, CA/USA Purpose: To evaluate the use of MR guidance for diagnostic and interventional procedures in the shoulder using a vertically open MR unit. Methods and Materials: 15 patients with suspected shoulder instability and 2 patients with spino glenoid notch cysts (SPC) were studied in an open magnet (GE Signa SP, 0.5T) . An MR compatible needl e was advanced into the joint via anteri or approach (SPC: posterior approach). Dilute gadolinium was injected for MR arthrography (MRA) . Static shoulder MRA (3-point Dixon SE) was followed by dynamic motion MRA with stress testing (GRASS, 2sec/scan). Aspiration of SPC's was followed by steroid injection. Results: MR guided intraarticular needle placement was possible with a single needle pass in 13 of 15 patients. Statie MRA demonstrated labral tears in 11 patients (3 SLAP, 5 anterior, 1 ALPSA, 2 post erior) . Dynamic motion MRA demonstrated shoulder instability in 5 patients (3 anterior, 2 posterior subluxation). SPC aspiration was successful in both patients . Conelusion: MR guided intraarticular injection for shoulder MRA is techn ically feasible and eas ier than intraarticular inject ion using f1uoroscopy. Static routine MRA can be complemented by dynamic MR mot ion studies to demonstrate shoulder instabil ity. Range of motions studies and therap eutic interventions are poss ible because of the ope n configuration of the magn et. FIGREF257.text: The role of transvaginal sonohysterography in the assessment of the uterine cavity in patients with fertility problems A. Vourtsi , T. Stefanopoulus, AG. Antoniou, D. Kehagias, E. Kapetanakis, L. Vlahos; Athens/GR Purpose: To evaluate the role of transvaginal sonohysterography in the assessment of uterine abnormalities in infertility patients. Methods and Materials: Transvaginal sonohysterography was performed in 43 patients (aged 32-47 years) in whom conventional transvaginal sonography suggested intrauterine abnormalities either by endometrial thicken ing or abnormal morphology. In all cases the examination was performed by placing a small catheter into the endometrial canal and injection of 5-10 cc of saline solut ion under sonographic visualization. Results: Transvaginal sonohysterography depicted endometrial poly ps (n =10), intracavitary fibro ids (n =13), endometrial thickening (n =8),carcinoma (n =1), and normal cavities (n =11). All patients underwent diagnostic hysteroscopy and in 1 case hysterectomy was performed. All findings diagnosed with transvaginal sonohysterography corresponded to the results observed with hysteroscopy and hysterectomy. No complications occurred. Conclusion: Transvaginal sonohysterography using saline solutlon injected is a low-cost, easy and very sensitive procedure in the assessment of the uterine cavity, and we believe it should be the primary examination in evaluating patients with fertility problems.11:40 889 MR patterns of ovarian fibromas A La Fianza , E. Methods and Materials: Pre-and post-treatment CT (n=52) and MRI (n=45) examinations of 28 patients with primary NPC treated with RT (6000-7500 cGy) were retrospectively evaluated. Results: We subdivide the patients in three groups on the basis of the differences in the CT and MRI appearance of the primary tumors treated with RT: Responders (9): Complete resolution of tumor or redu ction in tumor size = or >75 %; Non-Responders (8): Persistent tumor or residual mass with reduct ion in tumor size = or <50%; Partially Responders (11) Persistent residua l mass with reduclion in tumor size from 50% to 75% or persistent asimmetry of the mucosal surface.Conclusion: There are some points to analyze in the interpretation of CT and MRI of post-treated NPC : Transient changes of irradiated soft tissues contrast enhance and may induce false positive . Visceral: retract ion of pharyngeal wall and distortion of Rosenmuller's recess ; d. Nervous: temporal radionecrosis. 2. Bone tissue changes: Sphenoid bone sclerosis. 3. Sinusal changes: Sphenoid sinusitis . FIGREF262.text: MR image-guided laparoscopy in phantoms and an animal model M. Wendt, A. Melzer, E. Yen, K. Petal, Q. Zhang, J.L. Duerk, J.S. Lewin; Cleveland, OH/USAPurpose: lt was the purpose of this work to combine laparoscopic procedures with MR imaging to allow the localization and guidance of the endoscope to the target region. Methods and Materials: An open MR scanner and two MR compatible endoscope systems were used to perform the experiments. Three approaches to guide the endoscopes were developed and compared: 1) An active localization and guidance system allowing computation of the position of the tip of the tool and its predicted path towards the target, 2) Gd-DTPA filled trocars to be visualized with standard MR imaging, 3) endoscopes coated with Gd-DTPA and copper coils mounted near their tip to be used as receive coils for an active tip-tracking system. During the animal experiments the gallbladder was targeted and punctured. Results: There were no limitations to simultaneous use of the endoscopic equipment in an MRI environment. All three guidance systems were capable of showing the location of the endoscopes within the inflated abdomen and were helpful in guiding the endoscope towards the target. Conclusion: The combination of both clincially useful imaging techniques enabled the physician to analyze the high-resolution endoscopic image in conjunction with the "big picture" created by MRI.11:15 906 MR image-guided percutaneous sclerotherapy of low-flow vascular malformations in the head and neck: safety and feasibility J.S. Lewin, E.M. Merkle, J.L. Duerk, R.W. Tarr; C/eve/and, OH/USA Purpose: This study was performed to test the feasibility and safety of MR image-guided percutaneous sclerotherapy of low-flow vascular rnalforrnations in the head and neck. 5ubjects and Methods: Seventeen MR image-guided percutaneous sclerotherapeutic procedures were performed on an open MR imager in 3 patients with head and neck low-flow vascular malformations. A 22g MR-compatible needle was advanced into the targeted vascular malformation component under direct continuous MR imaging guidance. Between 4 and 10 ml of sclerosing agent mixed with dilute contrast was injected under continuous gradient echo MR image monitoring. Clinically and MR imaging follow-up ranged from four to 17 weeks. Results: Successful needle placement and MR image-monitored sclerosing agent injection was accomplished in all cases without complication, and all targeted vascular malformation compartments were filled with sclerosing agent with a mean interventional procedure time of 29 minutes. Follow-up images and c1inical examination demonstrated reduction in size of the treated portions of the malformation in all patients. Two patients reported an improvement in chewing and one reported a complete cessation of previous nightly oral hemorrhage. Conclusion: MR image-guided percutaneous sclerotherapy of lowflow vascular malformations in the head and neck is feasible, can be performed safely, and allows monitoring of injection of both superficial and deep vascular components. 11:20 907 Evaluation of percutaneous MRI-guided abdominal biopsy in a closed magnet using the pig as a model R.F. Methods and Materials: Thirty-six single pass biopsies were performed in 6 piglets using 5 different types of MR compatible needles.

FIGREF263.text: MR-guided percutaneous nephrostomy of the non-dilated upper urinary tract in a porcine model E.M. Merkle, M. Hashim, M. Wendt, J.S. Lewin; Cleveland, OH/USAPurpose: To test the hypothesis that MR-guided percutaneous nephrostomy of the non-dilated upper urinary tract in a porcine model is feasible and safe. Methods and Materials: A total of six MR-guided percutaneous nephrostomies of the non-dilated upper urinary tract were performed in four domestic farm pigs (20-25 kg BW) using a 0.2 T system. Ten minutes following IV administration of 0.2 mmol/kg gadodiamide and 004 mg/kg furosemide, a T1-weighted fast biopsy sequence was used to guide insertion of a 18G MR-compatible needle into a predetermined calyx. After needle position confirmation using a TSE T1-weighted sequence, a .035 inch glidewire coated with superparamagnetic iron oxide (SPIO) was inserted under MR monitoring. This was followed by tract dilation and insertion of a modified 4F sheath. Final sheath position was confirmed by injection of diluted SPIO into the collecting system. Results: Needle insertion was successful in all six procedures without any complications with an instrumentation time ranging from 4 to 13 minutes (6 ± 4 minutes). Successful sheath placement was possible in five of six cases within 6 to 28 minutes (16 ± 9 minutes).Conclusion: MR-guided percutaneous nephrostomy of the non-dilated contrast-enhanced upper urinary tract in a porcine model is feasible and safe. 11:40 909 Real-time fluoroscopic MR-guided fine needle aspiration biopsy M. Hahn; MunichlD 10:40 Purpose: To evaluate the usefulness of MRI using Half Fourier Single shot Turbo Spin Echo (HASTE) sequence detecting intrauterine fetal anomalies.911 Essential optimisation of storage phosphor radiography for pediatrie radiology R. Fotter, E. Sorantin; GrazlA 914 Ultrasonographie patterns of eervieal Iymphadenopathy in ehildren O. Papakonstantinou, A. Bakantaki, M. Paspalaki, E. Papadaki, N. Gourtsoyiannis; IraklionlGRPurpose: Exact definition of anatomical connections is essential in assessing surgical strategy for separation of Siamese twins. The value of dynamic contrast enhanced MRI and MRA is discussed. Methods and Materials: For morphological analysis, HASTE, spin echo, and turbo spin echo sequences were used. To define the separation line, dynamic scanning was done with FLASH 20 sequences after application of Gd-DTPA to only one twin of each set. MRA was performed with FLASH 20 and FISP 3D time of f1ight sequences. Results: The first set of twins showed conjoined structures including diaphragm and Iiver. Dynamic imaging clearly demonstrated the separation line between unified Iivers. The time delay of nearly 4 minutes until the contrast agent was seen in the other twin, gives a good estimation of the degree of cross circulation. In the second set of twins MRI showed a small fibrous connection between the sacral bones and a muscular bridge involving the internal obturatorius and levator ani muscle. MRA demonstrated a branch of the internal iliac artery crossing the midline and leading to the other twin. Conelusion: Dynamic MRI and MRA allowed precise and surgically proven definition of morphological connections in conjoined twins.

FIGREF267.text: of chronic recurrent parotitis in childhood T.A .G.M. Huisman, D. Holzmann, U.V. W illi, E. Martin, D. Nadal; ZurichICHPurpose: To def ine Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) -characteristics of chron ic recurrent parotitis (CRP) in childhood. Methods and Materials: 11 children (3-11 years) with clin ical proven CRP were examined in a 1.5 T MR-Un it. Pre-and post-contrast T1and T2-weighted, axial and coronal sequences were performed. Images were evaluated by two experienced neuroradiologists. Results: In the acute phase of inflammation both parotid glands are swollen, T2-hyperintense with marked contrast-enhancement. Multiple intraparotideal Iymphnodes are seen . In the chronic phase the parotid glands are atrophie, T2-hypointense, non-enhancing and presents with multiple T2-hyperintense cysts within the glands. In addition the parotid ducts are enlarged. Conclusion: MR I allows differentiation between acute and ehren ie inflammation in CRP. Compared to ultrasound (compression of the parotid duct by the US-sonde) and sialography (dilatation of the paro tid duct by contrast-injection), MRI does not alter the anatomy of parotid duct and therefore allows a preci se evaluation of parotid duct ectasia.(Submitted by Internet) 11:05 916 Atlanto-axial rotatory subluxation C. FIGREF270.text: child pneumonia: assessment with B-mode ultrasonography and power Doppler X. Serres, L. Inaraja, M. Coll, M. Penas, E. Gallardo, V. Garriga;Granollers/E Purpose: The aim of this study is to evaluate the role of thoracic ultrasonography and power Doppler to establish the severity and the prognosis of serious pneumonia in children. Methods and Materials: 11 children with serious community-acquired pneumonia, 5 boys and 6 girls, aged 1-10 years, were evaluated by ehest X-ray and ultrasonography. The severity of pneumonia was established on basis of c1inical and radiological criteria. Parenchyma consolidation, air and fluid bronchogram, vascular perfusion, areas of necrosis and pleural effusion was sonographycally evaluated using power Doppler. Results: Power Doppler showed parenchymal perfusion in 3 patients and abscence of perfusion in 8 patients. In 4 patients, with non-perfused pneumonia, parenchymal hyperechoic and hypoechoic focal areas were detected. These features were associated with increased frequency of cavitary necrosis at follow-up. Pleural effusion seen in 4 infants was always associated with cavitary necrosis. The mean length of hospital stay was 5 days in perfused pneumonia, 8 days in non-perfused pneumonia and 25 days in non-perfused pneumonia with necrotic areas.Conclusion: Ultrasonography bring us eomplementary information respect ehest X-ray. With power Doppler imaging it's possible to deteet the non-perfused pneumonias. Passariello; RomeIl Purpose: To evaluate in vitro the possibility to develop target specific contrast media for Magnetic Resonance (MR) Imaging, using reeombinant human antibody fragments. Methods and Materials: Human recombinant anti-Herpes simplex antibody fragments (rFab) were linked in vitro to Gd-DTPA in several chemical conditions and molar ratios. The residual immunospecificity of the labeled rFab was assessed by ELiSA and immunofluorescence microscopy. MR Imaging was performed on a 1.0 T magnet, using standard T1w. SE sequences. Signal intensity (SI) measurements were performed on labeled and non labeled rFab. The imaging potential of the labeled rFab was assessed on 10 6 epithelial cells infeeted by herpes simplex virus (HSV) 1, as compared to non infected cells. Results: Gd-DTPA was efficiently and stably linked to human rFab, without loss in immunospecificity up to a molar ratio of 25:1 (Gd-DTPA:rFab). A significant SI inerease was obtained in labeled as eompared to non labeled rFab. Labeled rFab yielded a significant SI increase of cell suspensions infected by HSV1 as compared to non infected cells. Conclusion: Labeling human antibody fragments with Gd-DTPA is possible. rFab-Gd-DTPA could prove an interesting target specifie contrast agent, not showing moreover compatibility problems and providing a more favourable pharmacokineties as compared to the extensively used murine Mabs. 10:40 923 Mn·DPDP as a new contrast agent for MR imaging of the adrenal gland J. FIGREF271.text: Gd-SOPTA (multihance) in MR imaging of focal Iiver disease: a summary of phase 11 and 111 clinical studies A. Spinazzi, G. Pirovano, M. Kirchin; Milan//Purpose: To assess the value of Gd-BOPTA for delayed and dynamic MR imaging of focal Iiver disease. Methods and Materials: 737 patients with known or suspected focal Iiver lesions were enrolled in Phase 11 and 111 clinical trials. Phase 11 studies were performed to assess Gd-BOPTA efficacy for the detection and delineation of focal lesions on T1-WSE/GE images acquired up S210 to 180 min post-dose and, subsequently, to compare delayed (40-80 and 90-120 min) imaging results with gold standard findings. Phase 111 studies looked at delayed imaging at 60-120 min with 0.1 mmollkg Gd-BOPTA and immediate post-dose dynamic imaging with an 0.05 mmollkg bolus. Results: A significantly higher number of lesions were detected on delayed images in 33-38% and 26-27% of Phase 11 patients administered 0.05 and 0.1 mmollkg Gd-BOPTA, respectively. Overall, an 0.05 mmollkg dose enabled the detection of 72% of lesions detected by gold standard, compared with an unenhanced finding of 59%. Phase 111 results additionally showed that 0.05 mmol/kg Gd-BOPTA combined with bolus dynamic imaging provided additional information in terms of lesion characterisation in up to 43% of patients and effected patient management in up to 23% of patient studies. Conclusion: Gd-BOPTA is an effective contrast agent for both dynamic and delayed MR imaging of the liver.11:20 927 Angiogenesis of wound healing: assessment with contrast-enhanced MRI Th. Helbich, M.D. Rollins, T.P.L. Roberts, D.M. Shames, M. Mühler, T.K. Hunt, R.C. Brasch; Vienna/APurpose: Ta quantitatively assess the time course of microvascular permeability and fraclianal plasma volume (fPV) , representalives of angiogenesis, in wound healing. Methods and Materials: Wound healing was induced by implanting two "Hunt-Schilling wound cylinders" (internal diameter 8 rnrn, length 2.5 cm) in each of six rats. Dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI was performed using a macromolecular contrast agent (albumin-(Gad-DTPA) 30) immediately after implantation (day 0), and at days 1, 4, 9, and 22 post implantation. Permeability surface area product, as estimated by corresponding endothelial transfer coefficient (Kph), and fPV were calculated for each cylinder using a two-compartment bi-directional kinelic model. MRI rnicrovascular characteristics were correlated with histopathology (vessel count) of the wound. Results: Microvascular permeability of the wound, characterized by Kps, increased significantly from day 0 (Kps = 0 ml min-1 100 cc-1 tissue) 10 day 9 (Kps = 0.05 ml min-1 100 cc-1 tissue; p < .01) and remained constant through day 22 (Kps = 0.05 ml min-1 100 cc-1 tissue). The fPV increased progressively with time (day 0, fPV = 0.01 ml cc-1 tissue; day 22, fPV = 0.07 ml cc-1 tissue). Both, Kps and fPV correlated closely with vessel counts of the wounds, Conclusion: Contrast-enhanced MRI is able to assess quantitatively changes of wound healing angiogenesis. Thus, MRI may offer a quantltative assay for the wound healing process and may be used to monitor treatment response.11:30 928 Assessing irradiation induced bone marrow alterations with contrast enhanced MRI: comparison of Carboxymethyldextran-Gd-DOTA and gadopentetate dimeglumine H.E. FIGREF273.text: Influence of Gd-DTPA concentration on PC MR velocimetry J.T. Heverhagen, M. Hoppe, H.-J. Wagner, K.-J. Klose; Marburg/D Purpose: An important diagnostic tool in the analysis of arterial stenoses and their hemodynammic significance is the PG MR velocimetry. We sought to evaluate the influence of Gd-DTPA in different concentrations on the reliability of PG MR velocimetry. Methods and Materials: In a validated arterial model with a defined concentric stenosis and calibrated flow velocity, increasing concentrations of Gd-DTPA (MagnevisjTM, Schering) were administered. PG MR velocimetry was obtained using a 1.0 T Magnetom Expert™ (Siemens) with a manufacturer provided software (Flash2D-sequence TRITE/FA 200 ms/6 ms/300). Measurements were obtained simultaneously pre-, intra-and poststenotic. The area of stenosis was calculated using the ratio of pre-and intrastenotic flow velocities. Results: There was no statistically significant influence of the Gd-DTPA concentration on the reliability of PG MR velocimetry. The results of the calculation of the area of stenosis showed only small variance (72.1 -75.5 ± 0.9%). Conclusion: In vitro Gd-DTPA had no significant impact on PG MR velocimetry. Therefore PG MR velocimetry can be acquired at any time in respect to Gd-DTPA application for contrast enhanced angiography. 10:30 931 Cerebral aneurysms: a comparlson of MR angiography and digital subtraction anglography Z. Duhamel; LillelFPurpose: To determine the clinical usefulness of thin collimation spiral CT in identifying segmental and subsegmental pulmonary emboli (PE). Methods and Materials: 370 patients were prospectively evaluated with a subsecond scan time and a 2-mm collimation and pitch of 2Group 1; n = 284) or a 3-mm collimation and a pitch of 1.7 (Group 2; n = 86) to detect acute PE at the level of central, segmental and subsegmental pulmonary arteries. Results: Spiral CT examination was suboptimal in 10 patients (3%), negative in 217 patients (58%), positive in 104 patients (28%) and indeterminate in 39 patients (11%). In the 360 spiral CT scans coded as interpretable, the percentage of the analyzable central, segmental and subsegmental arterial bed was 98%, 87% and 59%, respectively. Whereas no significant difference was found between the two groups at the level of central and segmental pulmonary arteries, a significantly higher percentage of analyzable subsegmental arteries was found in Group 1 (65% vs 43%; P < 0.001). Isolated segmental and/or subsegmental clots were identified in 29 patients (8%) (Group 1: n =24; Group 2: n = 5), 24 of them presenting with a prior history of cardiopulmonary disease. Conclusion: Scanning patients with thin collimation enables reliable depiction of segmental and subsegmental pulmonary emboli.15:20 1011 Interactive sliding-thin-slab-maximum-intensity-projection (8T8-MIP) in CT-angiography of pulmonary embolism C. The software has been rnainly developed in IDL.• Modalities: MRI, CT, es , US, PET, SPECT, Secondary captures,• Basie processing: Windowllevel , colour LUT's , filtering, zoom/Pan , annotations, measurements, printing, ... • Advanced processing: 3D tools , Segmentation, Quantification, Multimodality fusion • Video-Conference and Application shar ing (CSCW) • Acquisition: DICOM 3.0 , video frame grabber; TWAIN comp liant scanner; file reading : Interfile , proprietary formats • Text and voiee reports atlached to the images Results: The implemented application allows for different configurations ranging from cheap medium-quality systems to sophisticated workstations. The user interface has been designed according to guide lines provided by experienced clinical users. Prototypes are under evaluation in several elinical sites . SUINSA S.A., a Spanish medical equ ipment manufacturer, has comm illed itself to the commercialisation of the system by the end of 1998. FIGREF290.text: The use of the POLAR (pathway of least arterial resistance) device in the treatment of arterial occlusion M.R. Rees, M.P. Callaway, RN. Baird; Bristol/UKPurpose: Several reports have noted the success of vibrational angioplasty or activated guidewire technology as a method of traversing chronic arterial occlusions in the circulatory circulation. Methods and Materials: Two patients with peripheral disease have been treated using this method. In both cases conventianal endovascular techniques failed. The occlusions were traversed using conventional wires in combination with vibration apparatus designed to follow the pathway of least resistance and the wire remain intraluminal. The first patient, a 74 year old female had chronic arterial disease presenting with a painful ulcer over the lateral malleolus. Angiography indicated a 5-6 cm occlusion in the common peroneal trunk. The POLAR device was used and the lesion successfully angioplastied. Follow-up angiography at 3 months confirmed patency. The second patient, a 65 year old male presented with progressive severe thigh c1audication. Angiography indicated a 10-12 cm occlusion of the right external iliac and common femoral arteries. The POLAR device was used the lesion was successfully angioplastied and a stent placed. Conclusion: The POLAR device is a new and useful method of endovascular treatment of chronic peripheral arterial occlusions.(Submitted by Internet) 14:05 1033 Application of carbon dioxide gas in vascular interventions W. Hahn; Munich/D Purpose: To determine the value of carbon dioxide DSA in interventional procedures in patients with contraindications to iodinated contrast medium (ICM). Methods and Materials: 17 patients with peripheral vascular disease (PVD) underwent vascular interventions. Contraindication to ICM was a contrast agent-related hypersensitivity in 4 patients and compensated renal insufficiency in 13. Balloon dilatation was performed in 12 cases and stent placement in 5. Lesions were located in iliac (6), femoral (6) and popliteal (3) arteries. All interventions were done on a Siemens vascular imager (MULTISTAR TOP). CO 2 application was done with apressure -and volume controlled injector (lnspect 2005, TRIGON-MTS, Moenchengladbach, Germany). During dilatation the balloon was filled with pure Gd-DTPA contrast medium in all patients. Beside C02 angiography the results of interventions were controlled with intraarterial pressure measurement.Results: Technical success (residual stenosis <30% and a postinterventional mean resting gradient <10 mm Hg) was achieved in all cases. 13 of 17 patients had a positive c1inical benefit with improvement of their PVD stage according to the Fontaine c1assification. Methods and Materials: Thirty-four patients (17 men, 17 women; mean age 68, years) with symptomatic PAD (category 3: n = 15; 4: n = 7 and 5: n = 12) underwent transcutaneous oxygen pressure measurements at the dorsum of the foot 24 hours before PTA, during PTA, 24 hours after PTA and 6 weeks after PTA. A control group was measured at the same time points. The control group consisted ofthirty-one patients (21 men, 10 women; mean age 68.5 years) with PAD (3: n =14; 4: n =4; 5: n = 12) undergoing diagnostic intraarterial angiography.

FIGREF294.text: Acute pyelonephritis -B-mode, color Doppler and power Doppler in detection of focal renal hypoperfusion M. Brzewski, A. Marcinski, B. Fracka, A. Jakubowska, J. Madzik; WarsawlPLPurpose: In acute bacterial pylonephritis, intratubular obstruction, enzymatic destruction and bacterial invasion of the intrestitium results in inflamation, parenchymal edema, and intense vasoconstriction of the arteries and anterioles in the inflamed region. The purpose of this study was to determine the value of color Doppler and power Doppler in detection of focal renal hypoperfusion. Methods and Materials: 36 children with clinical suspicion upper urinary tract infection were diagnosed by ultrasound during 24 hrs after the admission to our hospital. 20, color Doppler and power Doppler were used to exam each of patients. We use in all cases the same ultrasound unit and transducers 4-7 MHz. Results: The focal lesions were detected in 21 children, within 28 kidneys. We detected areas of hypoperfusion in both scans: longitudinal and axial. In B-mode sonography focal changes we observed only in 9 kidney, in color Doppler in 20 kidney and in power Doppler in 28 kidney. Conclusion: Power Doppler sonography semms to be a useful method for detection of acute pyelonephritis in children. It is more sensitive than B-mode and color Doppler sonography.14:45

Landwehr; Münster, Cologne/D Invasive vascular imaging by means of catheters and contrast media has been the gold standard for the diagnostic work-up of peripheral arterial and venous vessels in the last decades. The purpose of this course is to describe techniques suited for non-invasive vascular imaging and to discuss their current c1inical applications for imaging of peripheral vessels. Principles for applying Ultrasound, CT-Angiography (CTA), and Magnetic Resonance Angiography (MRA) for non-invasive imaging of peripheral arte ries and veins are presented. C/inical applications are reviewed for different vascular diseases, therapy planning, and followup studies. Conventional Doppler and color duplex are the most costeffective procedures to detect or rule out peripheral arterial occlusive disease (PAOD) and to provide specific recommendations for therapy. Caretle; ParislF Purpose: To compare contrast-enhanced pulmonary MR angiography (CE-MRA) which is a new noninvasive method without irradiation, with HCT, for the diagnos is of pulmonary arteriovenous malformations (PAVMs). Methods and Materials: 16 patients with a total of 56 CT scans were reviewed. Diagnosis relied either on multiple positive cultures (n =16),or on open lung biopsy specimen (n = 6). CT findings were analysed using a specific set of diagnostic criteria. Four consecutive patients with PAVMs underwent HCT, CE-MRA during the pulmonary arterial phase and pulmonary artery digital substraction angiography during embolisation procedure . CE-MRA images were reviewed for the presence of PAVMs precising the localization, the size of the aneurysm and the diameter of the vascular pedicles. Results: 37 PAVMs were detected by HCr. All of the 19 PAVMs aneurysm equal or superior to 5 mm in diameter and 10 of 18 PAVMs aneurysm inferior to 5 mm in diameter identified on HCT were identified on CE-MRA (29/37). Methods and Materials: 3 female and 6 male patients (age 20-68 years) with suspected pulmonary embolism, pulmonary hypertens ion or vascular anomaly underwent contrast-enhanced 3D spoiled gradientecho recalled sequence (spgr) pulmonary angiography. Findings were correlated with spiral CT or angiography. Parameters of the 3D spgr sequence were: 28 slices of 3.8-4.4 mm , 28-36 ml Gd-DTPA, scan time 18-26 sec, 0.5 NEX. Results: Pulmonary embolism could be diagnosed or excluded up to segmental level. Good opacification of the subsegmental arteri es was seen in all patients . Complex pulmonary arterial anomaly in one patient each with lung transplantation and Fallot's tetralogy could be very weil depicted with MR angiography. Methods and Materials: 3 PK-and 10 K-Tx patients underwent MRA and non-selective La. DSA with in a 3 days interval. A 17 sec . 3D Flash fatsuppress ing pulse . sequence (TRITE 3.8/1.3, 30°) with a slice interpolation technique was repeated 4 limes. Results: In the CIA 4 stenotic areas were equally identified on MRA and DSA MRA under-and overeslimated resp. 2 and 1 stenosis compared to DSA in the EIA Pancreas Tx: Arterial occlusions were scored equallyon both MRA and DSA Perfusion and splenic-portal vein were seen better on MRA . Haberal; AnkaralTR Purpose: The purpose of this study is to assess the capab ility of gadolinium-enhanced magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) in show-ing the number and the variations of renal arteries of living renal transplant donors. Methods and Materials: Renal arteries of 30 renal donors (22-65 years old) were examined by using single breathusing multiple intensity projection technique. Source and MIP images were evaluated. The results were compared with standard angiography (SA) in all patients. Results: 26 patients had single renal artery bilaterally whereas 4 patients had unilateral double arteries on MRA and SA. Bilateral early bifurcation of renal arteries in one patient was shown successfully on MRA. 5 of 7 polar branches were demonstrated successfully in 5 patients on MRA. Conclusion: 3D Gd-enhanced MRA can be substituted SA in renal transplant donors as a fast and noninvasive technique. Lammer, SA Thurnher; ViennalAPurpose: To determine the potential of contrast-enhanced MRA in diagnosis of peripheral bypass graft in comparison to digital subtraction angiography (DSA) as standard of reference. Methods and Materials: 27 patients with previous peripheral bypass graft surgery underwent DSA and contrast-enhanced MRA within two weeks. Every leg was divided into eleven segments and scored in five categories of stenosis. A total of 38 bypass grafts and 455 segments on 38 extremities were classified. Images were interpreted in a blinded manner. Results: In 33 (87%) bypass grafts stenosis grading by both methods was corresponding, in 3 (8%) patients, stenosis was overestimated by MRA for one class and in 2 (5%) cases for two categories. In 332 (73%) vascular segments there was conformity in graduation, in 37 (8%), there was a difference of 1 grade, in 29 (6%) of 2 grades, in 5 (1%) of 3 grades and in 7 (2%) segments there was an overestimation by MRA of 4 grades. 45 segments (10%) could not be c1assified because of technical limitations. (Submitted by Internet) 11:20 1162 Assessment of dilated Iymphaties of the breast by MR imaging A-E. Mahfouz, H. Sherif, B. Karle, M. Taupitz, B. Hamm; Cairo/ET, Ber/in/O Purpose: To assess feasibility and utility of demonstrating dilated Iymphatics of the breast on MRI. Methods and Materials: Seventy-four women were examined. They had histologically proven malignancy in 40 breast, benign lesions in 26 breasts, no lesions on one-year follow-up in 64 breasts, and previous surgery/radiotherapy in 18 breasts. T2-weighted FSE (4200/140) was performed followed by T1-weighted gradient-echo (11/4.6/25°) before and 90, 180,270, and 360 sec after injection of Gd-DTPA. Craniocaudal and mediolateral maximum intensity projections (MIP) of T2-weighted and subtracted gadolinium-enhanced images were evaluated by two blinded readers. Results: Three types of hyperintensities were encountered on the MIP-T2-weighted images: rounded (cysts), linear that corresponded to vessels on gadolinium-enhanced MIP images, and linear structures that did not correspond to vessels on gadolinium-enhanced MIP images (dilated Iymphatics). Dilated Iymphatics were seen in 27 of 40 breasts that harbor malignant neoplasms (67.5%), 6 of90 breasts with benign or no lesions (6.6%), and 11 of the 18 previously treated breasts (61.1 %). Statistically, dilated Iymphatics were indicative of malignancy or previous surgery/radiotherapy to the breast (p < .001). Conelusion: Dilated Iymphatics can be demonstrated on MIP-T2weighted MR images. This sign is indicative of malignancy with specificity of 93.3% and sensitivity of 67.5%. Dei Maschio; Mi/an/l Purpose: To define the role of dynamic MRI in detecting unknown primary carcinoma in patients with metastatic lesions suspected to be from breast carcinoma. Methods and Materials: Eleven patients with carcinoma metastases histologically suspected to be from breast carcinoma primary, with negative mammography and US examinations, underwent dynamic MRI study (Gd-DTPA 0.1 mmol/Kg body weight) with FAST 3D SPGR sequences. Examinations were elaborated with image substraction, MIP, multiplanar reconstruction and quantitative analysis. When identified at MR examination, lesions were searched with US and if found, examined with FNAB. Patients with positive MR reports underwent surgery. Results: Eight patients had metastases localized in axillary Iymph nodes; two in bones; and one in both lungs and bones. MR identified five patients out of eleven (45%) with breast lesions (1/5 multifocal) not detected by traditional examinations. At histology 4/5 breasts had malignant lesions, 1/5 benign. Conclusion: Our results, although not so remarkable as some found in the literature, confirm that MR is a useful technique to detect metastatic occult breast carcinomas. 8262 1166 Pitfalls and technical Iimitations in MRI of chronic osteomyelitis of the legs H.P. Suri; Chandigarh//ND Purpose: To determine the severity and extent of emphysema in heavy smokers by high resolution computerized tomography (HRCT) and to correlate the findings with spirometrie tests (ST) & symptomatology. Methods and Materials: 50 adult smokers underwent HRCT and ST (FEV1, FEV1/FVC, PEFR). HRCT was performed using 1 mm thick sections at 2 cm intervals beginin 2 cm above aortic arch upto a total of 10 sections. Quantification of emphysema was done using density mask programme used by Mueller et al and visual scoring method used by Sakai et al. FIGREF359.text: Emphysema and airflow limitation in patients with advanced COPD: a CT study RJ.S. Lamers, G.J. Kemerink, E.F.M. Wouters, J.M.A. van Engelshoven; MaastrichtlNLPurpose: To assess prospectively the association of emphysema with airflow limitation in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (CO PD) Methods and Materials: One hund red patients with COPD as defined by the American Thoraeie Society participated in this study. The population was subdivided into three groups based on forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV 1) % pred. results: stage I COPD is FEV 1 50-70% pred. (n =27); stage 11 COPD is FEV1 35-49% pred. (n =32); and stage 111 COPD is FEV 1 < 35% pred. (n =41). Five thin-section CT scans were obtained at full inspiration. Each slice was scored to a visual CT emphysema score (CT-ES) by two radiologists according to the observational method of Sakai. The mean CT-ES of both observers was calculated. This score could range from zero (no emphysema) to 120 (severe emphysema). Results: The mean CT-ES for stage I COPD was 12 and significantly lower than for stage 11 COPD (37, P < 0.005) and for stage 111 COPD (48, P < 0.0001). In 85% of patients with stage I COPD the CT-ES < 30 indicating no or trivial emphysema. In 47% of patients with stage 111 COPD the CT-ES was >60 indicating moderate or severe emphysema. Conclusion: Results suggest a distinct presence and degree of emphysema in patients with advanced COPD.10:50 1179 Pulmonary emphysema -quantitative evaluation in high resolution computed tomography (HRCT) and pulmonary function tests (PFT) M. Zabicka, A. Frank-Piskorska, E. Skrobowska, E. Luczak, R Malinowski, P. Maleszka, E. Bielczynska, P. Twarkowski; Warsaw/PL Purpose: The extent of changes in patients with clinical and radiological diagnosis of pulmonary emphysema was quantify in high resolution computed tomography examination (HRCT) and pulmonary function tests (PFT). Methods and Materials: HRCT were done in full inspiration for 24 patients (age 55-73). The type and extent of emphysema were evaluated, the mean lung density (MLD) and the relative area of the lung with attenuation values lower then -950 HU (RA 950) were measured. Pulmonary function was assessed by indices: forced expiratory volume in 1 sec (FEV 1), FEV1/vital capacity (VC) ratio (FEV1 %VC), forced expiratory flow in 50% of VC (FEF50), totallung capacity (TLC), residual volume (RV), RVITLC ratio (RV%TLC), intra thora eie gas volume (ITGV). Results: HRCT recognized emphysema as centrilobular in 6, as paraseptal in 11 and as mixed type in 7 cases. Mean MLD was -895.8 ± 25.3 HU (-836.9 HU to -937.8 HU). Mean RA 950 was 19.9 ± 18.4% (2% to 77%). Mean vaJues of puJmonary function tests in percentage of predicted were: FEV1 = 58.2 ± 24.3%, FEV1%VC = 74.3 ± 28%, FEF50 = 27.2 ± 16.1%, TLC = 122.4 ± 17.1%, RV = 192.3 ± 40.1%, RV%TLC =150.2 ± 24.8%, ITGV =163 ± 28.8%. Significant negative correlation between FEV1 and RA 950 (r = -0.5186; P = 0.009) and, in lesser degree, positive correlation between FEV1 and MLD (r =0.4049; p =0.050) was found. The relation between RA950 and ITGV was also positive and significant (r = 0.4875; P = 0.040). Conclusion: The radiologic index of the extent of pulmonary emphysema RA 950 correlate significantly with the functional index of emphysema ITGV and with the index of expiratory airflow obstruction FEV1. The mean Jung density MLD correJate with the index of airflow obstructlon FEV1. determine the functional impact of concurrent emphysema in cryptogenic fibrosing alveolitis (CFA). Methods and Materials: Thin-section computed tomography (CT) scans in 160 CFA patients (males = 119, females =41; median age = 63 yrs [range = 26-84 years]) were reviewed independently by two observers. The extent and severity of CT patterns were quantified visually; in CFA patients with coexistent emphysema identified on CT (CFA EMPH) (n = 63), the distribution of emphysema, relative to the fibrosis, was quantified. Functional indices were correlated with CT features.

HRCT scans in patients with obstructive airways disease: effect of bronchodilatation on focal air-trapping JA Verschakelen, K. Trap, L. Oupont, J. Bogaert, G. Verleden, M. Oemedts; LeuvenlB Purpose: To examine the effect of bronchodilatation on inhomogeneous lung attenuation at expiratory HRCT in patients with obstructive airways disease. Methods and Materials: Twenty-four patients with symptoms suggestive for airways disease entered the study and were subdivided in 3 subgroups: A (n = 7): % reversibility of FEV1 (% REV) ::::15% = asthma; B (n =8): % REV :S 5% =COPO; C (n =9): % REV 6-14% =mixed group. In each patient, both before and 30 min after bronchodilatation (BO) with 400 mg salbutamol and at 3 lung levels (aortic arch, hilum, lung base), extent of air-trapping was scored and mean inspiratory and expiratory lung density (MLO) was calculated.Results: Focal areas of air-trapping were seen in 14 (A = 3; B = 5; C = 6) patients before and in 16 (A =4; B = 4; C =8) patients after SO. Airtrapping scores were not significantly different nor between groups, nor when compared before and after BO. At all measured levels MLO was significantly lower at full inspiration (TLC) than at full expiration (RV) (p < 0.05). In group A, MLO at RV was significantly higher post SO than pre BO (MLO 3 levels =-688.3 ± 121.4 HU vs -732.1 ± 112.1 HU P < 0.05). This was not the case in group Band C (B: -778.9 ± 37.7 vs -779.5 ± 36.7; C: -734.9 ± 36.5 vs -756.5 ± 37.1).ConcJusion: In our groUP of patients with obstructive lung disease, presence and extent of focal air-trapping were not influenced by BO even when PFT showed high % of reversibility of FEV1 and when MLO measurement indicated a significant increase of expiratory lung density.11:30 1183 Expiratory HRCT detecting subclinical Jung injury after ingestion of sauropus androgynus M.T. The evaluation contained the number of detected lesions in the individual liver segments but also false positive and false negative results. Verification by means of histology and intraoperative ultrasound. Results: With CTAP 43 out of 44 Iiver lesions could be detected, with MR imaging 37 with preference to the FLASH-sequence. False positive CTAP 3, MRI 0 and false negative CTAP 1 and MRI 7. A dependence on the lesion size (maximum diameter of 1 cm) of the false negative in MRI was found. MRI showed 100% positive resectability. Conclusion: With Teslascan®-supported MR imaging enough lesions are detectable despite the lower sensitivity in comparison to spiral CTAP. False negative results in MRI are based on technical difficulties and not on imperfection of the contrast medium. Thus in the near future Teslascan®-supported MR imaging seems to be the method of choice in the detection of liver lesions. (Submitted by Internet) 14:25 1278 Non-invasive assessment of vascular disease in infants and children: value of fast contrast-enhanced MR-angiography M. Taupitz, I. Scheer, D. Kivelitz, B. Stöver, I.J. Kröncke, B. Hamm; BerlinlD Purpose: To evaluate the diagnostic value of contrast enhanced MR angiography in the assessment of vascular disease in pediatric patients. Methods and Materials: A total of 21 children (2 weeks-17 years) was examined at 1.5 Tesla using fast interpolated 3D GRE-sequences (turbo-MRA, TR = 3.2-6.2 msec, TE = 1.1-1.9 msec, alpha = 35, acquisition times: 5-21 sec) after bolus injection of a Gadolinium containing extracellular contrast agent (0.2 mmol Gd/kg). Arterial and venous phase data sets were acquired during breath-holds in cooperative children (6 years) or during general anesthesia with short intervals of suspended respiration (younger children and infants). Maximal intensity projections were evaluated qualitatively. Results: In 20/21 cases MR-angiograms of good or excellent quality were obtained. In all cases MR angiograms provided significant diagnostic information. Pathologies included: vascular malformations (isolated or in combination with various syndromes, n = 11), arterial occlusion (posttraumatic or iatrogenic, n =5), renal pathologies (n =3) vascular tumor infiltration (n = 2). Conclusion: Ultrafast contrast enhanced MR angiography allows accurate assessment of vascular pathologies in pediatric patients. Invasive procedures like conventional angiography and administration of X-ray contrast media can be avoided. FIGREF385.text: Non-invasive assessment of cervical artery dissection F. Roncallo, I. Turtulici, B. Gasparetto, A. Bartolini; Genoa/l Purpose: Cervical Artery Dissection (CAD) account for up to one fifht of ischemic strokes occurring before 45 years. Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) remains the gold standard for evaluating CAD. We investigated the accuracy of non-invasive radiological techniques such Ultrasounds (US), Magnetic Resonance Imaging and Magnetic Resonance Angiography (MRI-MRA), Computed Tomographyand Computed Tomographic Angiography (CT-CTA) compared to DSA in the assessment of CAD. Methods and Materials: We have monitored six patients with CAD (four male, two female; 32-67 years old). All patients performed DSA, US, MRI-MRA and CT-CTA within the first two weeks from the c1inical onset. Patients are then followed up with US alone (3 patients) or combined with CTA (3 patients) at 3 months to 2 years. Results: 4 patients had internal carotid artery dissection; 1 had vertebral artery (V1 and V2) dissection; 1 had multiple neck vessel dissections, that were correctly demonstrated by CTA and DSA in all cases. In five cases US overestimated the stenosis, showing a false occlusion pattern. MRI-MRA weil showed mural hematoma in the subacute stage (2 patients), homolateral reduced intracranial blood flow and brain damage (3 patients). Conclusion: The favorable natural history of CAD emphasizes the need for a non-invasive approach to the detection, monitoring and followup. A combined morphological and functional analysis of the brain and of the neck arteries is mandatory. Because the three sets of CTA images correctly depict arterial wall and lumen without flow artifacts, this technique may be cosidered the new method of choice for the assessment of CAD.14:55 1281 Carotid stenting follow-up: comparison of angiography (DSA), CT-angiography (eTA) and duplex sonography (US) U. v. Cammisa; San Giovanni Rotondoll ABDOMINAL AND GASTROINTESTINAL 111901 How to diagnose focal Iiver lesions: US, CT, MR Over the past years, a large variety of non invasive techniques have been developed to quantify Bone Mineral Density (BMD) for the assessment of skeletal status in osteoporosis. Nevertheless, fracture occurrence in osteoporosis does not depend on BMD alone. Studies have shown that a deereased bone mass is only one of the several faetors influeneing the risk of fracture and BMD can account for only 70--80% of the variability in the strength of bone. Other factors related to fracture independently of BMD such as trabecular microarchitecture, bone elasticity and bone strength appear to be relevant to enhance the prediction of fracture risk. Hahn; WürzburglD Purpose: Due to the low resolution in conventional ultrasound imaging there are only limited results in the examination of interphalangeal joints regarding signs of inflammation, morphology of the cartilage and the synovia. In this study we tested the value of high resolution Multi-D-Array for the examination of interphalangeal joints in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) refering to signs of inflammation and discrete morphologic alterations. Methods and Materials: We examined the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints of the fingers 11 and 111 in 10 healthy persons (20-30 years old), in 10 patients with active arthritis in RA and in 10 patients with chronic swelling of the joints because of RA. A Sonoline Elegra (Siemens) with a Multi-D-Array, VFX 13-5 (B-mode 12.0 MHz, Colour-mode 9.0 MHz) was used. Criteria were morphology of the cartilage, proliferation of the synovia and vascularisation of the synovia.

FIGREF432.text: MR-angiography of the hand U. Krause , T. Pabst , S. Fischer , W. Kenn, M.W. Kellner, G. Wittenberg , O. Hahn; Würzburg/D Purpose: The purpose of this study was to optimize different MRAtechniques and to evaluate MRA of the hand in comparison to La.-OSA. Methods and Materials: MRA examinations were performed on a Siemens Magnetom Vision (1.5 T) equipped with a flexible surface coil. The protocol contained time of f1ight, phase contrast, rephased/dephased and contrast enhanced techniques. To improve angiogram quality the hand was placed in warm water before imaging. Maximum Intensity projection was employed for postprocessing. Results: 15 healthy volunteers and 36 patients were exam ined . All images were of diagnostic quality. Best results concerning the detection of digita l arteries were obtained with TOF-techniques. Complete delineation of digital arte ries was possible in all examina ted healthy volunteers. MRA showed a high correlation of the pathological findings detected in La.-OSA, which was performed in 7 patients. In comparison to La.-OSA additional arterial segments were seen by MRA . Vasospasms didn't appear. Conclusion: MRA of the hand with optimized protocols is a robust procedure with promising results . Bigot; Paris/F Purpose: To improve the renal veins visualization in MR phlebography.Methods and Materials: MR was performed in a Siemens Vision machine on 59 patients. We used fisp 3D sequences for angiography and phlebography of the renal vessels. Mean a mechanic injector (Spectris, Medrad) we performed a circulation time curve and a MRA. MR phlebography was obtained 10 seconds after the MRA on 33 patients (group A), after the calculation of the venous delay time: time difference between arterial and venous peak + time of the acquisitlon + duration of the injection on 26 patients (group B). Images were evaluated using a 4 degree scale. Results: Significative improvement in visualization of the renal veins was obtained mean the calculation ofthe venous time using our method. In all cases of the group B the renal veins were opacified, in 34% of the cases of the group A no evaluation was possible. A good or very good opacification of the renal veins was obtained in 46% of the patients of the group A and in 100% of the patients of the group B. Conclusion: Accurate MR phlebography of the renal veins can be obtained using our method to calculate the venous delay time.Methods and Materials: In 114 patients with 134 adrenal masses , MR findings were compared with histologie results . Lateral views will show the slip but CT and MR evaluate the degree and the possible complications of avascular necrosis and chondrolysis. Inflammation: Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis may present as an irritable hip. Ultrasound shows an effusion and radiographs have slight lateralisation of the head and a degree of osteoporosis. MR using dynamic Gadolinium show intense enhancement of the synovium. Bone Tumours: Intra-articular tumours include chondroblastroma, which appear as a weil defined lucency extending from the epiphyseal plate into the femoral head and metaphysis and intra-articular osteoid osteomas which show osteoporosis, while Tc 99 bone scans may show local or generalised uptake, CT is particularly vaiuaote in identifying the focus of the osteoid osteoma and MR will identify the extent of the oedema in bone. For imaging of the liver, biliary traet, and pelvis, US has become the modality of choice. US is valuable in imaging patients with localized pain, such as cholecystitis or appendicitis. CT has assumed growing importance and at times is essential for accurate further evaluation. CT is particularly beneficial in patients with marked obesity, unelear ultrasound findings, bowel distension, malignancy, and multiple lesions.

TABREF47.text: Helical CT may play an important role in helping confirm or exciude the presence of bronchogenic carcinoma. Contrast enhancement of pulmonary nodule appears to be a good indicator of malignancy. Normal or definitely benign findings may obviate thoracotomy. In other situations as specificity of CT is limited, histologie evaluation or careful follow up remains necessary. Information about ehest wall and mediastinal invasion is still one of the most important factors in the clinical decision to perform surgery. Although certain CT findings demonstrated as being diagnostic of unresectable disease may obviate thoracotomy, tumor contiguity with adjacent mediastinal ehest wall structures is not equivalent of definite invasion. Helical scanning with thin collimation and bolus injection of contrast media during breath hold over the area of contiguity, and multiplanar reconstruction, facilitate the analysis of tumor invasion into adjacent structures. MR remains indicated only in cases in which the CT findings are inconclusive and in those in which extension into the neural foramina and epidural space is Because of its relatively low sensitivity and specificity, CT has limited value in staging mediastinal Iymph nodes. Lymphography obtained by an intravenous injection of superparamagnetic iron oxide nanoparticles is promising in distinguishing hyperplastic and tumorous Iymph nades.Urinary tract infections remain among the most common bacterial infections in children. Renal scarring from recurrent infection is an important cause of end-stage renal disease and hypertension in the pediatric population. Main risk factors for development of pyelonephritic scarring are obstructive malformations, vesico-ureteral reflux, young age and delayed or insufficient therapy. Imaging diagnostic techniques are of paramount importance for evaluation of the child with urinary tract infection and identification of those at risk for infection. Only early diagnosis and prompt institution of proper therapy reduce the Iikelihood of renal scarring and hence, improve child's outcome. In this course, the current status of the pathogenesis of acute renal infection in children and available imaging methods will be discussed.

Metens;The ineidenee of ehronie lung disease in children is low relative to adults. The causes are generally different. Though the underlying cause may be congenital in origin, such as cystic fibrosis or immune deficiency states, the development of the disease is gradual and progressive. Clinical management is to maintain respiratory function and to control infection -the main cause of deterioration. Clinical symptoms in children are mainly those of tachypnoea diminished effort tolerance, cough and repeated infections. The diagnosis is often difficult, with the initial symptoms or infection being treated as simple infection. By the time the correct diagnosis is made, lung damage is often severe. The radiological management and investigation is primarily by ehest radiographs, supplemented by high resolution CT and va lung scans.Chairperson: G. GELL (GrazlA) 303 A. TABREF54.text: The radiographic examination of an infant with skeletal dysplasia is a typical event in pediatric radiology. Constitutional skeletal dysplasia is Prostate cancer is the second most common cause of cancer deaths in the United States and Europe. Early diagnosis and staging is important, as prostate cancer is a curable disease if detected early. While new findings regarding genetic predisposition and environmental factors may lead to the definition of potential risk groups, the relative lack of knowledge about the biological behavior of prostate cancer remains the greatest challenge to the c1inical management of this disease at the current time. TransrectaI ultrasound (TRUS) supplemented by color and power Doppler is primarily used for biopsy guidance, directing biopsies of suspicious hypoechoic or hypervascular areas within the prostate gland or systematic sextant biopsies of the entire gland. Endorectal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) shows promise for local staging, but its use is still controversial due to variable diagnostic accuracy (54-89%) and concerns about costs. MR spectroscopic imaging is a promising new technique which provides metabolic information about the prostate gland based on the detection of the metabolites creatine, citrate and choline. This new approach may improve local tumor staging as weil as provide information on tumor aggressiveness. Better imaging evaluation will lead to better tumor control by helping to guide treatment. The development of new forms of palliative therapy, supported by imaging, mayaiso ultimately improve the quality of Iife of patients with prostate cancer.Prostate cancer (PC) is the number 2 cause of cancer death in the USA and most European countries. It has to be emphasized that PC is a curable disease if detected early enough. New findings about genetic infiuences as weil as environmental factors may lead to definitions of potential risk groups. Moreover innovative forms of imaging as weil as novel biological markers may lead to even better detection rates. Nevertheless staging inaccuracy and lack of knowledge about the biological behaviour of PC impedes an optimal therapeutical approach. Better understanding of functional anatomical aspects would help to improve surgical tumour control by reducing side effects. New forms of palliative treatment for metastatic diseases will help to improve quality of Iife in PC patients. Better understanding of hormonal manipulations as weil as non-hormonal treatment regimens will also improve palliation results and together with the application of new radiopharmacenticals may increase survival in the future.

TABREF55.text: 310 Role of MRI/MRSI and CT in staging prostate cancer fi"Hricak ; San Francisco, CAIUSA Imaging prostate cance r is a subje ct of controversy. The recommendations range from denial to strong advocacy for imaging prior to therapy decision. Considering the disagreement about prostate cancer detect ion and choice of treatment, the debate concerning imaging is not surpr ising. Bone scan and computed tomography (CT) supplement clinical and biochemical evaluation (PSA, prostate acid phosphatase) for search of suspected metastatic disease with accepted appropriateness criteria for their use. Serum PSA is used to eliminate unnecessary bone scans (in patients with PSA < 10 ng/ml) and CT scans (in patients with PSA < 20 ng/ml). Guidelines for evaluation of locoregional extenl, however, have not been established and the diagnostic efficacy of both TRUS and MRI remains debatable . Although endorectal MRI shows the rnost promise for local staging, its role ls controversial due to its high cost and variable diagnostic accura cy (54% to 89%). One of the major problems is interobserver variability and lack of reprodu cibility. The recent development of MR spectroscopic imaging expands the diagnostic assessment beyond anatom ie information. MR spectroscopic imag ing provides metabolie information specific to the prostate through the detection of the cellular metabolites citrate, creatine , and choline . The information obta ined from this new technology may allow an expanded assessment of tumor aggress iveness and the attendant risk of disease progression.CT features were correlated several funct ional indices . TABREF87.text: 448 T2-weighted MRI of focal Iiver lesions: non-breathheld T2-weighted MRI versus breathheld T2-W MRI with hybrid-techniques P. Reimer, H. Kricke, K. WörtIer, E.J. Rummeny; MünsterlD Purpose: To prospectively analyze the clinical performance of various breath held T2-weighted pulse sequences for the detection and characterization of focal liver lesions. Methods and Materials: Unselected patients (n =68) with suspected liver lesions were enrolled into the study. There were 19 patients with benign lesions, 25 with malignant lesions, and 24 patients without lesions. Non-breathheld TSE (TR 5000 ms, TE 83 + 165 ms, sections, TA 18 s). Lesion detection and lesion characterization was performed by two blinded readers. Results were analyzed based on a goldstandard consisting of histopathology for malignant lesions and follow-up for benign lesions and patients without lesions. Results: Lesion detection based on a total of 116 proven lesions was best for HASTE with a TE of 90 ms (100/116; sensitivity 86.2%). The two TSE sequences did not show significantly different results with 95/116 for the non-breathheld sequence and 94/116 for the breathheld sequence. Detection was lower for HASTE with a TE of 64 ms (89/116) and EPI (73/116). Results for lesion characterization were comparable. Conclusion: Optimized breathheld T2-W HASTE sequences can be used as routine sequences for unenhanced T2-weighted liver MR imaging.
