Carbone; Rome/l Patency rate in malignant biliary obstruction depends on the type of stent used. Conclusion: Percutaneous approach is very valuable both in malignant hilar lesions and in benign lesions after repeated surgery, especially when complicated by lithiasis. Purpose: To document the validity of percutaneous approach to both benign and malignant biliary obstruction. Methods and Materials: Over the last 20 years, we have performed elose to 3,000 percutaneous treatments for biliary obstruction; approximately 1/10 of lesions were of benign nature, while the remaining ones were malignant. In case of malignant lesions, we have used metallic stents. In benign lesions, multiple dilations were preferred leaving the catheter in situ for a few months until infection subsided. In presence of biliary stones, both intra-and extra-hepatic, we have performed percutaneous cholangioscopy and electrohydraulic lithotripsy. Uncovered metallic stents have been inserted in approximately 170 patients with malignant obstruction, while covered metallic stents have been employed in 21 malignant cases. Results: Benign lesions: we have had 70% of excellent results at 10year follow-up. In case of biliary lithiasis, we have had 83% of complete resolution when using electrohydraulic lithotripsy. Malignant lesions: Chairperson: S. LAURIN (Lund/S) 581 Spinal canal disorders in children: a combined neuroradiologic-neurosurgical approach using MRI P. Winkler, J. Krauß; Stuttgart, Würzburg/D Numerous recent technical innovations in US Doppler and MR imaging have dramatically improved the imaging evaluation of musculoskeletal disorders in children. US doppler and MR imaging now allow both visualization of cartilage and depiction of joint vascularity and perfusion. Power Doppler US and gadolinium-enhanced MR imaging allow the study of femoral head vascularity in neonates and the detection of positional ischemia.Proper use of gadolinium administration, imaging timing, subtraction or fat suppression techniques is critical and is dependent on child's age and suspected abnormality. Tailored protocols are necessary to obtain either perfusion study (cartilage, physis, bone marrow, synovium, osseous center) or indirect MR arthrography. New magnets offer the potential for unrestricted motion studies and dynamic MR arthrography. Applicalions to disorders pertaining to specific anatomie areas, such as the hip, will be given. New imaging techniques in musculoskeletal disorders in children G. Sebag, S. Lamer; Paris/F

TABREF117.text: In the last decade an increasing number of fast imaging techniques on the base of gradient echo (GE), turbo spin echo (TSE) and echo planar imaging (EPI) sequences have been developed to speed up examination and to shorten scan time in MRI. In general this fast MRI techniques have only partially succeded to increase patient throughput but are instead often used to introduce new diagnostic procedures for structural and functional imaging of the brain and the body. Therefore GE, TSE, and EPI sequences are meanwhile fully integrated in a large variety of c1inical imaging protocols to enhance diagnostic specificity and to promote medical research. In this course the c1inical application586 B. Primary hepatie malignant neoplasms V. Vilgrain, B. Terris; ClichylFSonography, helieal CT, and magnetie resonanee (MR) imaging are powerful tools in the evaluation of primary malignant liver tumors. Tumor deteetion is usually made at sonography, whereas tumor eharaeterization and determination of tumor extent are provided with helieal CT and MR imaging. Intravenously administered eontrast agents at CT or MR imaging provide additional opportunities for lesion eharacterization and allow to differentiate hypervaseular tumors from hypovaseular tumors. Knowledge of gross and microseopie pathologie features of primary malignant liver neoplasms helps for a better understanding of their imaging appearanees. The authors eorrelate the key pathologie features with the most signifieant imaging findings of primary malignant Iiver tumors, including hepatoeellular carcinomas developed in eirrhotie or non-eirrholie liver, peripheral eholangioeareinoma, epithelioid hemangioendothelioma, and angiosareoma.The purpose of this course is to review the Imaging Findings of the most frequent benign Iiver neoplasms and tumor-Iike eonditions, using a radiologie-pathologie eorrelation approach. For eaeh entity, the key underlying pathologie features are presented emphasizing the ones with impact in the imaging findings. The imaging findings by ultrasound, CT and MRI seans are diseussed for eaeh tumor, highlighting the most important features that allow in most eases to eharaeterize these tumors. The main tumors to be deseribed inelude hemangioma, hepatoeellular adenoma and foeal nodular hyperplasia. Other benign tumors such as eysts, lipoma, angiomyolipoma, von Meyenberg eomplex, ete., are also mentioned. At the eompletion of the course, attendees should be able to understand the features that allow by imaging to eharaeterize the major benign hepatie neoplasms and tumor-like eonditions.Chairpersons: J.-M. BRUEL (Montpellier/F) P.C. MUZZIO (Padoall)

TABREF118.text: 590 Evaluation of an optimized MRI-technlque in Crohn's disease -preliminary results K.-P. Jung ius, J. Gaa , R. Botte, H. Gerha rdt, J. Rabe, M. Georgi ; MannheimlDPurpose: To evaluate wether high resolut ion magnetic resonanee imaging (MRI) can be optimized in patients wilh enteral inflammation caused by Crohn's disease by performing the MRI examination after enteral liquid application. Methods and Materials: 18 patients with histologically verified Crohn's disease underwent MRI either immediately after diagnostic entereclysma (11) or without enteral liquid application (7). MRI was performed with fast breath-hold sequences: T1-FLASH-20-GRE with and without tat suppression (FS) before and after l.v. application of 0.1 mmol Gd-OTPNkg; T2-TSE, HASTE . Investigations were performed on a Magnetom Vision 1.5 T scanner (Siemens Medical Systems, Erlangen, Germany). Results: MRI after enleroclysma allowed for excellent delineation of both the bowel wall and the infammation of the surrounding tissue . There was a good correlation between lhe activity of Crohn 's disease of the enleroclysma and the MRI find ings . After Gd-infusion patients with aetive inflammation showed marked enh ancement in the bowel wall whereas patients with minor inflamation showed only moderate signal enhancement. Conclusion: Post-enteroclysma MRI is an excellent addition to eonventional imaging in primary diagnosis of Crohn's disease . In follow up-stud ies MRI without prior enteroclysma could be able to be the first imaging procedure in those patients. Limitations of this teehnique might be still in lhe deteetion of subtile lesions.591 Magnetic resonance imaging of the gastrointestinal tract in Crohn's disease O.M. Koh, J.C. Healy, R. Chinn , Z. Am in, Y. Miao, R. Zeegan, O. Westaby; LondonlUK Purpose: To evaluate the use of MR imaging In the assessment of aetive Crohn's disease.Methods and Materials: 30 patients with Crohn's disease were referred for MRI. They were scored elinieally for disease aetivity using the Crohn's disease aetivity index (CDAI) . MRI was performed using breathhold sequences before and after intravenous contrast. MR images were interpreted blind to COAI to determine if there was aetive or inaetive gastrointestinal disease. MR findings were eorrelated with c1inical scoring . Results: Analysis of the first 20 cases show goOO correlation between MR findings and elinical seoring . In 15 patients with aetive disease , MRI demonstrated thiek walled (mean 7.9 mm , range 4-15 mm) segments of bowel. The mean length of involvement was 10.7 em (range 2-45 em). All inflamed segments showed contrast enhancement follow ing IV. Gadolin ium. The pattern of enhancement was diffuse (65%) or layered (33%). Increased per ienterie vaseular ity analogous to the "eomb sign" on CT was seen in all patients. An abscess was identified in 1 patient. In 5 patients with c1inieally quiescent disease, no bowel wall thiekening or enhaneement was seen. MR identified a fibrotie strieture in 1 patient. Conclusion: MRI is useful in assessing disease aetivity in Crohn 's disease. MRI may be useful in assessing Crohn's disease aetivity in eases where COAI score is equivoeal.592 Fast hydro-MRI of Crohn's disease: comparison with follow-through examinations K. Sehunk , A. Kern, C.P. Heussei, P. Kalden, T. Orlh, M. Thel en ; MainzlD Purpose: To compare the value of hydro-MRI with follow-through examinations in Crohn 's disease . Methods and Materials: After an oral bowel opaeification using 1000 ml of a 2.5% mannitol solution, axial and coronal breathhold sequenees (T2W HASTE ± FS, contrast-enhaneed T1W FLASH FS) were acquired in 46 patients with Crohns 's disease at 1.0 T. The findi ngs of hydro-MRI were compared with follow-through examinations. Results: In comparison with hydro-MRI, the follow through examination showed advantages for the dep ietion of the upper gastrointestinal tract ; hydro-MRI was equivalent in the small bowel and superior in the colon . In the stomaeh and the small bowel, hydro-MRI and follow-through examination demonstrated similar numbers of Crohn's involvements (39 vs. 36); in the colon, hydro-MRI showed c1early more infestations (23 vs. 10). In the 46 patients, hydro-MRI showed 585 cm of inflamed bowel , altogether (follow-through examinations: 479 em, p =0.004). There was a good agreement of both methods regarding the assessment of the extent of Crohn's disease and the severity of bowel stenoses (r = 0.89and 0.88, respeetively). Altogether, hydro-MRI was assessed as the superior imaging modality in 31 patients , the follow-through exam ination was assumed to be superior in only one patient. In 14 patien ts. both methods were equivalent. Conclusion: For the assessment of Crohn 's disease, hydro-MRI is preferable to the follow-through exam ination because of super ior imaging quality and the lack of radiation exposure.593 The outer diameter of the appendix: lack of diagnostic specificity. The threshold value for aeute appendieitis mostly used is~6mm. Th is study compares diam eters of normal and aeute inflamed append ices prospeetively. Methods and Materials: Append ix diameters of symptomatie patients (240), of symptomatie patients without evidenee of aeute append ieitis (126 : either confirmed by histology (33) or by elinieal follow-up (93)) and of patients with aeute appendicitis (72 : all eonfirmed by histology) were prospeetively evaluated with ultrasound. Results: The mean diameter of the asymptomatie patients was 5.3mm and 29% (70) of them had diameters~6mm . The me an diameter of the symptomatie patients without evidenee of aeute appendieitis was 5.4 mm and 36% (45) of them had diameters~6 mm. The mean value of the aeute inflamed appendiees was 10 mm and 94%(68)of them The choice of the optimal ultrasonic frequency for vascular studies is determined by the required resolution and penetration. TABREF119.text: Purpose: To assess the diagnostic accuracy of thin collimated unenhanced versus contrast enhanced helical CT in patients with suspected acute appendicitis. Methods and Materials: a focussed appendiceal CT was performed in 50 patients, 28 males and 22 females, mean age 43.7 years (17-89) with clinically suspected acute appendicitis. Unenhanced and i.v contrast enhanced CT scans were obtained from the L4 level to the symphysis pubis by using 5 mm collimation, 7.5 mm table feed and 4 mm reconstruction algorhythm. Prospective diagnoses based on CT findings were compared with surgical results and c1incal follow-up. Results: Unenhanced helical CT was an accurate imaging technique for the initial examination of patients with suspected acute appendicitis with an accuracy of 98%. The sensitivity was 96%, the specifity was 100%. No difference was notable between unenhanced and enhanced scans (p < 0.01). Conclusion: Unenhanced helical CT provides accurate diagnosis of acute appendicits.594 Gas or absence of gas in the appendix: additional criteria torule out or to confirm acute appendicitis. Evaluation by sonography T. Rettenbacher, A. Hollerweger, P. Macheiner, B. Schneider, had diameters 2':6mm. Six percent (4) of the acute inflamed appendices had diameters <6mm. The outer diameter of 2':6mm confirms acute appendicitis with a sensitivity of 94%, a specificity of 64%, a positive and negative predictive value of 40% and 98% and an accuracy of 75%. Conclusion: The threshold value of 2':6mm for acute appendicitis is a very sensitive criterion (94%), but a Iimited specificity (64%) has to be taken into consideration. 595 Sonography of acute appendicitis: influence of visualisation and criteria Z. TABREF120.text: Mammography continues to be the most important breast imaging technique because of it's effectiveness for both screening and diagnostic Chairperson: P.R. ALGRA (Alkmaar/NL) 603 Degenerative disorders of the spine J.T. Wilmink; Maastricht/NL Modern imaging techniques have proved highly sensitive for detecting degenerative spinal conditions such as disk herniation and also arthro-sis associated with various types of spinal narrowing. An old problem is making itself more strongly fel!: degenerative spinal pathology can be seen in significant numbers of asymptomatic persons. In those referred for diagnostic imaging because of neck or arm pain, low back pain or sciatica, it is often difficult to distinguish which degenerative conditions seen on CT or MRI studies may be responsible for symptoms, and which may be irrelevant. This workshop sets out to clarify those anatomical features seen on imaging studies which are likely to be associated with radicular pain. In the cervical region for instance, root compression by herniated disk material is only likely when the entrance to the intervertebral foramen is completely occiuded. In the lumbar spine it is necessary to study the dimensions of the spinal canal, especially its lateral regions, as weil the contours of the dural sac, the root sleeve and the epidural fat. Relevant techniques are static and dynamic myelography and CT myelography as weil as MRI and MR myelography. Baleriaux, F. Rio, Ph. David, Th. Roger, J. Brotchi; BrusselslB This lecture will mainly deal with spinal cord tumors and their differential diagnosis. Clinical symptoms of cord tumors are often of insidious onse!: pain may be for long the only complain. Before the advent of MRI the diagnosis of cord tumor was often delayed. MRI nowadays studies not only the shape and external contour of the cord, but also the internal changes. Astrocytoma, ependymoma and hemangioblastoma are the most frequent tumors. It is important to try to provide apreoperative diagnosis to the surgeon. Careful analysis of the images will lead to describe important features such as solid nodule, cystic components, associated hydro-syringomyelia, ect. Signal behavior after contrast enhancement provides additional helpful information. Rare tumors are more difficult to diagnose and should essentially be differentiated from non neoplastic lesions such as granulomas, MS, vascular maIformations or inflammatory diseases. Important concepts have to be kept in mind: every tumor does not necessarily enhance and conversely every enhancing mass is not a tumor. Extensive mass lesions on the contrary are most likely to be neoplasms.Acute transverse myelopathy refers to any acute bilateral motor, sensory and autonomic dysfunction in the spinal cord. It can be caused by trauma, neoplasm, infarction, multiple sclerosis (MS), acute disseminating encephalomyelitis (ADEM), idiopathic acute transverse myelitis (IATM), systemic lupus erythematodes, HIV, Lyme disease or irradiation.

TABREF124.text: MR-Angiography has entered a new stage since the introduction of ultrafast, breath-hold scanning in combination with introvenously administered contrast media boli. The evaluation of the first pass of the contrast media through the area of investigation in 3-dimensional MRAtechniques offers new perspectives in vascular imaging, because the strong contrast ratio achievable by MR exceeds the contrast of x-raymodalities. The draw back of CE-MRA is limited spatial resolution, while native techniques für carotid MRA such as time of f1ight with ramped RF-pulses or MOTSA-technique enable excellent resolution. To beat native MRA, parameter settings and contrast media application have to be optimised for CE-MRA In a direct comparison, the patients tolerance of the fast contrast enhanced MRA-technique is by far superior to the much longer native techniques. The clinical results, however, do not show such a tremendeous progress today. Only at perfect timing and parameter constellation, contrast enhanced MRA can substantially replace native techniques.

TABREF126.text: 629 Accuracy of magnetic resonance pancreatography after secretin stimulation in chronic pacreatitis compared to enoscopic retrograde pancreatography R Manfredi, M.G. Brizi, M. Mutignani, G. Costamagna, A. Vecchioli, G. Maresca, P. Marano; RomelJAim of the 5tudy: To determine the sensitivity of Magnetic Resonance pancreatography, after secretin stimulation, in detecting ductal anornalies due to chronic pancreatitis, compared to endoscopic retrograde pancreatography. Methods and Materials: 19 patients with chronic pancreatitis underwent MRCP before and up to 10 minutes after secretin stimulation. Clinically 11 patients had no or mild chronic pancreatitis, 8 patients had severe chronic pancreatitis. MRCP images were blindly analyzed by two radiologist. Image analysis included: sharpness of ductal rnargins, presence of ductal narrowing, endoluminal filling defects, side branches dilatation, presence of cysts, presence of pancreas divisum, chronic pancreatitis classification. All patients underwent ERCP that represented the gold standard of diagnosis. Results: There was an MRCP/ERCP agreement on the sharpness of the ductal margins in 18/19 patients. 15/17 ductal narrowings were correctly detected by MRCP; and 2 were missed. 7/7 filling defects were correctly detected by MRCP; there were however 3 false positives. 12/12 dilated side branches were correctly detec!ed by MRCP, there were however 2 false positives and 2 dilated side branches were detected only at MRCP because of incomplete opacification of the duct at ERCP.

TABREF127.text: The imaging results were correlated with surgery, laparoscopy, biopsy, and/or followup. Results: 8 pancreatic adenocarcinomas were present. 10 patients suffered from chronic pancreatitis, and 2 showed a papillitis stenosans. CT and ERCP detected 8 malignant lesions, MRI 7. In 9 patients, ERCP, CT, and MRI excluded malignancy. MRI, CT, and ERCP showed 3 false positive results. Additionally, one pancreatic cancer could not be detected with MRI. Thus, the accuracy of detecting lesions was nearly similar with all 3 methods. Delineation of pancreas and pancreatic tumors on MRI was best on postcontrast fat-suppressed T1w GRE images in correlation with T2w images. Conclusion: This study indicates that mangafodipir trisodium MRI could improve the detection rate and staging accuracy of focal pancreatic lesions. These results need to be confirmed in a larger patient trial. Chronic pancreatitis with enlargement of the pancreatic head: new specific signs on cross-sectional and projective magnetic resonance cholangio-pancreatography F. Haven, H. Bloemen, L. Van Hoe; LeuvenlBResults: Edematous form of pancreatitis was observed in 39% cases, exudative -38%, necrotic -23%. Local complications detectable by CT were caused by various reasons. Fluid extravasation and inflammatory debris in peripancreatic spaces leaded to pseudocyst formation in 22 cases. Superimposition of bacterial infection resulted in abscess or diffuse phlegmonous pancreas inflammation (15 patients). Extension of pancreatic necrosis into adjacent organs caused inflammatory infiltration and ulceration of gastric wall (8 patients), colon fistulization and necrotizing obstruction (3 patients), splenic rupture or hematoma (2 patients). Pancreas hematoma due to arrosion of blood vessels was revealed in 2 cases, secondary compression of biliary tract by enlarged pancreatic head -6 cases. Positive predictive value of CT in diagnosis of infected pancreatic complications was 92.2%, others extrapancreatic complications -98.2%. Depending on clinical and CT manifestations patients underwent therapeutic treatment, surgery or drainage under CT guidance. Conclusion: CT is a valuable method in diagnosis of severity and complications of acute pancreatitis, prognozing the development of pathologic process and determining timely adequate curative measures.Purpose: To describe how chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic carcinoma can be differentiated by using cross-sectional and projective magnetic resonance cholangio-pancreatography (MRCP) in patients with enlargement of the pancreatic head. Methods and Materials: MR imaging (including MRCP) was performed in 44 patients with pancreatic head enlargement. Final diagnosis was pancreatic carcinoma in 29 and chronic pancreatitis with inflammatory enlargement of the pancreatic head in 15. The MRCP features of both entities were compared. Results: The following features were commonly found in pancreatic carcinoma: low signal intensity on 'turbo-FLASH' T1-weighted images; focal narrowing of pancreatic duct; signs of vascular invasion or metastases. In chronic pancreatitis, the following features were typical: signs of attraction or displacement of the common bile duct; intermediate signal intensity of the pancreatic head; presence of dilated side branches within the 'rnass'. The 'double duct sign' was commonly observed in both groups. Conclusion: Presence or absence of the double duct sign is not a reliable criterium to differentiate chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic carcinoma. Reliable criteria are:(1)signal intensity on T1-weighted images; (2) presence of dilated side branches traversing the mass; (3) the 'attraction sign'. TABREF128.text: Ultrafast high resolution, 3D contrast-enhanced MR angiography of the aorta In patlents with endovascular grafts A. Laghi, G. Passalaqua, P. Pavone , C. Catalano, P. Filauri , A. Venditti,R. Passariello ; RomeIlPurpose: To evaluate the diagnostic utility of ultrafast , high resolu tion , 3D contrast-enhanced MR ang iography of the aorta in patients with endovascular grafts . Methods and Materials: Seven patients with abdominal aort ic aneurysms underwent MR imaging examination using a 1.5 T magnet (Magnetom Vision Plus, Siemens, Erlangen), within 1 month of receiving transfemorally placed endovascular graft. Contrast-enhanced MRA was performed acqu iring 3D FISP sequence(TRITE/matrixlacq.t. :   4.6/1 .8/195  x 512/23 ) during dynamic injection of 40 ml. of gado linium at 3 ml/s using apower injector. MRA images were reconstructed using MIP algorithm. Conventional MR imaging study included: high resolution T1w FLASH (TRlTElFNmatrix: 127.7/4 .2/60/160 x 512) and T2w HASTE (TRlTE/FNmatrix: 4.4/90/150/160 x 256) . The shape and patency of the graft, perigraft thrombosis and the size of the aneurysm were assessed. Results: All grafts remained patent and no deformation was observed. In all the cases complete thrombosis of the aneurysm was present. In one case partial patency of an embolyzed internal iliac artery was assessed. Conclusion: Ultrafast, high resolution, 3D contrast-enhanced MR angiography is an accurate method for the evaluation of endovascular grafts. MRA can be used as a primary technique for follow-up of patients with endovascular grafts.E. Di Cesare, A. Costanzi, A. Catalu cci, J. Ferraluolo , O. Michel ini, C. Masciocchi; L:Aquilall Purpose: To verify the diagnostic potent ialities of conventional MRI , 3D bolus enhanced MR Angiography (MRA) and transesophageal ecocardiography (TEE). Methods and Materials: 26 patients surgically treated for type A aortic cissecnon underwent MR examinations: it was performed emloying a 1.5 T GE System using standard axial SE T1-w sequences and breath hold 3D FGRE after intravenous Gd injection (0 .2 mmoIlKg). Previous 20 bolus test was performed to optimize the bolus delay; 3D MIP reconstruction was obtained. TEE analys is was obteined using a HP 2000 system and multiplanar 5 MHz probe. 5146 649 High resolution contrast-enhanced turbo-MRA in the evaluation of abdominal aortic aneurysms C. Catalano, P. Pavone, A. Laghi, V. Panebianco, G. Luccichenti, R. Passariello; RomeIl Purpose: To determine the feasib ility and accuracy of high resolution contrast enhanced MRA (CE-MRA) in the presu rgical evaluation of abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) . Methods and Materials: 42 patients with AAA were examined with a 1.5 T magnet (Siemens Vision Plus) using a 3D T1 w. FISP sequence (TRlTElNEX: 4.6/1 .8/1; TA = 23 seconds; Matr ix = 195 x 512) after i.v, bolus injection with apower inj ector of a dose of 20 ml of Gd-DTPA. A 3 ml bolus test of Gd-DTPA was performed in all patients. MIP reconstructions were performed in all cases. In all patients DSA and CT (spiral CT in 27 patients) were performed within 7 days from the CE-MRA. Extension of the AAA (suprarenal, iuxtarenal and infrarenal) , presence of thrombus and renal polar arteries and involvement of iliac arteries were evaluated. Results: In all cases CE-MRA provided exams considered equal (in 29) or superior (in 13) to DSA. All MRAs were considered superior for all information to C'T, 24 AAA were infrarenal, 11 iuxtarenal and 7 suprarenal. In 14 cases involvement of the iliac arteries was correclly depicted . 16/18 renal polar arteries were correctly detected . Conclusion: High resolution CE-MRA provides all the information necessary for the preoperative evaluation of patients with AAA, without need of other diagnostic exams. 650 The value of eontrast-enhanced 3D MRA in the pre-operative evaluation of patients with aorto-iliac disease W. TABREF129.text: 653 Automatie bolus timing with gadolinium-enhaneed MR angiography of thoracie aorta S. Baus, A. Leppert, J. Lotz, H. Köstler, H. Rosenthai, M. Galanski; HannoverlDPurpose: Prospective comparison of automatic bolus tracking versus test bolus and simultaneous Gd-application for MR-angiography. Methods and Materials: Randomized prospective study with 30 patients after ISTA correction using three different protocols: 1. Simultaneous application of 30 ml Gd-DTPA (f1ow 2 ml/s) and 3 DGE (TR 8.7 ms; TE 1.8 ms; ThklSp 1.8/-0.9 mm; FOV 40130 cm; Mal. 512 x 192) without k-space transformation, 2. 2 ml test bolus and k-space transformation, 3. Automatic bolus detection and k-space transformation (smart prep). Evaluation by three radiologists in regard to preparational demands and post processing feasibility. Results: Test bolus and smart prep proved superior to simultaneous Gd-application in regard to post processing time and vessel rendering. Smart prep required less preparational time before data acquisition in comparison to test bolus technique. Conelusion: Automatic bolus tracking is superior to test bolus technique and simultaneous Gd-application in MR-angiography in patients after correction for ISTA. Ferrajuolo, I. Morricone, G. Cerone, R. Vestuto, E. Di Cesare, C. Masciocchi; L:Aquilall Purpose: To compare the potentialities of Gd-enhanced 3D Magnetic Resonance Angiography (MRA) and conventional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) in the evaluation of patients treated with abdominal aortic graft interposition. Methods and Materials: We studied 15 patients (3 female and 12 male, mean age 54y) surgically treated with abdominal aortic graft interposition. The evaluation was made by a 1.5 T GE-Unit 8.2, employing conventional FSE T2-weighted sequences and FGRE breathhold T1-weighted sequences. MRA was performed using 3D GRE sequences breath-holding after intravenous bolus injection of contrast medium (0.2 mmoI/Kg). We analyzed the status of the proximal and distal anastomosis, the graft size and patency and the presence of periprosthetic fluid collection. Results: MRA and conventional MRI were both able to define the status of proximal and distal anastomosis, the size and patency of the graft.MRA better defined the status of the renal arteries, proximal and distal native aorta with good evidence of atherosclerotic lesions in all 15 patients.The presence of periprosthetic material was also evident in 10/15 patients by the analysis of MRA single partitions, ranging between 5 mm to 25 mm, but was inadequate to define the presence of fluid and edema, that were evident in 6/10 cases by conventional MRI T2weighted sequences.Conclusion: Gd-enhanced 3D MRA is adequate in the evaluation of intraluminal alterations in patients surgically treated with graft. Moreover the evaluation of periprosthetic fluid collection needs the employment of conventional MRI acquisitions. Merlino, R Fossaceca, F. Vizzani, M. Salcuni, A. Carriero, L. Bonomo; Chietill Purpose: To assess the potential value of ultrafast spoiled gradient echo (GRE) contrast (CM) enhanced MRA (CE-MRA) in comparison to unenhanced conventional MRA (C-MRA) in the evaluation of the vertebral arteries (VERT). Methods and Materials: Fifteen patients (age 57-68 yrs.) were consecutively enrolled and underwent C-MRA and CE-MRA (neck array coil, Siemens Vision). Conventional MRA was performed by using a 3D axial TOF multislab (MOTSA) technique. CE-MRA was performed with a 3D-FLASH spoiled GRE sequence on the coronal plane, during administration of a bolus of CM (0.1 mmol/kg, 2 ml/s, TA 15-20 s). The vertebral arteries were divided in four segments: a visualization index (from 0 -no visualization -to 3 -very good visualization) for each segment was attributed. Results: In 14 patients (93%) CE-MRA allowed full visualization of VERT (99% of all segments). CE-MRA visualization index was better than for C-MRA (2.1 +1-0.7 vs 1.3 +1-0.6, p < .01), even for the origin and the proximal portion of VERT. Conclusion: Ultrafast CE-MRA improves the visualization of VERT. Due to the acquisition on the coronal plane and the high S/N, it represents the best MRA technique for a complete assessment of VERT. and corrected by repeat VB. All malignantlborderline diagnoses were confirmed by definitive surgery. No underestimation of tumor type and only two side-effects occurred with VCB (1 seizure, 1 large hematoma). Conclusion: Aggressive removal (over 16 cores 11g) may increase accuracy without increasing side-effects. Comparison of vacuum-assisted versus automated large-core breast biopsy in atypical ductal hyperplasia and ductal carcinoma in situ Th. Helbich, RJ. Jackman, S.H. Parker, F.H. Burbank, C.H. Lee, S.J. Adler, M.C. Lechner, R.F. Brem, D.E. Lehrer; ViennalA Purpose: To compare the accuracy of directional, vacuum-assisted breast biopsy (DVABB) vs. automated large core biopsy (ALCBB) in the assessment of atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH) and ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). Methods and Materials: In this multi-center trial (16 centers) percutaneous, prone, stereotactic breast biopsy was performed in 13163 lesions. ADH was diagnosed in 524 and DCIS in 1278 lesions. Of the 524 lesions diagnosed as ADH 194 were biopsied with 14-G ALCBB, 129 with 14-G DVABB,and 201 with 11-G DVABB. Of all 1278 DCIS 373 were biopsied with 14-G ALCBB, 348 with 14-G DVABB, and 557 with 11-G DVABB. The number of ADH lesions upgraded to breast cancer and the number of DCIS upgraded to infiltrating breast carcinoma (IBC) at time of subsequent surgery were evaluated for each biopsy technique.Results: The percentage of ADH lesions diagnosed with ALCBB and upgraded to breast cancer was 38.1%. For the ADH lesions diagnosed with 14-G and 11-G DVABB, the percentage of the upgrading to breast cancer was 21% and 20%, respectively. Thus, with both DVABB techniques the underestimation rate of ADH decreased significantly (p = 0.0001). The percentage of DCIS lesions diagnosed with ALCBB and upgraded to IBC was 20.1%. For the DCIS lesions diagnosed with 14-G and 11-G DVABB, the percentage of the upgrading to IBC was 11% and 11.5%, respectively. Thus, with both DVABB techniques the underestimation rate of DCIS decreased significantly (p =0 0001).Conclusion: With both DVABBtechniques underestimation rate of ADH and DCIS decreased significantly in comparison with ALCBB. Suh ; SuwonlROKPurpose: To determine enhancement pattern of pulmonary nodules using !wo-phase enhan ced spiral CT for differentiating noncalcified tuberculomas from malignant nodu les. Methods and Materials: Patients with solitary pulmonary nodule were examined with two-phase enhanced spiral CT. Noncalcified nodules in 29 patients (M: F =21:8, mean age =45.9) were subsequently diagnosed as tuberculomas (size range : 1.3 to 3.8 cm , mean : 2.6 cm) . Another group of 26 patients with nodules was proven patholog ically to have malignant nodules (size range : 1.1 to 4.5 cm , mean : 3.1 cm) . Enhanced scans were performed 30 (early phase) and 70-180 sec (Iate phase) after intravenous injection of 100 mL of iodinated contrast med ia in a rate of 2.5 mUsec. Enhancement patterns of tubercu lomas were compared with malignan t nodules. Results: The enhancing pattern was more effic iently evaluated with the late enhanced images and was significanlly different between tuberculomas and malignant nodules (p < 0.001). Thirteen (45%) tuberculomas showed peripheral thin rim enhancement and 11 (38%) showed nonenhancement. Twelve (46%) malignant nodules were enhan ced homogeneously and another 12 (46%) with mosaic pattern. Conclusion: Two-phase enhanced spiral CT ls efficient for evaluating enhancement pattern of pulmonary nodules and is useful for non invasive differential diagnosis between tuberculoma and malignant nodules.691 Model-and knowledgebased segmentation of hand radiographs for maturity determination E Vogelsang, M. Pandolfo; Messinall 688 Evaluation of CT air bronchogram sign in malignant solitary pulmonary lesions J.-Ä. Choi, H.-S. Kim, Y.-w. Oh, E.-Y. Kang; SeoullROKPurpose: To evaluate prevalence and pattern of air bronchogram sign in malignant solitary pulmonary lesions (SPLs). Methods and Materials: CT scans of 78 patients with malignant SPLs including air bronchogram were reviewed. Lesions were c1assified into 4 cell types as squamous cell, small cell, adenocarcinoma, bronchioloalveolar carcinoma (BAC), according to degree of differentiation, size, and location. Air bronchogram patterns were c1assified into obstructing (I), patent (11), displacing (111), or tapered narrowing (IV) types. Results: Eighty patterns were analyzed. According to cell types, squamous cell carcinoma showed most often type I (45.8%) but no type 11 pattern, most common in BAC (77.8%) and adenocarcinoma (34.8%). Small cell carcinoma showed most often type IV pattern (41.7%). In all 3 degrees of differentiation, type 111 was most common. No significant differences existed according to size. According to location, central types were seen more often (63.75%) with more commonly type land IV patterns, whereas peripheral ones had more often type 111 and 11 patterns. Conclusion: We conclude that in SPLs with air bronchogram sign of either obstructing or displacing pattern, squamous cell carcinoma should be suspected. In SPLs with patent air bronchogram, either BAC or adenocarcinoma should be considered.

For staging of Iymph node metastases both MRI and FOG-PET yielded a high sensit ivity compared to CT. However, specificity of CT and MRI was superior to that of FOG-PET. Conclusion: In primary diagnosis FOG-PET may be useful in patients where CT and MRI fail to depict the leslon, and to detect additional tumor manifestations. TABREF200.text: The MR measurements were performed on a Siemens MAGNETOM Vision scanner. A spatial resolution of up to 0.16 mm x 0.16 mm x 1 mm was achieved. For the determination of T2 we varied the echo time between 14 and 200 ms. Results: The measured T2 values in articular cartilage rise with increasing distance from the bone due to the changing orientation of the collagen fibrils. T2 has values between 20 ms near the subchondral bone and 60 ms at the articular surface supporting the data observed by other investigators at higher field strengths. Conclusion: Our results show that T2 maps of human articular cartilage can be determined in clinical MR scanners. A study on the relationship between water content and T2 is in progress.

TABREF249.text: 1315 Virtual traeheobronehoscopy in Pediatrics -technique and first cllnical experience E. sorantm , B. Geiger, R. Fetter, H. Mayer. E. Eber; GrazlA ;Purpose: Presentation of 2 different techniques (surface rendering vs volume rendering) for computation virtual tracheobronchoscopy (VTB) in comparision to fiberoptic bronchoscopy (FTB) in pediatric patients. Methods and Materials: VTB based on Spiral-CT of the ehest was computed in 11 patients (0.5--16.7a) with tracheobronchial palhology. For surface rendering (SR) the tracheobronchial tree was detected semiautomated. On a workstation screen the virtual endoscopic view together with the CT slice, a 3D anatomie model and a MPR orthogonal to the virtual camera view were displayed. Volume Rendering was performed with a commercial software package (VoxelView 2.5. Vital Images). Study protocol of spiral CT was adjusted to the clinical question. All reports and videotapes of FTB were available for comparison. Results: VTB could be computed in all patients. There was total agreement between VTB and FTB. Volume rendering showed more realistic virtual endoscopic views but surface rendering provided more simultaneous information of extraluminal anatomy and was less cornputer intensive and time consuming . Conclusion: There is no age limit for computation of VTB from S-CT data and tracheobronchial pathology can be imaged. VTB using surface detection allows matching of extra and intraluminal anatomy which is far beyond of FTB alone. Therefore VTB can be used for training and simulation purposes .15:25 1316 Determination of pulmonary time constants in aporeine ARDS model using dynamie CT H.-U. Kauezer. K. Markstaller. N. Weiler. B. Eberle, M. Thelen; MainzlDPurpose: To determine inspiratory and expiratory time constants in healthy and diseased lungs using aporeine ARDS model and dynamic multiscan CT. Methods and Materials: Surfactant depletion ARDS was induced in five anesthetized pigs by saline lavage. Transaxial dynamic multiscan HRCT scans (slice thickness =1 mrn, temporal resolution =250 rns, acquisition 49 s) were obtained before and after induction of ARDS. During dynamic CT acquisition airway pressure was suddenly increased (0-50 cm H20) or decreased (50-0 cm H 20) . Absolute and relative ventilated lung areas were measured planimetrically using a double threshold (-910 to -300 HU). Results were plotted against time and fitted to calculate different time constants. Results: In healthy lungs a single inspiratory time constant (0.3-0.4 s) was found, whereas in AROS two different inspiratory time constants (0.6-0.8 sand 5.5--10 s) were observed. The slower one recruited about 15% of the total ventilated area. During explration, healthy lungs exhibited two different time constants (1.1 and 5 s), whereas AROS lungs had only one time conslant of 0.4 s. Conclusion: Different pulmonary time constants were measured using dynamic multiscan CT in healthy and diseased lungs. Their knowledge could allow for individual modification of ventilation techniques.RoomGConclusion: In conclusion the correct local staging of the uterocervical neoplasia needs the use of a methodological approach by images capable to complete the clinical examination on narcosis.
