Brambs; U1mlD 1317 Uterine cervical carcinoma: comparison of standard and pharmacokinetic analysis of time-intensity curves for assessment of tumor angiogenesis and patient survival H. Hawighorst, P.G. Knapstein, MV Knopp, G. van Kaick; HeidelberglD Purpose: To examine the association of standard and pharmacokinetic analysis of time-intensity curves in dynamic MRI with histomorphological markers of tumor angiogenesis (microvessel density [MVD]; Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor [VEGF]), and (ii) to determine the ultimate value of those data with disease outcome in patients with cancer of the uterine cervix.Methods and Materials: Pharmacokinetic parameters (amplitude A, exchange rate constant k21) and standard parameters (maximum signal intensity (SI)-increase [SI-I] over baseline and steepest SI-upslope per second [SI-Uls]) were calculated from dynamic MRI series in 37 patients with biopsy-proven primary cervical cancer. Histomorphological data, Kaplan-Meier survival curves were calculated and compared using logrank statistics. Results: A significant association was found between MVD and amplitude A (P < .01) and SI-I (P < .05). No significant relationships were observed between VEGF expression and dynamic MRI parameters. Kaplan-Meier curves based on k21 and SI-Uls showed that tumors with high k21 and SI-Uls values had a significantly (P < .05, .001, respectively) worse disease outcome than tumors with low k21 and SI-Uls values. Conclusion: The pathophysiological basis for differences in dynamic MRI is MVD but not VEGF-expression; a functional, dynamic MRI approach may be better suited to assess tumor microcirculation than current histomorphological-based markers of tumor angiogenesis. 14:10 1318 Transrectal ultrasonography (TRU5) in the cervical carcinoma local staging V. Summaria, P. Mirk, G. Maresca, AM. Costantini, S. Speca, AL. Valentini; RomeIl Purpose: To assess the role of TR-US in the local staging (T) of the cervical carcinoma (FIGO stage IB, 11, 111), in patients candidate to surgical treatment after chemiotherapy. Methods and Materials: Twenty three patients with cervical epidermoid carcinoma (clinical staging: 2 IB, 5 IIA, 9 IIB, 7 IIIB), before and after systemic neoadjuvant chemiotherapy (2 cycles), were examined with TR-US. The images were evaluated for the following parameters: size of cervix, tumor size, vaginal and parametrial involvement, bladder and rectal wall invasion. Imaging data were collected on performed sheets and compared to findings of clinical examination under anaesthesia and MRI. All data were finally compared to results of resected hysterectomy specimen, considered as the gold standard. Results: All patients underwent surgical therapy. The analysis points out that the diagnostic accuracy of TR-US in evaluating the cervix volume was equal to that of MRI (73%), superior to that of the clinical examination on narcosis (52%), although tumor size was exactly detected only in 10/23 pts. Also in estimating vaginal and parametrial involvement (78% and 74%), TR-US is superior to clinical examination on narcosis (75% and 65%) and inferior to MRI (83% and 82%). On the other hand TR-US and MRI have shown a diagnostic accuracy close to 100% in estimating bladder and rectal involvement.Purpose: Retrospective evaluation of interventional, percutaneous therapy in the final treatment of recurrent locally advanced cervical carcinoma. Methods and Materials: Between 1990 and 1998 15 patients with advanced tumor disease were referred to our department for diagnosis and therapy of an acute blood loss. In all patients aged from 40 to 89 years hemorrhage was detected by the loss in red blood count, partly Iife-threatening. In all cases patients suffered recurrent disease after surgery and additional radiation or chemotherapy. Embolization was performed by transfemoral acces using minicoils in most cases, liquid agents rarely and a covered vascular stent in one patient. Results: The site of the hemorrhage or the blood pooling of the tumor could be ssen in all cases angiographically. 27 therapie cycles (1.8 per patient) were performed in time intervals from 3 days to 6 months. The maximum time of treatment was one year. In 8/15 patients with single therapy the bleeding could be stopped immediately in 7 (46.5%). One patient died during therapy because of the not controllable bleeding and the consecuive enormous blood loss (7%). The remaining patients showed shightly persistent or recurrent bleeding, which could be managed interventionally until the following episode (46.5%). There were two complications during therapy representing a coil misplacement and a coil wash out which could be managed interventionally. Conclusion: Hemorrhage following recurrent cervical carcinoma can be stopped interventionally in over 90% of cases. Even in patial success it is possible to manage the acute life-threatening situation. Follow-up's of up to 1 year rectifie this therapeutic concept.1320 Magnetic resonance imaging of sarcomas of the female pelvis I. Biltjes, Ö. Özsarlak, AMA De Schepper; AntwerplBPurpose: To describe MRI-findings in sarcomas of the female pelvis. Methods and Materials: 18 patients with histologically proven sarcomas of the female pelvis were examined with MRI. Examinations were performed on either a 0.2, 1.0 or 1.5T whole body imager. At least sagittal T2-weighted and sagittal T1-weighted images before and after IV gadolinium were performed. Results: Uterine leiomyosarcoma was the most frequently encountered tumor (56%). It is difficult to differentiate from other uterine masses especially leiomyoma, but some findings are helpful in the diagnosis. In decreasing order mesodermal sarcoma (malignant mixed müllerian tumors), stromal sarcomas, and rhabdomyosarcomas were also seen. In these cases some MR-characteristics are suggestive for the histologie tumor type, but patients age and other parameters are also useful in making the correct diagnosis. Conclusion: Sarcomas of the female pelvis are rare tumors. Nevertheless it is important to be aware of their presentation, especially on MRI, in order to make a prompt and correct diagnosis. MRI is the preferred imaging modality in evaluating invasion into the myometrium, extension to surrounding structures and follow-up.1321 Phased-array body coil MR imaging in ovarian tumors and the impact of intestinal and intravenous contrast enhancementA Heuck, S. Uns, J. Scheidier, M. Steinborn, I. Bauernfeind, Th. Helmberger, M.F. Reiser; MunichlDPurpose: To evaluate the diagnostic potential of high field, phasedarray body coil MR imaging in the diagnostic work-up of ovarian tumors, and to assess the impact of a negative intestinal contrast agent and intravenous Gd-OTPA on diagnostic accuracy. Methods and Materials: 44 patients with sonographically suspected ovarian tumors were included in the study. MR imaging was preoperatively performed on a 1.5 T System (Magnetom Vision, Siemens, Germany) using a phased-array body coil. Non-enhanced imaging included T1-and T2-weighted turbo-spin-echo (TSE) sequences. After oral (400 to 600 ml) and rectal (200 to 300 ml) administration of a superparamagnetic contrast agent (Ferumoxsil, Guerbet, France) the same sequences were applied. After additional IV-application of 0.1 mmol/kg, Gd-OTPA (Schering, Germany) T1-weighted sequences with and without fat suppression were performed. Three radiologists, blinded to all clinical and other imaging data, independentiy reviewed the 3 imaging sets. MR imaging findings were compared to surgical and pathohistological findings. Results: The mean diagnostic accuracy in differentiating benign and malignant ovarian tumors was 88.6% for non-enhanced, 90.9% for bowel-enhanced, and 93.0% for bowel and IV enhanced imaging. Accuracy values for the detection of bowel infiltration were 79.7% (non-enhanced). 86.2% (bowel-enhanced). and 87.9% (bowel and IV enhanced); for peritoneal spread the respective accuracy values were 69%, 72% and 94%. The mean subjective certalnty of the radiologists in establishing a complete staging diagnosis increased from 77% with nonenhanced imaging to 82% with bowel-enhanced, and 92% with both bowel and IV enhanced imaging. Conclusion: Phased-array body coil MR imaging holds a high potential in the diagnostic work up of ovarian tumors. Negative intestinal contrast agent may improve the detection of bowel infiltration. IV contrast enhancerment is an important aid for the diagnosis of peritoneal spread.14:50 1322 Value of routine imaging in the follow-up of gynecologic malignancies R. Forstner, A. Graf, A. Stempfl, H. Nemec, A. Staudach; Sa/zburg/A Purpose: Routine staging in gynecologic malignancies is under debate. This study was performed to assess the value of routine imaging in the follow-up of gynecologic cancers. Methods and Materials: 115 patients underwent routine staging in-c1uding clinical examinations, endosonography (ES) and CA-125 every 3 months, and spiral CT after 12 and 24 months. Tumor recurrence was evaluated according to tumor type and stages, detection by modality, by site, size and architecture. Results: Tumor recurrence was detected in 31/115 (27%) of clinically unremarkable patients (cervical cancer: 14/58, endometrial cancer: 6/28, ovarian cancer: 11/29). Local recurrence was found in 15/31 patients. Recurrent tumor was detected in 45.2% by routine ES, in 35.4% by routine CT after one and 16.1% after 2 years. In 2 patients CA-125 elevation preceeded detection by imaging. In ovarian cancer recurrence was detected either by ES, or CT after 12 months. Conclusion: Routine postoperative imaging allows detection of tumor recurrence in 27% of clinically unremarkable patients and thus aids in improved treatment planning. Oue to its site 50% of recurrence will only be detected by CT.1323 Reduction of microvascular permeability and ascites fluid in ovarian cancer after treatment with vascular endothelial growth factor antibody: monitoring therapeutic effects with macromolecular contrast-enhanced MR imaging A. Gossmann, Th. Helbich, S. Mesiano, O.M. Shames, M.F. Wendland, T.P.L. Roberts, N. Ferrara, R. Jaffe, R.C. Brasch; Cologne/D, Vienna/A, San Francisco,CA/USAPurpose: The accumulation of peritoneal ascites fluid in ovarian cancer results from increased permeability of peritoneal Iining vessels to macromolecules, mediated, in part, by vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). Macromolecular contrast medium (MMCM)-enhanced MR imaging was used to monitor the effects of anti-VEGF antibody on tumor microvascular permeability and the volume of ascites in an ovarian cancer model. Methods and Materials: The human ovarian cancer cell line SKOV-3 was inoculated intraperitoneally into athymic rats. Six were treated with 8296 monoclonal antibody to VEGF (anti-VEGF), and six with phosphatebuffered saline (PBS) over a 14-day course. Oynamic MR imaging was performed with MMCM enhancement (albumin-(Gd-OTPAh o, 0.03 mmol/kg). Vascular permeability was assayed using dynamic enhancement data and a kinetic model. Results: Saline treated animals developed large volumes ascites fluid during the treatment period and showed a significantiy (p < 0.01) increased MRI-assayed tumor microvascular permeability. By contrast, anti-VEGF antibody treated animals developed significantiy (p < 0.01) smaller volumes of ascites associated with a significant (p < 0.03) reduction in tumor microvascular permeability to MMCM. Conclusion: Anti-VEGF antibody treatment reduces macromolecular permeability and the accumulation of ascites fluid in a human ovarian cancer model. These effects can be measured with MMCM-enhanced MR imaging. The hypothesized link between microvascular permeability and the production of ascites is supported.15:10 1324 The prognostic value of FOG-PET for the evaluation of high-dose (HO) chemotherapy (Ctx) treatment in metastatic germ-cell tumors (GCT): correlation with CT and MRI A.-Ch. Pfannenberg; Tübingen/D Purpose: This analysis investigates the prognostic value of PET for the outcome of HO-Ctx and for the classification of residual tumors after HO-Ctx in patients with relapsed GCT in comparison to radiological (CT/MRI) methods. Methods and Materials: FOG-PET with visual and quantitative (SUV) analysis and CT and MRI scans were performed in 27 GCT patients (pts) undergoing HO-Ctx. In CT and MRI tumor localization, changes in size (PD/SO = vital, PR/CR = avital), density and signal intensity were assessed. PET and CT/MRI results were correlated to histological results at resection or the clinical course of the pts. Results: Residual masses (28 pts, 56 residual tumors): In 37/56 (66%) the prediction by PET was correcl. The comparative results in CT/MRI were 28 true positive (6PO/22S0) and 10 true negative (10PR). Fals·e predietions occured in 18/56 (32%) with both methods. Prediction of response (17 pts): 5/5 negative and 10/12 positive PETs correctly predicted the clinical outcome (90%) (in comparison CT/MRI 72%).Conclusion: PET appears to possess a high predictive value to detect chemotherapy resistance and may improve patient selection for HO-Ctx. In the evaluation of residual tumors after HO-Ctx false results will be gained in 1/3 of the pts and PET does not help in the decision process about secondary tumor surgery. CT and MRI imaging cannot predict correctly therapy effects or vitality of residual masses after HO-Ctx.1325 Magnetic resonance (MR) of pelvis with fat-saturation sequences in pelvic endometriosls: comparison between MR and laparoscopy C. Zuiani, C. Dei Frate, P. Piani, G. Dei Frate, M. Fiorenza, M. Bazzocchi; Udine/l Purpose: To assess MR diagnostic chances, with fat-saturation se· quences, in specifie arrangement of patients affected by pelvic endometriosis, in comparison with laparoscopic results. Methods and Materials: 30 patients underwent to MR of pelvis with following sequences: TSE, T1 and T2 W, SE T1 FAT-SAT on transverse and sagittal planes with slice thickness of 6 mm. 27 palients underwent to laparoscopy within 15 days after MR. Others 3 patients after MR results, didn't undergo to laparoscopy, but had been subjected to clinical and sonographie follow-up of 6-12 months. Results: MR imaging left out the presence of endometriosis in 3 patients who had functional serous ovarian cysts. Among the others 27 patients, in 3 patients 5 dermoid cysts were identified, in 3 patients 3 cystic adenomas were seen, all confirmed at laparoscopy, and 21 cases of pelvic endometriosis with these MR reports: 25 endometriosic cysts and 44 implants. Moreover in 3 patients MR showed 5 nodular endometriosic lesions located between posterior vaginal fornix and rectum wall (rectumvaginal nodules).

TABREF250.text: Conclusion: As a result the standartized complex diagnostic scheme of upper respiratory tract tumours has been worked out. 14:30 1328 Dynamic spiral CT versus laryngoscopy: evaluation of T parameter in larynx carcinoma S. Budassi, A. Tartaro, M. Maiorano, L. Bonomo; ChietillPurpose: To compare diagnostic accuracy of dynamic Spiral CT (SCT) vs laryngoscopy in defining loco-regional extension of larynx carcinoma. Methods and Materials: 20 patients, affected by larynx carcinoma, were prospectively studied. SCT examination was performed by using the following parameters: 3 mm slice thickness; 5 mm/sec table feed; 140 kV, 205 mAs; 2 mm image reconstructions. Intra-venous injectlon of 100 ce of non-ionic contrast medium (300 mgl/ml) by means of power injector (2 mI/sec flow, 45 sec start delay) was used in all cases.Dynamic spiral scan of the larynx (2 mm slice thickness, pitch = 1) was performed during Valsalva's maneuver. Multiplanar reconstructions of the neck and larynx were available in all cases. Two blinded radiologists analysed SCT images, in joint session. Data analysis was carried out by means of the test of McNemar (p < 0.05). Results: Overall SCT was more accurate than laryngoscopy in defining loco-regional extension of larynx carcinoma (p =0.024). Nevertheless, no significant differences were found between the two methods at glottic and sovraglottic level. Conclusion: SCT represents the elective technique in evaluating locoregional extension of larynx carcinoma. The availability of coronal and sagittal images of larynx during dynamic scans improves the accuracy of this technique.1330 Staging of laryngeal carcinoma: role of contrast enhanced and non-centrast enhanced MRI A. Vallone, T. Scarabino, B. Merlino, A. Carriero, L. Bonomo; Chietill 14:50 1329 Spiral CT with multiplanar and 3D imaging after reconstructive supracricoid laryngectomy R. Dore, G. Di Giulio, L. Preda, C. Villa, G. Di Maggio, A. La Fianza, M. Benazzo; PaviallPurpose: Surgery for treating even advanced laryngeal cancer are aimed at removing the disease, reconstructing a neolarynx, mantaining physiological functions. Aim of this study is to define normal axial, MPR and 3D CT features after reconstructive laryngectomies. Methods and Materials: 24 supracricoid laryngectomies (SL) were carried out, 13 cricohyoidopexy (CHP) and 8 cricohyoidoepiglottopexy (CHEP). All patients were examined by SCT during the follow-up, from 1 to 9 months, in the absence (21) or presence (3) of clinical signs of suspected or obvious recurrence. Results: 18 patients with negative SCT, endoscopy ond or biopsy, formed the basis of this study. The SCT features after CHP were: asymmetry of airway lumen (3D); lateral hypopharyngeal pocket ipsilateral to the preserved arytenoid (3D, MPR); persistence of one or both arytenoids (axial); slight angulation between the hyoid bone and associated cricoid (MPR); thickening of supraarytenoidal soft tissue (axial, 3D); transverse arrangement of vocal space during speech. After CHEP epiglottis is usually vertical and preepiglottic space is thin. Conclusion: After reconstructive surgery SCT with MPR and 3D images can help to represent the new anatomy and can evaluate some important areas which are critical in the endoscopic view: cricoarytenoid unit, hypopharingeal pockets, peepiglottic space.Purpose: To evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of MRI in staging (T parameter) of the laryngeal carcinoma and to compare the results of contrast enhanced MRI (CE MRI) and non-centrast enhanced MRI.Im 1808 Imaging of the larynx and oropharynxChairpersons: JA CASTELlJNS (Amsterdam/NL) G.C. ETTORRE (Bari/l) 1326 Pretherapeutic study of initial squamous cell carcinomas of the cheek P. Meingan, J. Viala, B. Mesurolle, R. Sigal; VillejuiflF Purpose: To evaluate the value of CT and MR in squamous cell carcinomas of the cheek at the pretherapeutic stage. Methods and Materials: Nine palients were reviewed with CT only (5), MRI only(1), CT and MR (3). Extension of the tumor was evaluated for the following sites: buccinator museie, mandible, maxilla, retromolar trigone, and Iymph nodes. Results: Imaging was severely hampered by dental material by CT in only one case, and only slightly difficult in 6 cases. Two patients had a localized lesion of the cheek, confined to the buccinator muscle. Six patients had an extension to the retromolar trigone. Mandibular and maxillary lesions were excluded in all cases. One patient only had also suspicious Iymph nodes. Surgery was performed in 8 cases and correlated with imaging data. Conclusion: CT and MRI are useful in the pretherapeutic study of cheek squamous cell carcinomas in spite of dental material artefacts. They are particularly useful to evaluate the extension to the retromolar trigone which is partially or completely clinically occult.Purpose: To define possibilities of different X-ray examination methods in diagnosing tumours of the upper respiratory tract, indications for different X-ray methods used. Methods and Materials: In period 1993-1998 1008 patients with the head and neck pathology were examined. According to the facts of Cancer registry in this period in Lithuanian Oncology Center for 223 patients larynx cancer, for 189 pharynx cancer, for 596 patients have been diagnosed non-malignant tumours, inflammatory processes, cysts, polyposis, etc. 2305 paranasal sinuses roentgenogrammes, oropharyngotomogrammes, 55 computed tomogrammes were made by Siemens Somatom Plius 4. Results: Indications for different X-ray methods used in diagnostics of upper respiratory tract tumours has been worked out. Using the method of oropharyngotomography it was ascertained that in case a malignant tumour is located in the nasal cavity, paranasal sinus, pharynx or nasopharynx, the soft palate is noted to be thickened intensively. Methods and Materials: 22 patients, with laryngeal earcinoma, underwent MRI examination with a superconductive magnet (1.5 T) first with SE T1* and T2w sequences, then with SE T1w enhanced sequence. Surgery was considered the gold standard. MR images were evaluated by lwo radiologists during a single session, using a multiple choice form, to evaluate the presence of infiltration of the following anatomie structures: supra/infra-glottal spaces, anterior commissure, vocal cords, Morgagni's ventricle, epiglottis, arytenoid eartilage, cricothyroid eartilage, thyroepiglottal compartment and paraglottal space. The form was expressed as a TNM staging. Results: There were no statistically differences belween the two techniques. MRI with contrast medium had a higher diagnostic accuracy than conventional MRI in the evaluation of the supraglottal space (2 patients) and paraglottal space (2 patients), without any diferences with regards to the T parameter. Conclusion: MR imaging had a higher diagnostic accuracy in T1 and T4 stages but contrast medium did not give more diagnostic information. 1331 Current value of double-contrast pharyngography and computed tomography in the primary diagnosis of hypopharyngeal, oropharyngeal and supraglottic tumors M. Keberle, W. Kenn, A. Tschammler, G. Wiltenberg , D. Hahn; Purpose: The current value of double-contrast pharyngography (DCP) and computed tomographY'{eT) in the primary diagnosis of hypopharyngeal , oropharyngeal and supraglottic tumors is determined. Methods and Materials: DCP of 151 patients and CT of 99 patients were retrospectively examined by 2 experienced unbiased radiologists using a standardised list with all relevant anatomieal subregions and the T-classification. The results were compared with direct and indirect laryngoscopy (DL and IL) and the pathological diagnosis. The collective was composed of 22 carcinoma and 1 hemangioma of the hypopharynx , 20 carcinoma of the supragloltic larynx, 44 of the oropharynx , 2 of the upper esophagus, 2 lymphomas and 60 normal cases. The interobserver variability was determined . Results: For DCP a sensitivity of 75.0% and a specificity of 86.7% was determined. The analysis of the inter-observer variability yielded good conformity (K =0.72) regarding a tumor presence. DCP and IL together

TABREF251.text: 15:10 1332 Value of spiral CT in patlents with oropharyngeal and hypopharyngeal tumors S. Kösling, M. Schmidtke, G. Trommer, J. Oeken; LeipziglDPurpose: To compare spiral and conventional CT in the diagnostic accuracy of oropharyngeal and hypopharyngeal tumors. Methods and Materials: Retrospectively, 105 conventional CTs performed on Somatom Plus or Somatom Plus S (5 mm slice thickness and table feed, 200 ml Lv. contrast medium) were analyzed. In a prospective study (Somatom Plus 4, 3 mm slice Ihickness, 5 mm table feed, 1.5 mm increment, 150 ml l.v contrast medium, 70 s delay) 110 patienls were included. Additionally, coronal reformations were obtained. All CT results were compared with histological findings.Results: In conventional CT, there was an accuracy of 84% in T staging (T1 62%, T2 78%, T3 82%, T4 94%) and of 86% in N staging (NO 80%, N1 72%, N2 89%, N3 95%). Spiral CT showed an accuracy of 85% in T staging (T1 66%, T2 74%, T3 88%, T4 95%) and of 86% in N staging (NO 82%, N1 79%, N2 88%, N3 95%). There were no statistically signifieant differences in the accuracy of spiral and conventional CT in patients with oropharyngeal and hypopharyngeal tumors. Conclusion: In spite of the missing statistieally signifieant differences in the accuracy of both CT methods, spiral CT shold be prefered. There is a tendency of improved diagnosis of T1, NO and N1 stages. The advantages in the CT technique are known.1333 Videofluorographic evaluation of swallowing disorders In head and neck cancer patients treated with radiation therapy M. Anooshiravani, M. Becker, P. Dulguerov, F. Esteve, A. Allal, F. Terrier; GenevaICHPurpose: Head and neck cancer patients treated with radiation therapy often present swallowing disorders that could influence their daily quality of Iife. By apreeise analysis of these disorders, videofluorography (VFG) allows a belter therapeutic choice. In this retrospective study we have analysed morphologie and functional abnormalities induced by radiation therapy. Methods and Materials: 407 patients were examined with VFG belween April 1995 and April 1998. Among them sixteen had been referred for swallowing disorders following radiation therapy as an exclusive treatment for head and neck cancer. Results: All of the 16 subjects presented functional abnormalities and only lwo had morphologie changes (one benign stricture and one tumour recurrence) The functional disorders consisted of palatal deficiency, pharyngeal and epiglottic hypomotility, and cricopharyngeal dysfunction. Fifteen patients had aspirated during the study, nine of them being "silent" aspirations. Conclusion: Dysphagia after high-dose radiation therapy for head and neck cancer indicates mostly functional rather than morphologie abnormalities. VFG enables the detection of Iife-threatening silent aspirations and forms the basis for further therapeutic decisions.14:10 1334 Computed tomography diagnosis of inorganic neck tumors G.G. Karmazanovsky, V.N. Dan, N.S. Nikitayev, A.A. Shoubin; Moscow/C/S

TABREF252.text: Methods and Materials:Fourteen TIPS were performed with use of expanded polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) stentgrafts anchored at both ends by Z stents and centrally supported by Wallstents or spiral Z stents. The patients were followed up by ultrasound. Results: Sufficient shunt was performed in all patients. One patient died of liver failure with fully open shunt. The other patients were asymptomatic and no complications related to the procedure occurred. The mean follow up was 6.8 months (range 2-10 months). There was one case of asymptomatic hepatic vein stenosis which occurred in 2 months. The other shunts are without stenoses. Conelusion: Our early clinical results support experimental results reported in literature. The PTFE stentgraft is technically feasible and safe for TIPS creation and TIPS patency may be improved. The use of stentgrafts should still be considered investigational because of limited experience.1335 Correlation of angiographie results in transjugular portosystemie shunts with maeroseopie and histopathologie findings G. Sodner, A. Kreczy, A. Chemelli, P. Waldenberger, W. Jaschke;Purpose: To evaluate angiographic finding in transjugular portosystemic shunts (TIPS) with macroscopical and histopathological findings. Methods and Materials: Angiography of 24 patients with restenosis were evaluated regarding to the location of the stenosis. Macroscopical and histopathological evaluations were performed on 8 TIPS containing livers. Results: Stenosis due to pseudo-intimal hyperplasia were found in 16 patients in the midpart of the stent, proximal from the draining portal vein and in 8 patient stenosis were found at theoutflow part of the TIPS, proximal from the draining hepatic vein. Macroscopical arrd histopathological examinations of the stenosis revealed fibrinous layers. Stenosis at the venous side of the TIPS appeared thicker than at the area of the portal inflow. No pseudo-intimal hyperlasia was seen in the portal entry of the stent. Conelusion: Pseudo-intimal hyperplasia is always seen proximally of the draining portal and venous vein inside the stent. Turbulent flow from draining vessels, induced by the stent struds may are the cause for stent stenosis.1336 Dur experienee in 327 TIPS E. Zanon, A. Mancini, F. Pedrazzini, A. Saroncelli, C. Gazzera, M. Garruso, R. Gallo, M. Grosso; Turin, Cuneo/I Purpose: To present our experience in 327 TIPS procedures performed using different types of stent. Methods and Materials: We treated 327 cirrhotic patients (117 female, 210 male), (45, 202, 80 Child A, S, Cl. The indications were: 218 digestive hemorrage (52 emergency), 99 intractable ascites, 7 pre-OLT and 3 Sudd-Chiari syndrome. Patients were monitored by US-Doppler, angiography and esophago-gastroscopy. Results: We obtained technical success in 324/327 cases (99.1%).We had respectively 30/324 (9.2%) early and 52/274 (18.9%) late stenoses-occlusions of the shunt. 12-month primary patency rate was 70%, while 12-month assisted patency rate was 94%. Reduction of refractory ascites was obtained in 63/99 (63.6%). The incidence of encephalopathy was 41/324 (14.2%), only 6 severe. Mortality rate was 89/324 (27.4%). Conelusion: TIPS is a safe and effective method to treat patients with portal hypertension and to reduce refractory ascites. An accurate follow-up is indispensable to manage steno-occlusions of the shunt with optimal percentage of resolution and long-term shunt patency rate.1337 PTFE stent graft for TIPS: short-term resultsA. Krajina, P. Hulek, M. Lojik, J. Maskova, P. Ryska; Hradec KralovelCl Purpose: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of a PTFE stentgraft in preventing acute and early instent stenoses of TlPS.1338 Primary implantation of polyester eovered stent grafts for the ereation of transjugular portosystemie stent shunts (TIP5S): a pilot study M. Cejna, SA Thurnher, M. Schoder, G. Pidlich, M. Kaserer, J. Lammer; Vienna/A Purpose: To evaluate if polyester covered stentgraft placement increases primary patency of TIPSS. Methods and Materials: Setween 1995 and 1997 Cragg Endopro orPassager MISS stentgrafts were used for the creation of TIPSS in eight male patients, 35 to 59 years of age (mean, 48 years). All patients suffered from recurrent variceal bleeding andl or refractory ascites due to liver cirrhosis. Seven stentgrafts were dilated to a diameter of 10 mm, one to 12 mm. Follow-up was performed with duplex ultrasound, c1inical assessment and angiography. Results: The technical success rate to create a TIPSS was 100%. The pressure gradient decreased from mean 25 mm Hg to 12 mm Hg. One patient underwent liver transplantation following TIPSS thrombosis, histological analysis demonstrated bile incorporation into the occluding thrombus. In 7 of 8 patients TIPSS dysfunction occured between 2 days and 3 years (mean 362 +-331 days) after stentgraft placement. In one patient the TIPSS is still primary patent (224 days after creation). Conelusion: The primary use of polyester covered stentgrafts for TIPSS did neither completely prevent bile leakage nor increase the primary patency rate in our small series.1339 Portal vein oeelusion and embolization as a tool to indueeIiver hypertrophy: teehnieal aspeets and experienees in 15 patients V. Nicolas, G. Krupski, M. Malago, M.G. Henschel, X. Rogiers, C.E. Sroelsch; Bochum/DPurpose: Hilar hepatic tumors as e.g. the Klatskin-tumor often tend to be irresectable due to small left hepatic volume and therefore at high risk for liver failure after extended right resection. Since portal venous occlusion facilitates liver hypertrophy, this technique can be used to increase left hepatic volume thus enabling extended right resection. We present our radiological and surgical experience of percutaneous portal vein embolization and hilar portal branch Iigation concerning induction of liver hypertrophy with respect to surgical outcome. Methods and Materials: To date, 15 patients (11 Klatskin-tu, 3 colorectal hepatic metastases, 1 metastatic adrenal carcinoma) were treated either by surgeons (hepatic ligation, n = 8) or radiologists (embolization, n = 7). 12 of these patients had extended right resection at intervals of 4 to 13 weeks. Results: There was a statistically significant increase in the volume of the left hepatic lobe of more than 100 ml. One patient died due to Iiver failure caused by extensive fally liver degeneration and reduced functional capacity prior to resection. Another patient, although with a significant increase of the liver volume, had a prolonged compromised liver function.Conclusion: Both surgery and percutaneous portal vein embolization lead to significant increase of the liver volume thus enabling extended resection. Aspects of tumor biology and procedural technique will be discussed.(Submitted byInternet)    1340 Metallic stents in the treatment of malignant biliaryobstruction: 8 years follow-up H. Alfke, M. Hoppe, B. Alfke, H.-J. Wagner; Marburg/D Purpose: To study the long term results of percutaneous metallic stent placement for the treatment of patients with malignant biliary obstruction and to evaluate for risk factors of reocclusion. Patients and Methods: From 1990 to 1998 we treated 130 consecutive patients (age 68.4 +-12.5 [30-92]). Lesion location was hilar in 54%, bile duct in 41%, and other in 7%. Underlying causes of malignant 30 day mortality was 11%. The mean primary patency rate according to Kaplan-Meier was 108 days. The comparison of the mean patency rates for the different underlying tumors revealed: 550 days for cholangiocarcinoma, 83 for pancreatic carcinoma, 121 for gallbladder carcinoma, and 92 for Iiver metastasis with a trend for a better prognosis in patients with cholangiocarcinoma (p = 0.057). Conclusion: Metal stents offer sufficient long term relief of jaundice due to malignant biliary obstruction. There is a trend for better primary patency with cholangiocarcinoma. (Submitted by Internet) 1341 Malignant biliary duct obstruction: 5 years experience with wallstents and radiation therapy -prospective randomised study V. Valek, P. Hrobaf; Brno/CZ Purpose: We evaluate the effect of radiation therapy including intraluminal iridium-192 on survival in patients with malignant biliary strictures treated with Wallstents in prospective randomises study. Methods and Materials: 37 patients with unresectable malignant biliary obstruction were treated with percutaneous Wallstents implantation followed by intraluminal Ir-192 brachytherapy (mean dose 30 Gy) and external actinotherapy (mean dose 50 Gy) and 29 patients only with Wallstents insertion in prospective randomise study. Results: From the group of patients treated by combined radiotherapy and Wallstent implantation died 31 (mean survival of 9.1 months), 6 still alive. From the group of patients treated only by Wallstent insertion 25 died (mean survival 7.6 months), 4 still alive. Conclusion: Our results shows, that combined radiation therapy could extend the survival in the patients with unresectable biliary obstruction. 1342 Therapy for benign biliary obstructions with use of balloon-expandable and self-expanding metallic stents: long-term follow-up I.K. Tesdal, T. Roeren, J. Koepke, W. Jaschke, M. Georgi; Mannheim/D, Purpose: To discuss the role of different metallic stents in the treatment of benign obstructive jaundice. Methods and Materials: Between 1989 and 1996, 21 patients with benign obstructive jaundice were treated by transhepatic placement of metallic stents (Wallstent: n =9; tantalum Strecker stent: n =4; Memotherm stent: n = 1; Palmaz stent: n = 9). Sixteen patients presented strictures not responding to balloon angioplasty (postsurgical: n =14; chronic cholangitis: n =2). Five patients were, from different reasons, treated primarily with stent angioplasty without predilation.Results: Twelve out of 20 patients (one patient was lost to follow-up) are alive with a mean survival of 43.2 ± 5.7 months without any 30day mortality. Reintervention due to recurrent obstructive jaundice was necessary in 10 patients (50%), and the mean stent patency (MSP) was 34.2 ± 7.2 months. The Palmaz stent was the most effective in achieving short and long-term patency with a MSP of 35.3 ± 0.8 months, versus 27.7 ± 11.2 months for Wallstent and 7 ± 2.3 months for Strecker stents. In 4 patients the stents were removed and the biliary-enteric anastomoses revised after 3, 6, 9 and 71 months. Conclusion: The treatment of benign biliary strictures with metallic stents is associated with high long-term obstruction and reintervention rates. The Palmaz stent is the most effective in achieving long-term patency.1343Radiologie detection and treatment of biliary complications in the pediatric post-Iiver transplant patient Y. Maetani, K. Itoh, F. Ametani, T. Shibata, T. Tabuchi, J. Konishi; Purpose: To evaluate the radiological findings and the causes of biliary complications after Iiving related partialliver transplantation (LRLT) and to show the interventional procedures against the complications. Methods and Materials: From June 1990 to July 1998, 380 cases of LRLT were performed in our hospital. Choledochojejunostomy was performed in all cases. Among them 47 percutaneous transhepatic cholangiograms (PTC) were obtained in 41 recipients (10.8%) to confirm a biliary complication. Most of them were children with the mean age of 9.6 y.o. Results: There were 32 anastomotic strictures caused by anastomotic failure or hepatic arterial thrombosis (HAT), and 14 intrahepatic strictures caused by ABO blood group incompatibility, HAT, or chronic rejection. Intrahepatic biloma was shown in 5 cases. As the treatment, percutaneous transhepatic biliary catheter drainage was required in 38 cases. Among them, percutaneous transhepatic balloon dilation was performed in 26. Drainage catheter was removed with the improvement of stricture in 6, catheter drainage still continues in 14. Surgical revision was performed in 13. Conclusion: PTC is mandatory in the diagnosis of biliary complications after LRLT and interventional procedures are helpful in the treatment of these complications. 1344 Interventional radiology in the treatment of liver echinococcosis SA Dadvani, A.N. Lotov, 0.5. Schkrob, G.H. Musaev, V.N. Avakian, JA Legon'kov, A.M. Bronstein, S.K. Ternovoj, S.A. Kondrashin; Moscow/C/S Purpose: To assess the efficacy of minimally invasive methods in the treatment of liver hydatid disease. Methods and Materials: In our surgical clinic from 1986 to 1998 38 patients with liver echinococcosis underwent treatment. The age of the patients changed from 3 till 69 years. The main imaging methods were US, CT and electron-beam CT, serologic evaluation. In 29 (76.3%) patients cyst was solitary single-chamber, in 6 (15.8%) -multiple singlechamber, 2 (5.3%) -solitary multi-chamber and in 1 (2.6%) -solitary cysts in liver and right lung. In all patients was fulfilled percutaneous drainage of the cyst under ultrasound and f1uoroscopic control by complex stylet-catheter. Cyst cavity was processing with 20.0% NaCI solution or our own special mixture (last 10 patients) at 15 min duration. After microbiologically proven parasite destruction we expand the punction channel diameter with telescopic dilators up to 32 F. Then we destroy and aspirate chytinic membrane of the cyst under endoscopic control. In the postoperative period patients underwent three courses of prophylactic peroral therapy with Albendazol. Results: All patients were treated with good results without serious complications with mean drainage duration of 16 ± 3 days. Followup in 4-7 months in 5 (13.2%) patients reveal residual cavity required percutaneous punction. In one patient in subcutaneous fat formatted new cyst after early drainage removal.Conclusion: The received results surpass results of traditional surgical treatment. CONTRAST MEDIA EI 1806 MR contrast agents: MR angiography arteries were measured. Image quality was assessed based on a 4point scale. Results: Bolus characteristics revealed a significantly (p < 0.05) higher maximum SNR in the 'light' (34.9 ± 9.2) compared to the 'heavy' group (23.4 ± 5.2). Difference in time to maximum SNR was statistically not significant. Quantitative assessment of the 3D MRA demonstrated significantly higher arterial SNR values in the 'light' group (p < 0.05). Image quality was rated better by at least one grade in all four light subjects, in the 'heavy' group, in one subject the renal arteries were not diagnostic. Conclusion: These data suggest that dosing for contrast-enhanced 3D MRA should be weight-adjusted instead of based on fixed volumes. 1345 Evaluation of arterial first pass contrast medium dynamics as a function of intravenous injection parameters M. Boos, K. Scheffler, R. Haselhorst, E. Reese, P. Huber, J. Fröhlich, G.M. Bongartz; Basel/CH Purpose: To evaluate the arterial first pass contrast medium dynamics at the descendic aorta (DAo) in dependence from injection parameters. Methods and Materials: Using an ultra-fast 2D GE-sequence (Siemens Vision®, 1.5 Tl, 180 cross-sectional images of the DAo (1 slice/sec) were obtained. Several dosages of Gd (0.5, 1.0, 2.0 and 3.0 mmol/kg) and NaCI flush volumes (15, 30, 60 ml) were applied to a group of 4 normal volunters (BW 50 kg). The flow rates were varied (0.5, 1, 2 and 3 ml/s) using a mechanical MR injector. The signal intensity to time curve of DAo was evaluated. The bolus arrival time (BAT), the maximal signal to noise ratio (S/N), the bolus time length (BL; 80 and 75% maximum intensity duration) and the bolus time length dilution constant (BTDC were calculated. Results: Pierro, R. Kristy, J. Baker, K. Wolfe-Kerker, L. Kratz; St. Louis, MOIUSAPurpose: Four studies were conducted to determine the pharmacokinetic profile of OptiMARK® (Gadoversetamide Injection). Methods and Materials: The studies enrolled 245 subjects; normal volunteers; subjects with CNS or Iiver pathology, with or without renal insufficiency; subjects requiring hemodialysis. Each received 0.1, 0.3, 0.5 or 0.7 mmol/kg OptiMARK or placebo. Results: A brief distribution phase is completed by 1 hour post-dose. Analysis indicates OptiMARK kinetics are linear over the range of 0.1 to 0.7 mmol/kg. The data demonstrated no difference due to gender in gadoversetamide elimination. Renal impairment increased the half-Iife. Serum clearance of gadolinium was not dose related. No significant metabolism of gadoversetamide occurs. A good correlation was observed between total and renal dearance of gadoversetamide. Renal impairment affects the rate of gadoversetamide excretion, but not the extent. After 3 dialysis sessions, 98% of the drug had been cleared from the circulation. Conclusion: The pharmacokinetics of OptiMARK are not affected by gender, age or disease state, other than renal. OptiMARK is eliminated into the urine and is not metabolized. Renal impairment decreases the rate, but not the extent, of OptiMARK excretion. OptiMARK can be efficiently removed from the circulation by hemodialysis.

TABREF253.text: 3D-TOF MRA sequence and an ultrafast MRA (TR =4.6 msec, TE =1.7 msec , FA =35°, slab thickness 50 mm, 48 partitions, FOV =130 x 260 , matrix 128 x 256, duralion 25 sec) after bolus injection of Gd-DOTA at a dose of 0.1 mmol/kg. Timing of the acqu isition was optimized by a testbolus in order to achieve the maximum peak of enhancement. Results: No adverse effects were reported. Sensitivity and specificity were not statistically significant (Dotarem 93.5%/89.6%, TOF-MRA 93 .5%/84 .4%). But , more segments were assessable with Dotarem MRA than with TOF MRA (66.2% versus 51% considering all segments (ICAS and CCAS) , 100% versus 97% for ICAS) .The examination time was much shorter for Dotarem MRA (25 sec) than for TOF MRA (12 min) . Conclusion : DOTA-MRA has an equal accuracy than TOF MRA with shorter examinalion time and more asses sable segments. 14:45 1350 Efficacy of blood pool contrast media for 3D-TOF-MRA of perlpheral and coronary vessels M.R. Engel brecht, M. Saeed , M. Wend land, H. Sakuma , C.B. Higgins ; NijmegenlNL, San Francisco, CAIUSA

VON KUMMER (Dresden/D) 14:00 1355 Quantitative seml-autemated evaluation of leukoaraiosis and correlation with psychomotor performances S. Budassi, A. Tartaro, A. Di lorio, R. D'Adduzio, G. Abate, L. Bonomo;Purpose: The aim of this work was to compare the volume of periventricular hypodensity (Leukoaraiosis), detected at CT examination and measured by means of quantitative semi-automated computeraided method, with psychomotor performances of elderly subjects. Methods and Materials: Twenty-five neurologically non-diseased, elderly subjects (mean age 78 years), were prospectively enroled. All subjects underwent a complete Geriatrics Comprehensive Assessment (Tinetti's scale, MMSE, GDS) and non-enhanced CT examination of the brain. CT parameters were: 22 contiguous 5 mm thick slices; 205 mAs, 140 kV. Leukoaraiosis (LA) was assessed on CT images by means of a quantitative semi-automated computer-aided method. Data were compared by using Student t test, Pearson c2 and multiple linear regression analysis (MLR) Results: At univariate analysis, no relation was found among LA load (expressed in cm3) and sex, age and cognitive level. A significant inverse correlation was found in MLR between LA load and walking performance, adjusted for age, cognitive level and risk factors. Conclusion: In a population of normal elderly subjects, in whom the quantitative method shows low LA load, a sub-clinical impairment in walking performance is detectable. We hypothise that an increased LA load may cause more severe motor disturbances of c1inical relevance.(Submitted by Internet)

TABREF257.text: Retrospective Study: -31/520 MR scans of patients showed signal intensity changes of WD in various intracranial lesions. Presence of WD in these intracranial lesions correlated weil with persistent c1inical disability. Conclusion: Wallerian degeneration can be seen secondary to any CNS insult with MRI and its presence correlate weil with persistent functional disability.1358 Haemorrhagic transformation and different patterns of contrast enhancement in MRI during the first week in acute stroke J. Karonen, K. Partanen, R Vanninen, P. Vainio, J. Nuutinen, R Roivainen, J. Sivenius, S. Soimakallio, H.J. Aronen; Kuopio/FINPurpose: To evaluate development of haemorrhagia and different patterns of contrast enhancement in MRI during the first week in acute stroke. Methods and Materials: MRI was performed on 35 acute stroke patients (age range 48-87, mean 72 yrs) three times: 1) on the day of admission «24 hrs after c1inical ictus), 2) on the second day and 3) after one week. The MRI protocol consisted of T1, T2, diffusion weighted, perfusion weighted and postcontrast T1 imaging. The postcontrast T1 images were obtained immediatelly after perfusion imaging (not considered here) the dose of gadolinium being 0.2 mmol/kg. Results: On the second day, haemorrhagic changes were detected in 17-34% of cases and in 52-76% of cases after one week, depending on the imaging sequence. In postcontrast T1 imaging, the following patterns of contrast enhancement were detected in different time points (1S! day/2 nd day/1 week): intravascular 73%/85%/72%, meningeal 33%/39%/44%, gyriform 9%/12%/47%, transcortical 9%/21 %/63%, miscellaneous parenchymal 18%/24%/66% and sulcal enhancement 9%/9%/22%. Conclusion: According to MRI findings, haemorrhagic transformation was fairly common in initially non-haemorrhagic strokes. Intravascular and meningeal enhancement was often present after one week from stroke onset. On the other hand, parenchymal enhancement sometimes appeared even on the first two days.1359 Detection of acute and subacute intracranial hemorrhage with MRI at 1.5 T: an experimental study in rabblt O. The age of the patients at the time of onset of HIE ranged from 4 days to 70 years. Imaging findings were divided into four stages after the time of onset. Acute (day 1-7; n =4), early subacute (day 8-14; n =3), late subacute (day 15-28; n =3), ehrenie (>28 days; n =5)

TABREF259.text: Conclusion: MRI in hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy demonstrates chronologically changing distinct features. Some of these features may have prognostic importance.1361 Evaluation of Kallmann's syndrome with MRI N. Abolmaali, T. Hummel; DresdenlD Purpose: To determine the efficiency of coronal T1-and T2-weighted volume-sequences with multiplanar reformation in patients with Kallmann's Syndrome 8304 Methods and Materials: In 20 patients who reported no olfactory function since birth and had olfactory testing we used coronal T1weighted mp-rage volume-sequences (TR 9.7, TE 4.0, Flip 12, SL 1 mm) with isotropie pixels and without administration of Gadolinium and coronal T2-weighted TSE volume-sequences (TR 3400, TE 120, Flip 180, SL 1.9 mm) with a 1.5 Tesla-System (Magnetom Vision, Siemens, Erlangen). Additionally we reconstructed the acquired images in all orthogonal planes. Results: In all patients absence or hypoplasia of the olfactory tract or bulb could be c1early demonstrated. Additionally interruption or total absence of the olfactory sulcus was easily visualized. Conclusion: T1 and T2 weighted volume-sequences with multiplanar reconstruction are both valuable tools in imaging of Kallmann's syndrome.1362 Rostral vermian cortical dysplasia: a new entity Ph. Demaerel, K. Op de beeck, G. Wilms; Leuven/B Purpose: To describe the imaging appearances of a previously unreported congenital malformation. Methods and Materials: Fifteen patients with rostral vermian dysplasia were identified. Imaging included T2-weighted axial and coronal images. A 3D gradient echo sequence was obtained in three patients. These images were reformatted in all three planes using 1 mm slices in order to accurately localize the abnormalities. Results: The defective foliation and fissuration of the culmen and central lobule of the anterior lobe of the vermis extended into the hemispheres in 5/15 patients. Thickening of the cerebellar cortex and supratentorial congenital abnormalities were observed in respectively 4/15 and 3/15 patients. The clinical presentation was variable but one patient was asymptomatic. Conclusion: Rostral vermian dysplasia varied in degree of severity with a spectrum of abnormalities ranging from mild to extensive changes. In 8/15 patients there was no correlation between the clinical findings and the MR appearances. Because the symptoms were never life threatening, no pathological correlation could be obtained. Experimental studies on rats and hamsters have demonstrated similar vermian abnormalities after 6-hydroxydopamine treatment. We suggest that the abnormalities may result from an intrauterine insult leading to a destruction of meningeal cells and a destabilization of the cerebellar surface.15:10 1363 Multimodality imaging analysis in schizophrenia C. Benito, P. Fernandez, M. Desco, J. Lampreave, V. Molina, J. Carreras; Madrid/EPurpose: Schizophrenia is the best example of entities that are a good candidate to be studied by multimodality fusion techniques. Methods and Materials: This study includes 40 patients with schizophrenia (20/50) DSM-IV criteria, resistant to conventional treatment. They underwent imaging controls before and after at least 6 months of therapy with Clozapin. Imaging protocol consisted of MRI, PET, and image postprocessing study, with registration, segmentation and quantification of volume and PET activity in the following areas: • Premotor frontal lobe, defined according to a Talairach reference frame. • Temporal lobe, hippocampal-amygdala complex and neocortical structures. • Basal ganglia.

TABREF260.text: 1371 B. The CT approach Ph. Soyer; ParislFMR imaging is a powerful tool in detecling foeal liver lesions. Plain MR ls not sensible enough in the detection of small liver tumors. This limitation is especially troublesome with malignant lesions. Either dynamic MR imaging during the arterial, portal and delayed phases after the administration of extraeellular-distributed gadolinium ehelates, or specifie liver-target agents (like SPIO, MnDPDP and some gadolinium chelates) improve the ability of MR to detect small masses. On the other hand, the semiologie analysis of liver lesions must include architeetural, dynamie perfusion and signal intensity characteristics (mainly with T1 in phase and oppose-phase, proton density and T2 weighted images). With this data, MR is able to eharacterize most Iiver lesions, thus redueing the need for aspiration biopsy. The role, accuracy and pitfalls of MR will be presented. Learning Objectives: (1) To understand the different MR techniques useful in the study of focal Iiver lesions. (2) To familiarize with different non-specific and specific contrast media. (3) To recognize the most usual presentation of focal liver lesions. 1372 C. The MR approach L. Marti-Bonmati; Va/encialE

TABREF261.text: 16:10 1376 New experimental double IR breath·hold ECG triggered sequences in the evaluation of right ventricular myocardium A. Vanzulli, R Mellone, F. Oe Cobelli, P. Scifo, E. Garuti, A. Dei Maschio; Milan/I Purpose: The evaluation of the right ventricular myocardium with classical sequences is often difficult due to motion artifacts. The purpose of this work was the comparison of ECG triggered breath-hold multishot FSE black-blood sequences with new experimental double inversion pulses (double IR-MSFSE) and conventional ECG triggered SE TIW sequences in the depiction of right venticular myocardium. Methods and Materials: 25 consecutive patients were evaluated at 1.5 T (GE Signa Echo-Speed) with short axis ECG triggered SE TIW sequences (TRITE = 80% RE/15 msec) and with ECG triggered breathhold multi shot FSE sequences with double inversion pulses (double IR-MSFSE) (TRITE =2 RR/40 msec, ETL =32). The first inversion pulse is not slice selective and is used to create black-blood, while the second IR causes T1 weghting (TI =600 msec). Two short axis planes were obtained with each sequence. Right ventricle thickness, and presence of artifacts were evaluated by two observers in conference. Results: With conventional SE sequences the right ventricular myocardium was detectable and measurable in 37/50 sections, with a mean thickness of 6.6 mm. Artifacts were graded 1.5. With MSFSE sequences the right ventricular myocardium was detectable and measurable in 42/50 sections, with a mean thickness of 6 mm. Artifacts were graded 0.3. Conclusion: The new experimental MSFSE sequences are usefull in suppressing artifacts and give a very goOO depiction of right ventricular myocardium. 16:20 1377 The role of MRI in the diagnosis of arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia G.P. Reddy, H.W.M. Kayser, J. Bremerich, E.E. van der Wall, A. de Roos, C.B. Higgins; San Francisco, CAIUSA, LeidenlNL

TABREF262.text: Submitted by Internet) 1378 MRI diagnosis of endomyocardial fibrosis K. Li, S.L. Liu, L. Jiang; BeijinglPRCPurpose: To evaluate the diagnostic value of MRI in endomyocardial fibrosis (EMF). Methods and Materials: 9 patients underwent MRI with ECG-gated SE and GE cine techniques. The diagnosis of EMF was made by imaging findings including echocardiography, cardiac catheterazition, angiocardiography and operation. Results: The patients were divided into three subtypes: RVEMF, LVEMF and BVEMF. The findings of EMF on MRI as folIows: 1. RVEMF (6): RV is smaller and deformed with hypokinetic contraction of the ventricular wall and thickening of endocardium. The obliteration of apex, shortening of inflow tract and dilatation of outflow tract and the moderate to a great quantity of tricuspid regurgitation are depicted by eine MRI. The right atrium remarkably enlarged and vena cava dilated. 2. LVEMF (1): The obtuse apex, thickening endocardium and multiple outpouching wall of LV are seen, and mitral regurgitation and hypokinetic wall of LV are depicted also on cine MR imaging, with marked enlargement of left atrium and dilatation of pulmonary artery and vein. 3. BVEMF (3): Although both findings of RVEMF and LVEMF are present, one side of the heart is dominator. Of them, one case there is mural thrombus located in apex of RV. Conclusion: The findings of EMF on MRI is characteristic, and have conformed diagnosis value.1379 Multiplanar reformations of a k-space segmented gradient echo sequence: a new approach for evaluation of cardiac morphology A. Leppert, J. Lotz, S. Baus, M. Galanski; HannoverlD Purpose: Comparison of muliplanar reformations (MPR) of a single nonsequential k-space segmented gradientecho sequence (ns-Fastcard) to conventional spinecho (SE) sequences in three planes in order to optimize evaluation of cardiac morphology.Methods and Materials: 20 patients after correction of congenital heart failure (8 Fontan, 6 Mustard, 6 ISTA) were examined both with axial, coronal and sagittal SE (TE 20 ms, TR 1 x RR, ThklSp 8/2 mm) and a coronal ns-Fastcard (TE 3.7 ms, TR 11.6 ms, Flip 20°, ThklSp 4/0 mm). Accuracy of distance measurements using MPR of ns-Fastcard was determined. Additionally, three radiologists rated the presentation of cardiac structures and anastomoses or baffles. Results: Distance measurements using MPR of ns-Fastcard are cornparable to those using SE. Compared to SE sequences ns-Fastcard images reveal superior myocardium/blood contrast espeeially in cases of low blood flow. Due to the usually oblique orientation of anastomoses and baffles, MPR of ns-Fastcard are superior to SE sequences using three orthogonal planes. Conclusion: ns-Fastcard with MPR offers the possibility of retrospective and interactive determination of slice direction and superior myocardium/blood contrast in low blood flow. Therefore, this sequence is better than conventional standard plane SE sequences for evaluation of cardiac morphology.1380 Evaluation of isolated ventricular non-compaction in chUdren A. von Smekal, G. Junga, S. Kneifei, J. Schwitter, H. Steinert, U. Bauersfeld, GK von Schullhess, B. Marincek; ZurichlCHPurpose: Isolated ventricular non-compaction (IVNC) is a rare congenital cardiomyopathy with poor prognosis due to heart failure and ventricular arrhythmias. It was to evaluate morphological and functional changes of IVNC. Methods and Materials: Five children with IVNC were examined. All but one child were clinically asymptomatic at diagnosis and during follow-up. Cardiac murmurs were found in four and dyspnea in one patient. PET perfusion 13NH3 and metabolie 18FDG studies were performed. IVNC was diagnosed by echocardiography and MRI. Coronary arteries were normal in all children, all underwent electrophysiologic testing. Results: MRI visualized best the extend of IVNC related morphological changes. PET demonstrated decreased myocardial blood flow at rest and after intravenous dipyridamole application in non-compacted myocardium (0.84 ml/min/g and 2.61 ml/min/g) compared to normal myocardium (1.09 mllmin/g and 4.83 ml/min/g) indicating locally impaired coronary-flow-reserve. Electrophysiologic testing revealed late potentials in three and abnormal OT dispersion in one child. Conclusion: The combination and fusion of PET and MRI allows qood correlation of regional morphological and functional changes in IVNC. The study results demonstrate microvascular dysfunction causing myocardial ischemia in children with IVNC in the affected areas.1381 The influence of vibration on echocardiographic parameters M. Razmadze, M.B. Balavadze; TbilisilGEOPurpose: estimation of the influence of general vibration on the functional state of heart using colour dopplerechocardiography. Methods and Materials: out of 137 males { 30% representative cohort of railway transport workers} 90 {70%} were exemined. Average age was 47.5 ± 5.8; mean duralion of vibration -6.0 ± 4.5 years.Invesligation includes: ECG, stress test and dopplerechocardiography.All patients were divided into 3 groups: I{ N = 41 } is with arterial hypertension {AH } ; U { N = 32}-without AH, but with echopathologie changes; UI-{N = 23} control-without pathology.

Maas, C. Hamm, M. Stubbe, E. Bücheler, P. Steiner;Purpose: Imaging of myocardial signal alterations and perfusion differences after Percutaneous Myocardial Laser Revascularisation (PMLR) and Transmyocardial Laser Revascularisation (TMLR). Methods and Materials: MRI was performed pre-and 4-7 d postlasertherapy in 30 patients with end-stage coronary vessel disease. Breathhold, multislice, ultrafast turbo-FLASH gradient echo (30 s acquisition time) and T-1-weighted spin echo sequences were acquired ECGtriggered before and after injection of Gadolinium-OTPA (0.15 mmollkg). First pass perfusion was evaluated on the basis of qualitative and quantitative analysis. Myocardial signal alterations and wall changes were also depicted. Quantitative analysis was based on contrast-tonoise (C/N) data obtained from operator defined "Region of Interests".Results: Visualisation of laser induced channels was not possible. Native scans obtained before and after lasertherapy revealed no significant change with regard to the qualitative analysis.Both qualitative and quantitative analysis demonstrated a posttherapeutic increase of C/N in both left ventricular myocardium (64.4 pre-, 89.1 post-Iasertherapy; p =0.06) and septum in the majority of cases. No significant difference between laser-treated left myocardium and untreated septum was observed (p > 0.05). Conclusion: Visualisation of increased myocardial enhancement in laser-treated left ventricular myocardium was evident in the majority of cases on the basis of qualitative and quantitative analysis. The MRI-technique used, enabled a first, limited depiction of laser-induced myocardial changes. The c1inical value and impact of laser revascularisation still has to be defined. 1383 Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in cardiac massescomparison with histological findings U. Hoffmann, S. Globits, C. Loewe, R. Loewe, G. Oberhuber, Ch.J. Herold, H. Frank; ViennalAPurpose: The aim of this retrospective study was to assess the diagnostic value of MRI with respect to tumor malignancy/benignity in various histologically c1assified types of cardiac tumors. Patients and Methods: Since 1988 184 patients (pts.) were refered to the MR unit for the evaluation of a suspected cardiac or paracardiac mass. In 44 out of 184 pts. histological specimens of the tumor were available to serve as a basis for the assessment of tumor characteristics by MRI, whieh was performed using eertain morphologie eriteria (i.e.: signal enhancement, invasiveness). Results: Histologie examination showed a malignant tumor in 18 of 44 pts., which was in accordance with MRI in 14 pts.. The most common diagnosis included metastatic tumor formation (10 pts.), sarcoma (4 pts.) and lymphoma (2 pts.). 26 tumors were classified histologically as benign, MRI yielded the correet dignity assessment in 25 pts., including myxoma (6 pts.), thrombi (4 pts.) and granulomatous tissue as in case of tuberculosis (5 pts.). Overall sensitivity of MRI for assessment of malignancy/benignity in cardiac tumors was 72% and specificity was 96%, respectively.Conclusion: This retrospective analysis shows the high diagnostic impact of MRI in patients with cardiac tumors.

Conclusion: MRI can reliably provide functional information on parameters such as pressure gradients and volume flow after arterial switch repair of TGA. Furthermore, temporary stenosis in the primary pulmonary branches with significant changes in hemodynamics did occur and could not be seen by other imaging modalities.1397 Assessment of hemodynamic changes in patients with chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension after thromboendarterectomy by breath-hold MR techniques K.-F. Kreitner, S. Ley, P. Kalden, E. Mayer, G. Laub, M. Thelen;Purpose: to evaluate breath-hold MR techniques for assessment of hemodynamic changes in patients with ehrenie thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension.Methods and Materials: 10 patients with severe pulmonary hypertension due to thromboembolic disease were examined before and after pulmonary thromboendarterectomy. MR imaging was performed at 1.5 T using the body-array coil. For assessment of hemodynamics, a velocity-encoded segmented gradient-echo through the pulmonary arteries and a segmented eine gradient-echo sequence along the short axis of the left and right ventricle were performed. Further analysis was done at aseparate work station using the Argus software V 2.0. Flowmeasuremants were compared to the invasively measured pulmonary arterial pressures and vasculare resistances. Results: Flow-measurements c1early demonstrated a significant increase in pulmonary arterial flow postoperatively (peak velocity: +84%). This corresponded to the invasively measured reduction of pulmonary arterial pressure and pulmonary vascular resistance (p < 0.001). Cine imaging revealed a sigificant increase in right ventricular stroke volume and ejection fraction. Conclusion: Breath-hold segmented gradient-echo techniques enable non-invasive assessment of pulmonary hemodynamics in patients with chronic thromboembolic disease that undergo surgery. Further evaluation of pulmonary hemodynamics by rapid MRI-techniques may replace invasive procedures.Conclusion: The vasodilation was significantly lower in the group with NNCA than in SX group (p < 0.05). These data suggest that the abnormalities of the endothelium-dependent vasodilation have segmental character, arises more often in pts with NNCA.J. Lotz, A. Leppert, S. Baus, R. Kaulitz, H. Koestler, M. Galanski;

Felix; BerJi n/DPurpose: Aim of this study was to evaluate if MRI could be reliably used to assess the degree of stenosis and hemodynamic changes in the great vessels due to the arterial switch operation, which might influence the longterm outcome. Methods and Materials: MRI measurements were performed on a 1.5 T scanner (Gyroscan ACS-NT, Philips, Best, Netherlands). Twenty patients after undergoing an arterial switch operation were examined. Besides standard spin-echo sequences in three planes, flow and diameter measurements of the pulmonary trunk and its primary branches were performed by phase-shift velocity mapping and CINE-MRI. Results: Phantom studies demonstrated a good reliability of the sequence used for volume flow measurements (r =0.999, P < 0.001). Invive studies showed a good correlation for estimated pressure gradients in the pulmonary arteries as compared to Doppler or catheter data(11 patients). TABREF266.text: 1399 B. Conventional hysterosalpingography and tubal recanalisation A. Maubon, J.P. Rouanet; Montpellier/F Hysterosalpingography (HSG) remains an essential diagnostic tool in the initial work-up of an infertility, along with ovulation assessment and male sperm analysis. It must have two goals:1. Diagnostic: detection of abnormalities, potentially responsible for the infertility, related to the uterine cavity (uterine malformations, synechiae, fibromas...) or related to the tubes and peritoneum (tubai obstruction, salpingitis isthmica nodosa, tubal endometriosis, peritoneal adhesions...).

TABREF269.text: 1909 Intervention of the venous system Chairperson: E. ZEITLER (Nürnberg/D) 1405 A. Venous access J.E. Jackson; Londan/UKThere are numerous indicatians far central venaus catheter placement and these have increased considerably over the last ten years. Whereas previously the majority af the long-term devices were inserted by surgeans there has been a tendency in many centres for the procedure ta be performed radiolog ically. There are several reasons for this including shorter procedure times and lower complication rates. In addition , espec ially in those patients who have undergone previous central venous catheter insertion , patency of the peripheral and central veins can be easily confirmed by ultrasound or contrast venography prior to attempted catheterization. In those individuals in whom the more usual venous accesses are occluded, other techniques (for example a translumbar puncture of the inferior vena cava) may be performed under radiolog ical guidance . Radiolog ists are in an ideal position to provide a full venous access serv ice; many of the early and late complications of these central venous catheters such as occlusion , catheter breakage and venous thrombosis may be managed by using radiological techniques. This presentation will concentrate on the video presentation of tunnelled central venous catheter insertion . The potential complica tions of central venous catheters and their management will also be discussed.1406 B. Venous stenting Ch.L. Zollikofer; Winterthur/CH Various causes , benign and malignant may cause obstruction or stenosis of the V. cava and large Veins. Those seen most frequently inelude compression by malignant disease , fibrous reactions after radiation therapy, the sequellae of deep vein thrombosis or from indwelling central venous catheters. Other causes for venous obstruction include trauma, infection, post surgical complications, venous anomalies etc. The sites most frequently involved in these conditions are the superior and inferior V. eava (ineluding the innominate and pelvic veins).

TABREF270.text: Conclusion:Results are suggesting that skull fracture is predictive of CT evidence of contusion and/or haematoma, obliterated basal cisterns, and presence of extracerebral haematoma. Thus, skull X-ray may be helpful in initial assessment of patients with AHT.Ch. Weber, U. Grzyska, P. Steiner, R. Maas, E. Lehner, E. Bücheler, H. Zeumer; Hamburg/D Purpose: Evaluation of specificity, sensitivity and therapeutic consequences of cranial CT in the emergency department. Methods and Materials: 600 cerebral CTs were evaluated for indication, quality, sensitivity, specificity and therapeutic consequences. Before CT neurological examination was routinely performed. CT results were correlated to the e1inical indications for CT, neurological findings and posttherapeutic/postoperative and discharge diagnoses. In 23% MRI and in 4% cerebral angiography followed CT during the hospital stay. MRI confirmed CT diagnoses in 62%, angiography in 50%. Results: The common indications were cerebral bleeding (48%), skull fracture (15%), cerebral infarction (14%), space occupying lesion (8%), cerebral infection (6%) and hydrocephalus (4%). The correlation of CT diagnoses and discharge diagnoses was relatively high with a specificity of 80% and a sensitivity of 81%. 12% of the cranial CTs were followed by surgical intervention, 8% :S;12 h, 4% >12 h post CT. 5% were followed by an external ventricular shunting. Conclusion: High sensitivity and specificity of cranial CT in the emergency department in establishing a diagnosis confirms the important role of CT as a primary diagnostic method. Timely, reproducable and precise diagnosis outweighes increased costs and facilitates a shortened hospital stay.1408 Computed tomography in relation to the presence and type of skull fracture in patients with acute head trauma R. Maksimovic, B. Goldner, M. Janicijevic, T. Stosic, M. Dunjic, D. Stankovic, M. Perovic; Belgrade/YU Purpose: The role of skull fracture of in assessing patients with acute head trauma (AHT) is still controversial. The purpose of the study was to further investigate the possibility of skull fracture in predicting CT changes in patients with AHT. Methods and Materials: Our study group included 194 patients withAHT, mostly men (62.4%), mean age 46.5 ± 24.1 (range 1-91) years, who were admitted to the emergency department in the three months period. All patients underwent clinical workup, X-ray, and CT scans. Patients were divided into group 1, with skull fracture with 37.1% (72/194) patients and group 2, without skull fracture, which ineluded 62.9% (122/194) patients. The difference of frequencies between groups was evaluated using Chi 2 test, and t test when appropriate. Results: In group 1, linear fracture was present in 83.3% (60/72), while depressed fracture was notified in 16.7% (12/72) patients. In group 1, contusion and/or haematoma was found in 37.9% (25/66) patients, Also, there was statistical significant difference between frequencies of patients with obliterated basal cisterns in group 1 {40.9% (27/66)} and group 2 {23.5% (28/119)}, (Chi 2 =6.1, P < 0.05). Extracerebral haematoma was present more frequently in group 1 {37.1 % (26/70)} than in group 2 {23.8% (29/122)}, (Chi 2 = 3.9, p < 0.05). There was no statistical significant difference among these groups with respect to present of blood in ventrieles and subarachonid space, as weil as to Glasgow Coma Score and age. The same is true for the type of fracture and CT findings.1409 Diagnostic value of CT in the evaluation of gunshot injuries to the head D. Passomenos, G. Mantzikopoulos, K. Pikoulas, S. Kouris, X. Zlatidou, K. Dagianta; Athens/GR Purpose: Gunshot injuries to the head carry a high percentage of skull penetration resulting in death. As intracranial gunshot-associated lesions can be revealed by CT, surgical intervention can be Iife-saving in severe head trauma. We evaluated the efficacy of computed tomography of the head in depicting trauma-associated pathology in victims with gunshot wounds. Methods and Materials: Eighteen patients with gunshot injuries to the head, admitted in our Hospital in aperiod of the 16 last months were evaluated with plain radiographs and computed tomography. All but one were young male adults. Sixteen cases were assaults and two suicidal attempt. Results: Skull fractures were detected in 14 patients. Brain contusions were present in 15 and subdural hematomas in 9 patients. Midline shift was estimated to be less than 10 mm in all cases. Paranasal sinuses involvement was present in 2 cases and orbital injury in one case. Entry and exit sites were identified by CT in all cases. Conclusion: Computed tomography may be used as a front line examination in gunshot wounds to the head, as it depicts projectile path and associated intracranial pathology and reveals subtle bone fractures. Operative or conservative management of the trauma victims is largely based on CT findings, so that neurosurgeons should be closely working with radiologists.1410 Delayed cerebral ischemia caused by traumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage: computerized tomography evidence R. Maksimovic, B. Goldner, M. Janicijevic, S. Stankovic, D. Milovanovic; Belgrade/YU Purpose: This study provides findings of the influence of traumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage (tSAH) on the development of delayed cerebral ischemia detected by computerized tomography (CT) scans. Methods and Materials: Prospective study ineluded 194 patients, mostly men (62.4%), mean age 46.5 ± 24.1 (range 1-91) years,with elosed head trauma (CHT). The amount of subarachnoid blood was estimated according to a modification of the criteria of Fisher. According to the clinical course, CT scans were repeated in patients who deteriorated during hospitalization. Results: Out of 194 patients, 60 (30.9%) patients had tSAH on admission CT scans. Unilateral tSAH was in 30% (18/60) patients while bilateral was present in 70% (42/60) patients with CHT. In five patients (8.3%), out of 60 with tSAH, delayed ischemic symptoms developed between days 4 and 16 after the head injury. They consisted of one patient (5.5%) out of 18 with unilateral tSAH and in four patients (9.5%) out of 42, with bilateral tSAH. The difference of patients with delayed ischemic symptoms between these two groups did not reach statistical significance (Chi2 = 1.6, P > 0.05). There was a close correlation between the main site and amount of the tSAH, according to the modified Fisher scale, and the location offocal ischemic areas on followup CT scans. Conclusion: These results demonstrate that delayed ischemia is dependent on massive tSAH, rather than its extensiveness. Furthermore, presence of delayed ischemia may be an important determinant of outcome in patients with CHT that could be easy recognized on CT scans.1411 Combined endovascular and surgical treatment of intracranial hematomas following middle cerebral artery aneurysm rupture E. Castro Reyes, F. Villoria Medina, F. Fortea Gil, L. Muiioz Alrnazan, S. Sanchez Alarcos, C. Benito Cristobal, R. Carrillo Yague; MadridlE
