Forsting; EssenIDPurpose: To test the in-vitro performance of the new f1ow-guided microcatheter Spinnaker® for endovascular embolizations with EthibloC®. Methods and Materials: In-vitro testing was performed using 50 Spin-naker® 1.8 F hydrophilie infusion microcatheters (Target Therapeutics) of three different types (total length/distal length cm155/10, 155/30,  155/20). As embolie agent a mixture of EthibloC® and Lipiodol® (EIL 1:1, 1:2, 1:3) was used; each catheter was max. injected ten times (EIL 1:1, n =20 cath.; EIL 1:2, n =20; EIL 1:3, n =10). Additionally,

TABREF272.text: 1414 Spiral CT of the skull base: are multiplanar reconstructions of benefit for tumor estimation? B. Romaneehsen, M.L. Bahner, J. Debus, I. Zuna, G. van Kaick; HeidelberglD 17:10 1415 Interactive segmentation of computerized tomography data in patients with closed acute head trauma: an application of active contour models -'snakes' R. Maksimovic, S. Stankovic, D. Milovanovic, J. Marinkovic, B. Goldner, M. Janicijevic; BelgradelYUPurpose: Computed tomography (CT) scans of patients with acute head trauma (AHT) represent a basis for clinical decision making. Digital image segmentation methods based on active contour modeling offer new possibilities for extracting features relevant for predicting intrahospital outcome in these patients. Methods and Materials: Our study group consisted of 194 patients who underwent clinical workup and in whom the first CT scan was analyzed. Analysis of CT images involved preprocessing (noise reduction and contrast enhancement by multiresolution wavelet technique) and segmentation (adaptive contour modeling -snakes). Using this method, lesion to brain (LBR) and ventricle to brain ratio (VBR) were obtained accurately. They were taken, with other CT and clinical variables as inputs to artificial neural networks trained to determine prognosis in patients with AHT. Results: LBR and VBR obtained by the proposed segmentation method were found, together with two c1inical and three additional CT variables, to be significant for predicting intrahospital outcome in patients with AHT (LBR -0.011 ± 0.001 survivors vs 0.018 ± 0.002 nonsurvivors; VBR -0.008 ± .0.002 survivors vs 0.005 ± 0.003 nonsurvivors). Furthermore, in patients who did not survive LBR for lobar localization was greater than in patients with lesion in the basal ganglia or brainstem and fossa posterior.Conclusion: The extracted quantitative features (LBR and VBR) showed to be significant for predicting intrahospital mortality of patients with AHT. Thus, using active contour model -"snakes" it is possible to extract maximum information from available CT scans, and to obtain new data on vital status of these patients.17:201416 Cranial CTA on a multislice CT scanner in patients with dural sinus thrombosis: first clinical experiences F. Fellner, B.F. Tomandl, U. Baum, W.A. Kalender, W. Bautz; Erlangen, NürnberglDPurpose: To describe first c1inical experiences with cranial CT angiography (CTA) in patients with dural sinus thrombosis on a multislice/multirow detector scanner. Methods and Materials: We examined 10 patients with c1inical suspicion of dural sinus thrombosis. All examinations were performed on a multi-slice scanner (multirow-detector system) prototype ("Somatom Plus 4 VZ", Siemens). The images were compared with the results, obtained with digital subtraction angiography. The images were read by two observers in consensus. Results: CTA of cranial vessels -obtained with a multi-slice/multirowdetector scanner -provided helpful information for the non-invasive diagnosis of dural sinus thrombosis. Short measurement times were extremely worthful for the examination of uncooperative patients. In cooperative patients the improved resolution -provided by the new CT technique -was used to obtain high-resolution CT over a large region of interest. Furthermore, postprocessing modalities provided additional benefits when compared with DSA.Conclusion: The described new CT technique offers advantages in CTA of dural sinus over conventional scanner systems. 17:25 1417 Ultrafast electron beam tomography (EBT) angiography of internal carotid artery stenosis: comparison with digital subtraction angiography (D5A) K.W. Neff, K.-J. Lehmann, G. Weisser, S. Denk, I.K. Tesdal, A. Schwartz, M. Georgi; MannheimIDPurpose: To evaluate high resolution electron beam tomography angiography (EßT-CTA) in the investigation of internal carotid artery stenosis in comparison with DSA. Methods and Materials: 15 patients with 21 different grade internal carotid artery stenoses were investigated with EßT using an Evolution XP (Siemens, Germany) with continuous volume scanning of 140 images in 17 s (collimation 1.5 mm, table increment 1 mm, 50% overlapping image reconstruction every 1 mm, expose time 200 ms (124 mAs), scan-range 14 cm). 80 ml contrast material were administered (f1ow 4 mlls). Visualisation of the carotid artery circulation was performed with MIPs, 'shaded surface display' (SSD) and original axial slices. ICAstenoses were graded using NASCET criteria: mild (0-29%), moderate (30-69%), severe (70-99%) and occluded (100%). EßT-CTA results were compared to DSA. Results: All EßT examinations demonstrated high and homogenous density values along the imaged vessels. The used protocol allowed a scan range of 14 cm visualising the distal common carotid artery and the whole ICA. In 20/21 cases EBT-CTA and selective DSA demonstrated the same degree of stenosis. Calcifications were readily diagnosed with EBT-CTA. Conclusion: Ultrafast EßT-CTA provides a reliable evaluation of ICA stenosis. EßT with 140 slices and slice reconstruction every 1 mm offers a high resolution in the z-axis with demonstration of 14 cm of the carotid artery circulation.RADIOLOGIC-PATHOLOGIC CORRELATIONSBI 2016 Abdomen(3): esophagus/colon of the patho-anatomic changes is the primary goal of the radiographic examination. Now, that inflammatory bowel diseases increasingly is being investigated by endoscopy, many radiology trainees will have difficulty obtaining familiarity with barium enema appearances. This course offers an unique spectrum of experience in correlative imaging of colon disease, concentrating on the mucosal aspects.1418 A. Neoplastic and non-neoplastic tumors of the esophagus J.L. Buck; Lexington, KYIUSA Non-neoplastic tumors: A confident diagnosis of duplication cysts can be made if the contents of the intramural mass appear like water, but beware that soft tissue density or bright signal on T1 weighted images may be seen. The fibrovascular polyp originates in the submucosal space of the proximal cervical esophagus. However, it usually presents as an intraluminal mass, often lobulated, extending as far as the GE junction. The presence of fat confirms the diagnosis. Benign Neoplasms: Leiomyoma typically presents as a mural mass which is Ionger along the vertical axis of the esophagus. Lobulation is common. The lesions may present as polypoid intraluminal masses or may extend into the lung/mediastinum with relatively little mass affect on the lumen. Differentiation from leiomyosarcoma is not always possible. Occasionally. a segmental or diffuse form of involvement, termed leiomyomatosis , occurs. Malignant Neoplasms: Hematogenous metastases are rare, but secondary involvement of the esophagus from mediastinal spread of bronchogenic carcinoma is quite common. The esophagus is the least likely site for the presence of both secondary and primary lymphomas of the GI tract, but this diagnosis should be considered a immunocompromised patient. The most common primary malignancy remains squamous cell carcinoma . SCC appear as fungating polypoid masses, ulcerating masses, areas of stricture , varicoid tumors or, rarely, as superficial spreading careinoma. SpindIe cell carcinoma , in most cases a variant of SCC, usually presents as a large polypoid sessile mass, especially in the mid-esophagus. Adenocarcinoma now represents at least 30% of primary esophageal cancers in the white population. It is almost always secondary to Barrett esophagus and, therefore, its most eommon location is the distal esophagus. Its appearances may otherwise be identical to that of SCC, although other signs or symptoms of Barrett esophagus can suggest the diagnosis.1419 B. Neoplastic and inflammatory diseases of the colon J'w.A.J. Reeders; AmsterdamlNL

TABREF274.text: RoomC 1425 Vascular trauma J.E. Jackson; London/UK STATE-OF-THE-ART SYMPOSIUM m20 The acute trauma victim Chairperson: R.F. DONDELINGER (Lil3ge/B)Proper management of trauma patients who have reached the hospital relies on complete, correct and expeditive diagnosis. To achieve this goal, problems related to structure, organization and availability of expertise in Medical Imaging in the emergency environment, are to be addressed. Diagnostic and Interventional imaging will be discussed in this respect, focused on visceraI injuries.Blunt trauma are mostly related to motor-vehiele accidents. They represent the third leading cause of death after coronary disease and cancer and the first cause of mortality in children and young adults. It is estimated that 25 or 30% of deaths related to motor vehicle accidents are solely due to thoracic injuries. In about 60% of cases, ehest injuries contribute to patients mortality. The magnitude of blunt trauma is evidenced by the frequent association of other serious injuries, particularly head and abdominaliesions and only 24% of patients have isolated ehest trauma. Blunt trauma represent a major socio-economic problem. Indeed, they are related in 1/3 of cases with alcohol consumption. Data published in the early 90's indicate that costs related to blunt trauma are as high as 6.7 billion Swiss francs per year in Switzerland (7 million inhabitants). Similar data are found in the United States where over 230 billion dollars are spent per year (250 million inhabitants).

TABREF275.text: 1426 Radiological damage control: what to da and what should not be done R.F. Dondelinger; Liege/SManagement of the trauma victim requires urgent and efficient diagnosis and therapy. Diagnostic facilities should be either an integrated part of the Emergency Department, or located elose to it. CT and the angio room should be placed next to each other, or installed in the same suite and operate in an interactive way, avoiding time loss and mobilization of the patient. Senior staff radiologists with a particular interest in trauma and a consistent experience in CT and in interventional angiography should be available around the elock. CT with spiral acquisition and state of the art DSA are mandatory for radiological damage control. The severely injured polytrauma patient, in whom the haemodynamic status still allows exploration with imaging techniques, should undergo spiral CT and subsequent angiographic embolization, when hemorrhage is evidenced on CT and/or angiography. In our experience, cervical, parietal, hepatic, splenic, phrenic, retroperitoneal and pelvic bleeding sites were treated in such a way in selected victims. Unstable patients with retroperitoneal and pelvic hemorrhage primarily undergo angiography and embolization either without or after C'I, Pelvic bone dislocations may be stabilized by orthopedic fixation either prior or after the embolization procedure. All other hemodynamically unstable patients undergo urgent surgery. A majority of patients with hepatic, splenic and renal contusions can be treated conservatively, without any type of intervention. Others may undergo secondary surgical debridement or delayed coelioscopic evacuation of massive hemoperitoneum, or repair of any other surgical lesions. Delayed damage control caused by incomplete US or CT examinations, or unreliable film reading, should be avoided. Peripheral bone fractures and other obvious lesions should not mask an unrecognized thoracic or abdominal bleeding source. Time devoted to diagnostic work up in the emergency room should be inversionally proportional to the severity of the lesions (Ben Menachem's law). Bleeding in the neck region, retroperitoneal and pelvic bleeding is best documented by angiography and treated by selective embolization techniques. US is used to document minor trauma to a single parenchyma or to rule out visceral injury. What should be done 1. Place CT and angiography inside or elose to emergency room; 2. Maintain diagnostic and angiographic interventional expertise around the elock; 3. Integrate diagnostic and interventional imaging into the trauma team; 4. Inelude thoracic CT in abdominal or pelvic trauma; 5. Obtain systematically thoraeie and abdominal CT in a patient with severe head or spinal injury. What should not be done 1. Diagnose a patient to death (Ben Menachem's Law); 2. Let a first-year resident deal with a polytrauma patient without supervision.for preoperative planning and assessing the efficacy of therapy in osteoarthrosis.1427 Pressure distribution within joint cartilage visualized by dynamical high resolution MRI (NMR microscopy) W. Gründer, M. Wagner, A. Werner; LeipziglD Purpose: Depending on the orientation concerning the static magnetic field T2-weighted MR microimages of joint cartilage show multilaminar matrix struduring ("magie angle effect"). These internal structures can be visualized as zones of different signal intensies. The existence, extension and the appearance of these zones of anisotropie cartilage matrix structures are stronly influenced by mechanical stress. Based on this we show that high resolution MRI yields informations about biomechanical properties and can give new insights into the pressure distribution within loaded joint cartilage-in some equivalence to photoelastic measurements. Methods and Materials: Cartilage-bone plugs (paired specimens femur/tibia and femur/patella) of pig knee joint were imaged under varying pressure at 7 T using SE (TE = 20 ms; TR = 500 ms) with 80 11m in-plane resolution. Compression and decrompression behaviour were observed using a home-built probehead. Results: Obviously based on the different biomechanical function the multilaminar appearance of the joint cartilage vary between different types and regions. Under varying mechanical loading the T2-weighted images show drastic changes of the visualized multilaminar structure, depending on the orientation of anisotropie collagen meshwork within the different cartilage zones. Conclusion: Changes of mechanical loading very sensitive influence the MR presentation of the articular cartilage. Based on this fact from dynamical high resolution MRI measurements information about elastic properties and stress distribution within joint cartilage can be obtained. 1428 Quantification of articular cartilage volume and thickness: optimization and validation of a rapid 3D water excitation MR-sequence and experiences with joint effusion C. Glaser, F. Eckstein, S. Faber, K.-H. Englmeier, M.F. Reiser; MunichlD Purpose: Optimization and validation of a 3D Flash Water Excitation (WE) short imaging time sequence for cartilage thickness and volume measurements. Methods and Materials: 15 patellae (9 healthy volunteers, 6 patients with effusion) were imaged at 1.5 T (30 transverse sections a 2 mm, in-plane-res. 0.31 mm). We compared a 3D Flash WE sequence (17.2/6.6/15-40 0 /t(aq) 3'07") with a validated 3D Flash sequence (conventional fat suppression) (FS) (45/11/30 0 /t(aq) 9'15"). S/N and the flip angle (FA) providing the best C/N for cartilage (6 volunteers) and C/N for cartilage vs effusion (patients) were determined. After semiautomatic segmentation and 3D reconstruction, volume (voxel count) and mean and max. thickness (3D) were calculated. Results: A FA of 20°showed the best C/N with good discrimination of cartilage from effusion. The quantitative values for thickness and volume between FS and WE differed within 1% from mean values (not significant in Wilcoxon test). Conclusion: The 30 Flash WE sequence is a valid sequence for quantitative cartilage volume and thickness measurements with good differentiation between cartilage and effusion. This and the reduction of imaging time of 65% allows for routine clinical use and is promising 8:50 1429 Cartilage imaging: comparison of driven equilibrium Fourier transform (DEFT) imaging with SPGR and FSE sequences P. Lang, B. Hargreaves, S. Conolly, J.M. Pauly, J.E. Vandevenne, S.-U. Lee, G. Gold, D. Nishimura; Stanford, CAIUSA Introduction: To compare Driven Equilibrium Fourier Transform (DEFT) with SPGR and FSE sequences for cartilage imaging. Methods: 15 patients with symptomatic patellofemoral joints and suspected cartilage defects were scanned (1.5T GE Signa, 3 in surface coil, FOV 10 x 10 cm, matrix 256 x 256, slice thickness 4 mm, 2 NEX, fat-sat, DEFT 400/15 [TRITE in msec]; SPGR 50/15,30 degrees [flip angle]; FSE 3500/15, ETL [echo train length] 4 and 8. Centrastto-noise ratios (CNR) between cartilage and joint fluid were calculated and images were read by two trained skeletal radiologists. Results: In the 15 patients, DEFT demonstrated 8 cartilage defects (2 cartilage flaps, 6 fissures) not visualized on the other sequences. DEFT morphology was consistently best delineated with DEFT. Conclusion: DEFT is a new pulse sequence for cartilage imaging with higher CNR between cartilage and joint fluid than SPGR, GRE, and FSE sequences. DEFT appears to be ideally suited for detecting subtle cartilage defects. 1430 The role of T2 and Gd-DTPA-enhanced T1 relaxation in mapping degraded articular cartilage S. Trattnig, V. Mlynarik, M. Huber, A Ba-Ssalamah, A Zembsch, H. Imhof; ViennalA Purpose: To correlate variations of T 2 and Gd-DTPA-enhanced T 1 in pathological cartilage specimens with histological findings. Methods and Materials: Osteochondral specimens from the femoral condyle and the femoral head were removed during surgery for total endoprosthesis from patients who received intravenously a double dose of Gd-DTPA two hours prior surgery. Inversion recovery spin echo images and multiple spin echo images were measured on a 3T Bruker Medspec system equipped with a microimaging accessory. The relaxation times were calculated as mean values for six (0.23 mm) x (1.0 mm) voxels parallel to the cartilage surface. Histological sections were stained first with hematoxylin-eosin. Then the loss of proteoglycans was visualized by azan, alcian, and toluidine blue staining. Results: Relaxation time profiles across the cartilage layer show that Gd-DTPA-enhanced lesions with shorter T1 values do not coincide with those having longer T2 relaxation times. On the contrary, slightly higher T 1 values were found for a region with the elevated T2. Histological examinations indicate that the Gd-DTPA-enhanced decrease of T 1 corresponds to regions with depleted proteoglycans. On the other hand, higher T 2 values indicate mechanical damage (fibrillation and/or clefts) of the articular cartilage surface. Conclusion: Both T1 and T2 relaxation times could be useful in characteristing the state of articular feature of the cartilage tissue. 1431 Imaging articular cartilage defects in the ankle joint using 3D fat-suppressed echo planar imaging in comparison with conventional 3D fat-suppressed gradient echo sequence A Ba-Ssalamah, F. Vorbeck, S. Puig, R. Prokesch, AM. Hermeth, Th. Rand, H. Imhof, S. Trattnig; ViennalA Purpose: Our goal was to shorten examination time in articular cartilage imaging by use of recently developed 3D multishot echo planar imaging (EPI) sequence with fat suppression (FS), in comparison with conventional 3D FS GE sequence Methods and Materials: Twenty five patients with ankle joint disorders underwent MRI in 1.0 T uni!. Hyaline cartilage was imaged with a 3D FS EPI and 3D FS GE sequence. Image assessment criter ia included lesion consp icuity, contrast between different types of normal tissue , and image artefacts. In addition contrast-to-noise (C/N) ratios of cartilage versus joint fluid and morrow were compared for each of the imaging sequences.Results: The 3D FS EPI sequence provided high C/N ratio between cartilage and subchondral bone similar to that of 3D FS GE sequence.The C/N ratlo between car tilage and effusion was significantly lower on the 3D EPI sequence due to higher signal intensity of fluid. 3D FS EPI sequence detected more lesions than 3D FS GE sequence, but the difference between the sensit ivities was statistically not significant Conclusion: The 3D FS EPI sequence is comparable with the 3D FS GE sequence in the diagnostic utility of cartilage lesion with the advantage of reduct ion of the scan time by a factor of four.1432MR imaglng of articular cartllage lesions using fat-saturated 3D·FLASH and water-excitated 3D-DESS sequences: experimental study K. Wörtler, M. Strothmann, B. Tombach , P. Reimer; MünsteriD Purpose: To evaluate the diagnostic accuracy offat-saturated (FS)-3D-FLASH and water-excitated (WE)-3D-DESS sequences in the detection and grad ing of articular cartilage lesions. Methods and Materials: 100 fresh knee joint specimens of pigs were examined by means of MR imaging. In 50 joints artificial cartilage lesions of different localizations, diameters (4-13 mm) and grades (grade 2: 25, grade 3: 25) were created. MR imaging was performed at 1.0 Tesla using FS-3D-FLASH (47 ms/10 ms150011.5 mm) and WE-3D-DESS (25.7 ms/9 ms140011.7 mm) sequences. Images of both pulse sequences were evaluated seperately by 3 independent observers. Results: In the detection of cartilage lesions accuracies were 93/92/95% for 3D-FLASH and 96/95/93% for 3D-DESS, respectively. The size of the lesions was correctly assesed in 84/76/87% (3D-FLASH) and 77/78/89% (3D-DESS), the grade in 84/83/85% (3D-FLASH) and 74.5/73/79.5% (3D-DESS), respectively. In all obeservers incorrect grading was mainly caused by unde restimation of grade-3-lesions. Conclusion: In this experimental setting both , FS-3D-FLASH and WE-3D-DESS sequences, were highly accurate in detection of grade 2 and 3 articular cartilage lesions. While both sequences showed equivalent diagnostic performance in determination of lesion size, grading appeared to be more reliable using the 3D-FLASH sequence. 1433 MRI in the follow-up of osteochondritis dissecans (OCD) G. Bachmann, I. Jürgensen, R-H. Bödeker, W.S. Rau; GießenlD Purpose: Are there morphological findings in MRI that determine prognosis in the mid-term follow-up of osteochondritis dissecans (OCD) of the talus and condyle? Methods and Materials: 76 patients with OCD were examined before therapy and 24-36 months later using T1 and T2 weighted sequences and contrast studies. Five clinical and six morphological data were registered . At control exam ination , the same criteria were used to classify a part ial or complete remission , constant finding or progression.Results: We found a sign ificant correlation between age and con-sol idation, whereas gender, age and duration of symptoms had no influence on clinical outcome. Patients treated conservatively had same remission rate (62%) as those treated with several surgical techniques (44-63%) . Small OCD had a higher remission rate than large lesions (60%/26%). OCD with intact cartilage had a higher remission rate than those with defects (69%/40%). Contrast enhancing fragments were better than non-enhancing lesions (90%/47%). Stage, signal intensity and fragmentation had no statistical influence on the healing rate. Conclusion: MRI enables the assessment and graduation of prognostic factors which may support therapy plann ing. 1434 Magnetic resonance microscopy (MRM) of articular cartilage using the projection-reconstruction method M. Cova , R. Toffanin, P. Szomolanyi, F. Vittur, R.S. Pozzi-Mucelli, V. Jellus , L. Dalla Palma ; Triestel/ Purpose: Magnetic resonance (MR) imaging is the most accurate non-invasive method to evaluate articular cartilage. Convent ional MR imaging sequences, however, offer only Iimited image contrast betwee n cartilage and the surrounding structures and, consequently, on MR images cartilage thickness is underestimated. The aim of this MRM study was to assess the potential of the projection-reconstruction (PR) method in the aceurate measurement of cartilage thickness.Methods and Materials: PR microimages were acquired on bonecartilage cylindrical plugs excised from four regions of 6 disarticulated femoral heads (l.e, super ior, inferior, posterior and anter ior), using a Bruker AM 300 WB instrument equipped with a microimaging accessory. PR microimages were then correlated with conventional Spin-Echo (SE) microimages and with histology. Results: On PR microimages, acquired with an echo time (TE) of 3.2 ms, the cartilage signal was increased, thereby accurately delineateing cartilage from the region of tide-marklcortical bone. As a consequence, a more accurate measurement of cartilage thickness compared to conventional SE sequence was feasibile. An excellent correlat ion between PR microimages and histology was also obtained. Conciusion: By the proposed method it is possible to accurately determine the cartilage thickness , better than with the conventional sequences.1435 Evaluation of articular cartilage of the knee using a dedicated low flald MRI S. Delucchi, S. Migliorini, E. Silvestri, M. Cimmino, L. Satragno, G. Garlaschi; Genoall

TABREF276.text: Purpose: We correlated MRI of metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) with macroscopic findings of RApathology by micro-arthroscopy (McA = needle-arthroscopy).Methods and Materials: MRI and McA were performed prospectively in 22 patients with RA (16 f, 6 rn, 30-68 ys.), disease-duration (00) of 0.5-22 ys. and -activity (Disease Activity Score (DAS)) of 2.33-7.67. MRI parameters for RA-pathology were synovial extension and activity, bony alterations, bone marrow edema, joint width and effusion and tendovaginitis. These parameters were graded 0-111: none, mild, moderate, severe. Macroscopic items for arthritis assessed by McA were chondromalacia, bony alterations and for synovitis: proliferation, thickness, extension, hyperemia, vascularity and fibrosis. We seperately evaluated MRI and McA findings in the group of patients (n =9) with early rheumatoid arthritis (00 < 2 ys.). Statistical significance was defined as highly significant for p < 0.025, as significant for p < 0.05 and as low significant for p < 0.75 (Pearson's Chi-square test, Fisher's exact test). Results: MRI findings of synovial extension were significantly correlated with macroscopical findings of synovial extension (p < 0.001) and thickness (p =0.017) as weil as with chondromalacia (p =0.065) and bony alterations (p = 0.078). Synovial activity in MRI findings-derived from the extent of Gadolinium uptake -showed a significant relationship with synovial extension (p =0.073), hyperemia (p =0.009) and vascularity (p = 0.001) -the last two also in the early RA-group (p = 0.038). The joint width was significantly associated with synovial thickness (p = 0.089), fibrosis (p =0.011), chondromalacia (p =0.007) and bony alterations (p =0.004), in the early RA-group with synovial extension (p =0.05).

TABREF277.text: 1438 Analysis of rheumatoid erosions of the wrist with E-MRI E. Silvestri, M. Cimmino, N. Lombardo, S. D'Avanzo, A. Gallo, G. Garlaschi; Genoa/l Purpose: to determine the role of E-MRI in the evaluation of bone changes in the wrist of patients with Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA). Methods and Materials: fourty RA patients aged from 28 to 84 years (average age 58.5) with mean disease duration of 82 months (range 1-312 months) were studied. MRI was performed using a dedicated 0.2 T system (Artoscan, ESAOTE, Genoa, Italy). Sequences included T1 GE and STIR. Erosions were counted. Lesions larger than 5 mm were counted twice. Statistical analysis comprised Student t test and Pearson correlation coefficient. Results: 540 erosions were counted in 72 wrists. The mean number of erosions was 11.5 in the left and 10.1 in the right wrists. The most frequently affected bones were the capitate, the distal part of the radium and the triquetrum. Erosions were correlated with age (p = 0.027) and disease duration (p = 0.009). A correlation between lesions and disease duration was found only for the left wrists. No correlation was found between number of erosions and laboratory data. Conclusion: E-MRI is a simple and effective technique to evaluate bone erosions in Rheumatoid wrist. Follow-up studies should be focused on the left wrist because it develops more erosions that are better associated with duration of RA.1439 MR imaging of juvenile rheumatoid arthritis using 3D 5PGR fat suppressed acquisition before and after administration of gadolinium e.v. F. Ginolfi, MA Bali', G. Tortora, A. Salzano; Naples/l Purpose: To evalute diagnostic efficacy of 3D SPGR fat suppressed tecnique before and after administration of gadolinium in Juvenile Rheumatoid Arthritis of the knee. Methods and Materials: 16 pts affected with JRA of the knee underwent MR examination performing Fast Spin Echo acquisition in sagittal and coronal planes, and 3D SPGR fat suppressed acquisitions before and after administration of mdc ev in sagittal planes. Results: 3D SPGR acquisitions before gadolinium provided a good discrimination between synovia I fluid, hypointense, and synovial hypertrophy, that displayed from intermediate to high signal. A good contrast was realized, between cartilage, hyperintense, and synovial fluid, but in some instances synovia I hypertrophy was poorly discernible from chondral layer. In 3D SPGR acquisitions after gadolinium vascularized synovia enhanced, while hyaline cartilage descreased from high to intermediate signal.

TABREF278.text: 1440 Magnetic resonance imaging and power Doppler imaging in patients with clinical suspicion of rheumatoid arthritis P. Böhm, Th. Rand, F. Kainberger, G. Eberl, S. Puig, H. Imhof;Purpose: To evaluate potential MR findings and observations from Power Doppler Sonography in patients with clinical suspicion of rheumatoid arthritis and unequivocal findings on plain f1im radiographs. Methods and Materials: MRI was performed in 8 patients (mean age 41 ± 7 years) with clinical suspicion of rheumatoid arthritis, by using T1 SE, STIR images and contrast enhanced images with fat suppression (SPIR). In these patients plain film radiographs were negative, or revealed equivocal signs of soft tissue swelling. Power Doppler imaging as a potential way to demonstrate vascular flow was performed in all patients. Results: MRI evidence of synovitis was regarded as extensive in 2 patients, moderate in 4 patients, and mild in 2 patients. Mild bone marrow alteration was observed in 5 patients. Mild fluid collections were found in 7 patients. Based on findings from anormal control group, Power Doppler Sonography revealed a mildly increased vascularization in 7 patients.Conclusion: MR imaging with contrast enhanced sequences and fat suppression techniques can potentially demonstrate early stages of rheumatoid arthritis by the evaluation of synovial alterations. Signs of hypervascularization can be demonstrated by Power Doppler Imaging. 1441 E-MRI and power-Doppler sonography in the study of early rheumatoid arthritis of the hand M. Falchi, E. Silvestri, G. Garlaschi, M. Cimmino, L. Satragno, C.E. Neumaier; GenoallPurpose: the purpose of this study is to investigate tha value of E-MRI and PD-sonography in the diagnosis of early RA of the hand. Methods and Materials: 35 patients suspected of having RA, with Larsen score 0-3, were examined using a 0.2T dedicated MRI system (Artoscan, Esaote, Genova-Italy) with and without Gd-DTPA. We used SET1, GET1, 3D-T1-weighted GE sequences and STIR. Ultrasonography was performed with high-frequency transducers (10-13 MHz). 8/35 patients were evaluated with PD after therapy. 2/8 were followed with MRI. Results: in grade 0-1 E-MRI showed periarticular enhancement in all the wrists and in majority of MCP and PIP joints. In grade 2-3 E-MRI demonstrated isolated subcortical marrow edema like a "pre-erosion" state. In all patients PD confirmed hypermic changes of the synovia, especially at the level of the radiocarpal and inferior ulnocarpal joints, with low resistence index (RI) at spectral analysis. In 8/35 patients followed after therapy PD depicted significant reduced vascularity. In 2/8 patients E-MRI weil correlated with PD findings after therapy.Conclusion: E-MRI is a low-cost alternative, very effective for a early diagnose of RA but not for a follow-up. PD is able to detect hyperemic changes of synovial pannus and is suggested for a follow-up after E-MRI assesment.1442 Dynamic MR imaging in the diagnosis of chronic synovitis before and after synovectomy of the knee K. Dale, H.-J. Smith, A.C. Paus, S.B. Refsum; OslolN Purpose: To evaluate the effect of synovectomy in chronic synovitis of the knee by means of contrast-enhanced dynamic MRI.

TABREF279.text: 1447 5ymptomatic fibrous lunato-triquetral coalition A. Stäbler, C. Glaser, M.F. Reiser, D. Resnick; MunichlDPurpose: In general carpal coalitions are considered to be asymptomatic. Incomplete separated joints and associated changes similar to osteoarthritis and pseudoarthrosis are known as possible cause for wrist pain. Methods and Materials: We present clinical history, plain film and MR imaging findings of two patients with symptomatic fibrous lunatotriquetral coalition. Results: Conventional films disclosed a narrowed space between the lunate and triquetral bone with cysts and sclerosis similar to pseudoarthrosis. MR imaging showed bone marrow edema adjacent to the incomplete separated lunato-triquetral joint and Gd-DTPA enhancing fibrovascular tissue in the synovium and subarticular cysts, explaining for the pain over the ulnar sided wrist. Conclusion: Patients with congenital lunato-triquetral coalition poorly tolerate stress loading or trauma, resulting in a symptomatic state similar to degenerative arthritis or pseudoarthrosis, which is demonstrated by enhanced MR imaging.1448 Vibration-related elbow joint disorders on HRCT.A preliminary study L. Bautz ;Purpose: Detection and localization of traumatic or degenerative lesions in wrist ligaments and the TFCC using contrast enhanced MRI. Methods and Materials: 72 palients with wrist trauma or carpal instability were examined on a 1.0 T (Magnetom Impact , Siemens) or 1.5 T (Philips ACS NT) unit. Following sequences were applied in different orientations: TSE T2 , GE T2*, SE T1 before and after Gd-DTPA l.v. MRI results were compared with arthroscopic and operat ive findings . Results: In 23 patients suffering from static carpal instability (stage IIIIIV) a focal contrast enhancement in the injured ligaments was found . Following ligaments were involved: scapholunate, lunotriquetral, and radioulnar ligaments. In 10 cases with clinically suspected instability, but without carpal malalignment (stage 111I), MRI revealed tubular synovial enhaneement of involved ligaments. 30 patients with ulnar loeated pain showed spotlike enhaneement patterns at the different parts of the TFCC. With hyperextension trauma 9 lesions of dorsal ligaments were seen. In 16 eases arthroseopy revealed that the eontrast enhaneement was due to granulomatous tissue at the ruptured or distended ligament sites. Conclusion: Contrast enhaneed MRI allows non-invasive visualization of injured wrist ligaments resp. TABREF284.text: NEURO m2011 Brain MR: technical problems Chairpersons: N. BONTOZOGLOU (Athens/GR) E.M. LAASONEN (TampereIFIN) 1477 Possible estimation of pulsatile C8F flow intensity within the cerebral aqueduct using a different retro FI8P 20 acquired eine MR studies in transversal plane M.A. Lueie, O. Adjie, D. Kozie, K. Koprivsek, I. Ivanovie, D. Dilas, V. Ivanovie, Z. Babie, M. Prvulovie, Z. Lueie; Sremska Kamenica, Novi Purpose: To determine possibilities of two differently acquired CINE MR studies, one developed by MR unit manufacturer and the other one developed by our team, in estimation of the intensity of pulsatile CSF flow through the normal cerebral aqueduc!. Methods and Materials: Twenty healthy volunteers underwent routine brain MR examination on 1.5T MR imager, with additionally performed ECG retra gated FISP 2D sequences (first one developed by MR unit manufacturer: TR 40, TE 12, FA 17,192 x 256, Acq 1, and the second one, experimentally developed by our team: TR 30, TE 12, FA 70, 192 x 256, Acq 1) at one fixed slice position positioned perpendicularly on cerebral aqueduct and displayed by multiplegated images in a closedloop CINE format. Results: In all of 20 volunteers MR examination showed normal brain morphology with patent cerebral aqueduct. CINE study acquired with RETRO FISP 2D sequence (TR 40, FA 17) did not allowed us to obtain adequate signal of CSF pulsation which can be sufficiently valid to be interpreted. Consequently to the changes of TR and FA, we achieved increased T2 effect resulting in higher flow sensitivity, hence RETRO FISP 2D sequence (TR 30, FA 70) showed more detailed pattern, especially of descendent CSF pulsation, which was sufficient enough for diagnostic evaluation. Conelusion: CINE study acquired with RETRO FISP 20 (TR 30, FA 70) demonstrated higher sensitivity for detection of the intensity of CSF pulsation within the cerebral aqueduct than the one acquired with RETRO FISP 2D (TR 40, FA 17), revealing better possibility of the cerebral aqueduct patency estimation in the absence of Phase Contrast sequences. 1478 Quantifieation of intracranial liquor volumes with MR imaging Th. TABREF286.text: 1511 Carotid bifurcation stenosis: CE MRA versus CT angiography (CTA) R. Marano, T. Scarabino, F. Florio, A. Carriero, L. Bonomo; Chieti/l Purpose: To compare CE MRA and CTA in the study of patients with c1inical signs of cerebro-vascular insufficiency (CV!). Methods and Materials: 25 patients, with clinical signs of CVI, underwent MRA and CTA examinations. MRA was performed using a 1.5 T super-conductive magnet and these parameters: SPGR 3D sequence, TRITE/FA: <8 ms/2.5 ms/60o; matrix 256 x 128; Nex 1; FOV 24 x 16 cm; ST: 1 mm; AT: 32 s. Contrast medium was administered i.v, using injector (0.2 mmol/Kg and flow rate 1.5 ml/s). CTA was performed using these parameters: ST 3 mm; Pitch 1. Non-ionic contrast medium (80 c, 350 mgl/ml, flow rate 3 ml/s) was administered i.v, The circulation time was calculated with a bolus test. Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) was the gold standard. Three independent radiologists graded the stenosis, according to NASCET c1assification. Me Nemar test (p < 0.05) was used. Results: CTA expressed 3 false positive judgements, one overestimation and one underestimation. CE MRA did not expressed over-or under-estimations. MRA showed a sensitivity, specificity and diagnostic accuracy of 100% and CTA of 88%, 100% and 96% (not statistically significant differences). Conclusion: CE MRA and CTA are techniques with a high diagnostic accuracy, although CE MRA could be promising in the evaluation of epiaortic vessels. Passariello; Rome// Purpose: To determine the feasibility and accuracy of contrast enhanced Turbo-MRA (CE-MRA) in the evaluation of patients with carotid artery stenosis. Methods and Materials: 23 patients with suspected carotid artery stenosis were examined with a 1.5 T magnet (Siemens Vision Plus) using a 3D T1 weighted FISP (TRITE/NEX: 3.8/1.4/1; TA = 10 seconds; Matrix =110 x 160) acquired 4 times after i.v. bolus injection with a power injector of 20 ml of Gd-DTPA. Scan delay was determined after a 3 ml test bolus. In all patients also a 3D TOF MOTSA TONE sequence was also acquired. In all patients DSA and Color-Doppler US were also performed. Results: CE-MRA was considered diagnostic and superior to the 3D MOTSA sequence in all cases. CE-MRA was correct regarding the degree of stenosis in 6/7 mild stenoses, 7/7 discrete stenoses, 11/12 severe stenoses and 3/3 occlusions and correctly negative in 17 normal carotid arteries. TABREF288.text: After injecting half, two 3D GRE data sets (TRlTE/fIip 5.2/1.5/30°, 48 x 2.4 mm sections) each extending over 48 cm were collected of the lower and upper veins, respectively. Conventional and MR-V were prospectively analysed by separate, blinded observers. Results: MR-V iimage quality was comparable to conventional venography. Overcoming vessel superimposition, rotated and targeted MIPs surpassed conventional venography in defining the morphology of perforating veins. Varicose changes of the greater and lesser saphenous veins were assessed as reliably as their pre-bypass status. Two patients referred to exclude deep venous thrombosis showed normal venograms, while the other two patients displayed postthrombotic changes. Conclusion: Contrast-enhanced 3D MR-V provides a conmprehensive display of the venous system in the lower extremities. It represents an attractive alternative to conventional venography in patients with complex venous anatomy or allergies to iodinated contrast.1520 In vivo 1H MR spectroscopy of benign and malignant breast tumors KA Kvistad, I.J. Bakken, T.E. Singstad, A.J. Svarliaunet, S. Lundgren, O. Haraldseth, I.S. Gribbestad; TrondheimlNPurpose: The most common benign breast tumor, fibroadenomas, can be difficult to differentiate from carcinomas on all imaging modalities including MR mammography. The purpose of this study was to evaluate whether in vivo 1 H MRS can be used to differentiate normal breast tissue, fibroadenomas and carcinomas, based on detection of cholinecontaining compounds (Cho) and lipid composition. Methods and Materials: 10 patients with invasive breast carcinomas, 10 patients with fibroadenomas and 10 healthy volunteers were examined. For each patient, three spectra with increasing echo times (TE 135 ms, 350 ms and 450 ms). were acquired. Results: Cho was detected in 9 of 10 carcinomas, in 2 of 10 fibroadenomas, and in none of the volunteers. The ratios between the allylic, methylene and methyl resonances in lipids were not significantly different in the three groups. Conclusion: Cho can be detected in most carcinomas, but it is not a specific finding of malignancy. With a small increase in examination time in vivo 1 H MRS can be performed as part of an MR mammography. A larger study population is necessary to evaluate if MR spectroscopy can add to the specificity of MR imaging in the diagnosis of breast lesions.1521 Contrast-enhanced MRI of the breast after silicone implant P. Viehweg, A. Heinig, R. Beck, D. Lampe, J. Buchmann,S.H. Heywang-Köbrunner; HaI/eIDPurpose: Reliable exclusion and early detection of recurrence may be impaired after reconstruction mastectomy using silicone implants. Therefore we have investigated the use of c.e. MRI in this difficult field. Methods and Materials: C.e. MRI with FLASH-3D and 0.2 mmol Gd-DTPAlkg b.w., 2-3 view mammography, 7.5 MHz ultrasound. Results: 195 patients with silicone implants after mastectomy have been examined. Later than 6 mos. postoperatively enhancement within the scar tissue was usually insignificant. Problems occurred in less than 10% of the patients because of focally enhancing granulomas or diffusely enhancing reactive-inflammatory changes, but could in 50% of these cases be solved by follow-up. 16/17 recurrences were visible by MR, 9/17 recurrences were palpable or visible by the other methods. 1/17 recurrences was visible only in retrospect on MRI as 2 mm enhancing focus. Conclusion: C.e. MRI proves a very valuable tool for patients with silicone implants after mastectomy.1522 00 follow-up examinations increase the diagnostic confidence of MR mammography? M. back_matter.text: Purpose: to compare the performance of a new f1at panel detector system and conventional radiography for imaging various skeletal structures. Methods and Materials: The study group was randomly selected from clinical routine cases and consisted of 30 image pairs of digital and conventional images of various skeletal regions, including skulI, hand, feet, spine and long bones. Conventional and digital radiographs were obtained first with identical exposure parameters. Images were independentely scored by 6 radiologists using a five point rating scale with respect to five criteria of image quality (Iatitude, visibility of trabecular bone, of enosteal and periosteal cortical borders and visibility of soft tissues). Results: All observers showed a significant preference (p < 0.05) for the digital images for all quality criteria. Differences of rating scores were largest for the assessment of soft tissues and image latitude. In selected cases visualisation of increased bone density due to sclerotic lesions was inferior in the digital images. Conclusion: The new digital flat panel detector is superior to conventional radiography for delineation of anatomie structures in a variety of skeletal regions. Performance for detection of pathology remains to be evaluated.

1490 Image quality of pelvic radiographs: screen film system versus direct ray system P. Uhrmeister, E. Kotter, J. Winterer, W. Streng, M. Langer; Freiburg/D Purpose: To study the image quality of a new digital f1at-panel detector system (DFPDS) in comparison with a conventional 400 speed screenfilm system (SFS). Methods and Materials: Paired radiographs of the pelvis were acquired from 30 volunteers with both a 400 speed SFS (Cronex Rapid UV/UVG, Sterling Diagnostic Imaging, Greenville, SC) and a DFPDS (DirectRay, Sterling). All images were acquired at 1.15 m focus-detector distance, 73 kV with automatie exposure control and a moving 12/40 lines/cm grid. The quality of the images was evaluated independently by 3 senior radiologists. The visibility of the following anatomie details was evaluated: crista iliaca, spongiosa ala ossis ilii, soft tissues surrounding the crista iliaca; sacroliliac joint, massa lateralis; acetabulum and surrounding spongiosa; ramus superior ossis pubis; caput femoris and hip joint; trochanter major and fat layer of the hip joint; 5th lumbar vertebra, delineation of the psoas museIe. The visibility of all structure was ranked on a four point scale. Data were analyzed using a paired t-test. Results: The evaluation show superior results of the DFPDS in delineation anatomical structures of the lower lumbal spine and the sacral bone. The other analysed could be visualised as weil as with the SFS. Conclusion: DFPDS image quality is superior for regions corresponding to the extremities of the graduation curve of the SFS. For the other critical structures the quality is at least comparable. Purpose: Teleradiology has been a useful system to perform remote diagnosis using CRT units. However, a conventional teleradiology system can not show the advantage of the "real time" nature of the system elearly, because most systems have been dedicated to CRT diagnosing of images obtained at and transmitted from a remote hospital. The study, therefore, is to introduce the new two concepts for teleradiology: "real time radiology" and "seamless operation of a workstation to view images from both local and remote hospitals" into a teleradiology and to establish such a system. "Real time radiology" is a system, which can cover 24-hour services of diagnostic praetices by radiological speeialists. Methods and Materials: We designed a real time radiology system with a multimedia diagnostic workstation, which was established under the new teleradiology concepts and could be used for cooperative diagnosis by interchanging radiologieal images bilaterally in real-time during an audio-visual discussion. An intersocket communication technology was used to establish such a new real time radiology system. Results and Conclusion: In this artiele, we show the system configuration and present the results of evaluation from technical and clinical points of view on real time radiology. 11:00 1492 Teaching computer system as a model of physician performance in radiology M. Kamenetsky, M. Pervak, A. Nor, N. Arkhangelskaya; DonetskJUKR Purpose: To assess the role of computer algorithm-based system for training would-be physicians in radiology. Methods and Materials: A teaching system as a model of radiologist performance was devised, taking as a base diagnostic syndrome principle and algorithm-oriented approach. The identified radiologie symptoms were highlighted in the image. Multimedia means for manipulating complex information, MS Windows'95 as an environment, MS Visual C++ as abasie programming language, Visual Basic for breadboading along with MS Access for data base management were used. Results: The computer algorithm-based system enabled both the sequence ef diagnosis establishment and conclusion to be obtained, diagnostic process control to be exercised, an error to be revealed by returning to one of the previous stages. Conclusion: Apart from its beneficial utility for trainees in radiology the system demonstrated the potential to stimulate physician logic and judgement.

1493 Time used for radiological conferences J.T. Geitung, L. Dalla Palma; Os/o/N, Trieste/I A culture including conferences between radiologists and clinicians is customary in Scandinavia. This must necessarily be time eonsuming. Is it worth it? To assess the question, it is necessary to find the time used for conferences and try to assess how this time is used. This work has concentrated on this, Further on we will compare routines in Scandinavia and Italy to find possible differences due to the culture including conferences. Materials and Methods: Questionnaires were filled in at East University Hospital (EUH) in Gothenburg, Sweden and Ullevaal University Hospital (UUH), Oslo, Norway. Totally 34 conferences at EUH and 31 at UUH were registered. Total time, ineluding preparations, disturbances, conference and time for dictating examinations not previously dictated were registered. At EUH all daily conferences were registered. At UUH apart of the daily conferences were registered. UUH has a higher number of and shorter conferenees daily. Results: The time used at EUH was: average total time 136.1 minutes and median 140 minutes; average time for the conferences were 26.5 minutes, median 25 minutes. At UUH: average total time 78.2 minutes, median 72; average time for conferences were 24.3, median 22. The average number of examinations that had to be evaluated and described in connection with the conferences were at EUH 54.2 (median 57) and at UUH average 11.5 (median 12). The average time used for descriptions were at EUH 2.6 (median 2.5) and at UUH 8.2 (median 6.3). The shorter the conference the longer the time for either describing the examination or discussing it with the. The number of elinieians attending varied, 2-30. Discussion: Around 25 minutes are being used for each conference. It looks like most conferences are 20-25 minutes long independent of the number of examinations presented. The rest of the time registered would probably have been used for describing anyway, so those 20-25 minutes are the most interesting. An interesting observation is that the time available always seems to be used -the more time available, the more time used. If we assume 20 conferences a day (which is elose to UUH), it will constitute approximately 8 hours a day which is a standard workday; i.e. it costs one extra doctor. The time used by the clinicians will probably be worth a lot more, and the next question we will try to answer is: How much do the conferences cost the clinical department and do they find it worthwhile.

1494 Handling a growing workload with natural speech recognition W. Kumpan, F. Kamel, Th. Brüll, G. Nies, H. Rödler, R. Wolffhardt, Ch. Zolles; Vienna/A Purpose: Natural speech recognition was introduced following the rebuilding of the department so as to make it possible to handle a steadily increasing number of examinations without taking on additional staff. Methods and Materials: A speech recognition system with 22 workstations was integrated in the state-of-the-art radiological information system (RIS), and physicians were encouraged to dictate their reports using the new system. Results: Although the original timetable provided for the gradual introduction of speech recognition in three phases to ensure a smooth transition to the new technology, most of the physicians opting for the new technology immediately started using it for all their reports. With a minimum of training and customisation, they were quickly able to achieve recognition rates of over 90% without significant changes to their method of working. Conclusion: The introduction of natural speech recognition has significantly shortened the turnaround time of reports -partieularly at times during which no secretarial support is available. In many instances the Purpose: Ta find out why some women experience pain during mammography and to know whether any of the pain factors are controllable. Methods and Materials: A quantitative sociological study was performed to examine the pain experience during and after mammography. 247 women were interv iewed as weil in a screen ing unit, in university hospital as in a non-university hospital. All radiographers (N = 13, 5342 response =100%) perform ing the mammographies were intervi ewed as weil. A broad pain model is used and factars concerning the woman , the mammographie procedure and the radiographer were explored. The results of pain experience of women attending for a screening examination were compared with those undergoing a diagnostic or follow-up examination . Results: Analysis of the data were performed on different statistical levels. The results show that most of the women (3 out of 4) experience pain during mammography, and that pain experience is more frequent with a diagnostic mammography. The risk of pain experience can be explained by biological and psychoemotional aspects of the woman, the procedure of the mammog raphy and especially the attitude of the radiographer. Conclusion: 73% of women undergoing mammography experience pain. Faetors concerning the woman , the procedure and the radiographer can influence this pain experience. Resulls: 27 women with bilateral breast cancer were found. The incidenee of synchronous tumours was 22%. 78 percent were metachronous tumours with a median interval of 92 month . The recidivation rate was part icularly higher in synchronous tumours (33%) than in metachronous ones (19%). The second breast cancer was detected only by clinical examination or biopsy in two of the 27 patients . Only 67% of synchronous tumours seems to be similar in histology type and mammographie features. There was no eorrelation between mammography features of the first and second metachronous tumour (72%). Concluslon: More aggressive monitoring of the second breast by frequent clinical examination, mammography and selected biopsy is necessary.

1527 Calcium milk lactation of the breast: areport of 2 cases A. Van Steen , C. Van Ongeval, G. Vandenbosch , I. Sri ; LeuvenlB, JakartalRI Purpose: Calcium milk lactation is an extremely rare disease of the breast. In the literature of the past 15 years no documented reports were found . Methods and Materials: We report 2 Chinese women (42-46 y) who underwent mammo-and ultrasonog raphy. One had a FNAC and cytology of the nipple discharge. Results: The first woman came for a screening mammogram, no c1inical abnormality or previous disease was known. There was no nipple discharge , nor breastfeeding in history. The mammogram showed multiple slightiy dilatated radio-opaque ducts and cysts , the image one is used to see on a galactogram. The ultrasonography showed no suspicious lesions. The second woman breastfed her baby for 9 years. Because of a persistent nipple discharge a mammography was performed. Aga in multiple radio-opaque dilatated ducts were seen, but in this case, the cysts were larger. Cytology of the nipple discharge or a FNAC of one of the cysts showed no pathology. Discussion: With an identical mammographie image, the common finding between these two cases is the Chinese origin and the middle age of the women. Hormonal status was normal. There is a similarity with lipoid lactation , showing ducts which are filled with a fatty lucent material, but in the literature very few remarks and mammographie imaging was found. Conelusion: It seems that some Chinese women are affected by a very rare breast disease. Further investigation and more cases are needed to describe this abnormality.

1528 Mammographie manifestations of lobular eareinoma in situ M.J. Fuster, J. Ibafiez, D. Salas, F. Ruiz, I. Vizcaino; Elda/E Objetives: Unlike ductal carcinoma in situ, wich is considered a preinvasive lesion, lobular carcinoma in situ is at present c1assified as a risk faetor for breast cancer. The objeetive of our study is to show the spectrum of mammographie alterations of lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS), thereby updating the concept of this histological category. Material and Methods: We review the surgical biopsies carried out during the Prevention of Breast Cancer Programm run by the Autonomous Region of Valencia between April 1992 and December 1996. During this program, 101.657 patients were studied in the first series and 73.218 in the second. LCIS was the anatomopathological diagnosis in 10 biopsies. LCIS was diagnosed in 5 of the 797 biopsies done in the first series and in 5 of the 362 biopsies done in the second. Results: In 8 of the 10 cases the mammographie presentation consisted of clusters of microcalcifications, in one case in association with architectural distorsion and in another with palpable asymmetry. The two remaining cases were a nodule and a stellate lesion, both of which were palpable. Conelusion: LCIS is an uncommon histological category whose mammographie findings are not especific and wich requires special follow-up. Paris/F Purpose: The incidence of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) has increased by the widespread use of screening mammography. DCIS is often detected by microcalcifications on mammography. Based on the extent of microcalcifications, mammography usually underestimates the size of DCIS. The aim of our study was to describe the radiological and pathological findings of small DCIS. Methods and Materials: From january 1992 to january 1998, breast surgery was performed in 13 patients with the pathological findings of DCIS smaller than 1 cm in diameter. Cases with associated carcinoma were excluded. Mammography and/or radiography of the surgical biopsy were analysed retrospectively in comparison with pathological findings. Results: The mammographie findings were microcalcifications in all cases. The mammographie size of the area of microcalcifications was 3 to 40 mm (mean =14 mm). The pathologie size was 2 to 6 mm (mean = 5 mm). The microcalcification signal was always associated with DCIS and with other pathological findings (fibrocystic disease n = 8, atypical ductal hyperplasia n =1).Conelusion: In this subgroup of DCIS the mammographie size overestimates the pathological size. Calcifications of associated benign pathologies help probably to detect them on mammography. The exploration of all clusters of microcalcifications is important to detect precociously DCIS.

1530 Evaluation of the dignity of regional Iymphnodes in patients with histologieally verified mama lesions D. Kriegl, M.G. Smola, R. Gröll, R. Rienmüller; Graz/A Purpose: To identify criteria of metastatic versus non-metastatic Iymphnodes in patients with known malignant lesions of the mama before surgery to reduce the number ofaxillary Iymphnode dissections. Patients and Methods: 85 patients who were admitted to mama surgery because of mamographically suspected tumorous lesions were studied by EBT preoperatively. The scans were performed in all patients as postbolus scan with 300 ms exposure time and 3 mm slice thickness starting at the level of the acromioclavicular joint and ending below the lower mammarian junction line. At surgery 68 (85) lesions revealed histologically to be malignant and 17 (85) benign. A careful evaluation of the regional Iymphnodes at the surgical level 1 (Iymphnodes axill.lat. and paramammarian), level 2 ((Iymphnodes axilLcent. and intrapectoral.), level 3 (Iymphnodes infra-and supraclavicuL) with respect to their number and their size was performed. Using the retrospective approach of step by step analysis it was found that the Iymphnodes 2':5 mm in diameters and above two by number per surgical level suggest their metastatic involvement. Results: In 27 of 68 patients with malignant breast lesions the regional Iymphnodes in all three surgical levels did not exceed the number one and a size of 5 mm. In 41 of 68 patients the number of Iymphnodes was equal or higher than two and at least one of them was greater than 5 mm in at least one of the three surgical levels. Using this approach in identifying metastatic involvement of the regional Iymphnodes the statistical analysis revealed for EBT a sensitivity, specificity and accuracy of 100%, 69% and 82% and a negative predicitive value of 100%. Conelusion: Our data suggest that the preoperative evaluation of patients with suspected mama lesions using the described EBT approach and analysis may exclude unnecessary surgical exploration of the regional Iymphnodes if their number is found below one and the size below 5 mm in all surgical levels.

Purpose: Semi-automatic segmentation was used for comparative quantitative analysis of myelinisation in preterm and term infants Method and Materials: 11 studies were analysed: 4 preterm babies at birth, 4 preterm babies at expected term, 3 term newborns, all neuroloqically normal (axial proton-density and T2-weighted images, 1.5 T MR, contiguous 3 mm slices, pixel size 0.7 mm). Results: We found progress of myelinisation in an occipitorostral direction and from caudal to cranial. The volume of myelinated WM increased faster than that of non-myelinated WM (2.1 % ± 0.2% of the total white malter at gestational age of 33 weeks, 3.1% ± 0.3% at 41 weeks). We found no significant difference between relative myelinisation of term infants (3.0% ± 0.2%, week 40 ± 0.5) and preterm infants at term ( Purposellntroduction: Radiat ion therapy is the most effective nonsurgical method for the treatment of cancer. However, the precise determination of the lesions that take place in the brain tissue during the irradiation is very difficult. Although MR imaging allows mon itoring of lesion volumes, but it cannot provide the information on the brain metabolism -the stud ies of the latter seem to be very useful for predicling and/or deteeting the response to therapy. Proton in vive spectroscopy, because of its sens itivity, is an ideal tool for this aim, however the literature data are sparse and concern mainly the post radiation effects 1,2. The aim of this study was to monitor the metabolite changes that occur during therapy. 5ubjects and Methods: 15 patients (aged 40-45) were exam ined in a whole -body MRI/MRS system (Elscint 2T Prestige) operating at the field strength of 2T and a proton resonance frequency of 85 .6 MHz applying the standard head coil. All patients had been operated before they underwent fractionated radiotherapy. The influence of radiotherapy was studied by means of a sequential recording of spectra before the radiation exposure, after 50% of the total dose, after the compl etion of the therapy and a month later. MRllocalized 1 H MR spectra we re acqu ired using a single voxel doublespin-echo .pRESS sequence with the following parameters: TR-1500 rns, TE-35 ms , 200 Acq and for the voxel volume of 8 cm 3 . Water suppression was achieved using CHESS technique. For each palient the spectra were obtained from two volumes of interest -the first localizalion was in the area of a high dose (total dose of 60 Gy) and the second one was situated in the region of a low does (total dose up to 50 Gy). The spectra were postprocessed with the automatie fitting in the frequency domain. The fitting procedure was supplied by the machine manufacturer. Relat ive intensities of the signals due to N-acetyl aspartate (NM), choline based compounds (Cho ), crealine based eompounds (Cr), mio-Inositol (mi ), lactate (Lac) and lipides (Lip) were obtained by numerical integration of the fitted signals.The results were compared with the literature speetroscopie data on the early and late post radiation spectral characteristicslP. Results: It was found that in the case of high dose area in the short TE spectra the ratio NAAlCr decreases vs. time of therapy suggesting the depletion of NM and/or increase in Cr concentration. Intereslingly, the changes in the ratio Cho/NM occurring on radiotherapy are not very pronounced, however the values are observed to increase slightly. It is also worth noting that the Lac/NM ratio increases markedly during the course of therapy. The changes in the metabolite ratios in the low dose area are found to be similar, however the rate of reduction of the ratio NAAlCr vs. radiation time is markedly slower. were regrouped aceording to: 1. Antiretroviral therapy; 2. neurologic symptoms and 3. viral load, respectively. Two spectroscopy sequences were applied with a TE of 5 and 135 ms, respectively. Peak integral values were calculated for N-acetylaspartate (NAA), choline (Cho), phosphocreatine/creatine (Cr) myo-inositol (mi) and glutamate/glutamine (Glx) and normalized to Cr. Results: All patients had reduced NAAlCr ratio. The Cho/Cr ratio was increased in patients without therapy (p =0.07), but was back to normal after therapy. The ml/Cr ratio was significantly increased in patients with neurologie symptoms. The Glx ratio did not show any significant changes between volunteers and patients. Conclusion: The NAA and Cho alterations in HIV+ patients reflect neuronal loss in combination with cell membrane modification, such as myelin alterations or gliotic changes. While the HIV infection progresses, the metabolic alterations become more prominent. The other aim is to determine when a postoperative MRI most accurately shows residual enhancing tumor.Purpose: To determine the predictive value of single voxel MR speetroscopy (MRS) in the diagnosis of cerebral masses in patients with AIDS Methods and Materials: Patients with c1inical AIDS who had doeumented eerebral mass lesions were prospectively studied on a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR (GE systems) using the single voxel technique (8 eubic cm voxel Probe/SV). Spectra were analyzed by a radiologist blinded to c1inical data into four eategories: inflammatory, neoplastic, isehaemic and demyelination. Patients underwent stereotaetic biopsy of the lesions after MRS as part of the clinical management. Results: 18 patients were studied. MRS was in agreement with histology in 13 patients (72% with 95% confidence level from 62 to 83%). Kappa was 0.6 indicating fair to good agreement. Purpose: 1 H magnetic resonanee spectroscopy was used to eompare brain metabolism in elderly women and men. Methods and Materials: Automated 1 H chemieal shift imaging (PRESS, TE = 135 ms) was used to examine an 8 x 8 x 2 cm 3 supraventricular brain volume, a transverse plane parallel to the eanthomeatal line, in 540 subjects of 60 to 90 years old, stratified by age and sex. Results: Regional choline (Cho), ereatine (Cr) and N-acetylaspartate (NAA) peak areas in the 518 successful examinations (96%) were normalized by division through the total area of the corresponding metabolite in eaeh spectral map. This eliminated intersubject varianee, as expeeted, maximized intervoxel variance (26 < F < 149, P < 0.0001) and reduced the standard deviations in the voxel metabolite signals threefold. Normalized signals in women (n =257) and men (n =261) differed in 9 (Cho/SCho), 8 (Cr/SCr) and 10 (NAAlSNAA) out of 36 voxels (P < 0.001). The main finding was that Cho/SCho, Cr/SCr and NAAlSNAA are reduced in men compared with women in a block of 6 frontal voxels of the cingulate gyrus containing essentially white matter. Discussion: This phenomenon of reduced metabolite levels in men compared with women fits with a sex-related reduetion of glucose metabolism in the same brain lobe revealed by positron emission tomography (Gur et al., Science 1995; 267:528-531) . This is the first multivoxel MRS study demonstrating sex-related differences in human brain metabolites.Purpose Purpose: In a prospeetive MRI study using ehemieal shift speetroseopy imaging (CSI) we examined patients with temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE). We evaluated the predietive value of metabolie CSI ehanges in patients after epilepsy surgery. Methods and Materials: The MR-investigations were performed using a 1.5 T whole body MR-system. For CSI high resolution multi-voxel speetroseopy was performed. To evaluate the influenee of metabolie ehanges on the postoperative outcorne, we elassified the patients in three groups. Patients in group I had unilateral, in group 11 slight (Iess than 10% contralateral changes) and in group 111 severe (more than 30% contralateral changes) bilateral metabolie changes in CSI. 26 patients underwent epilepsy surgery. The results of preoperative CSI and EEGregistration were compared and evaluated by the postoperative results.Results: Statistical analysis demonstrates a better correlation (r = 0.8744, p < 0.005) of preoperative CSI changes and postoperative outcome than compared with EEG (r =0.2466, P =0.556). A discrimination analysis demonstrates a linear function between the severity of contralateral CSI changes (group 11 and 111) and the postoperative outcome. Conclusion: CSI changes have a pedietive value for the postoperative outcome in patients with TLE. In patients with severe bilateral CSI changes recidivism must be expected.

Wilms; LeuvenlBPurpose: To compare brain magnetic resonance (MR) imaging with computed tomography (CT) in patients referred from the Neurology and Neurosurgery outpatient c1inics. The purpose was to test measures of the dec ision-making process and pat ient outcome. Methods and Materials: One hund red consecutive patients, referred for a first and non-urgent brain CT, were enrolled after having given the ir informed consent and underwent MR imaging the same day. A routine turbo spin-echo T2-weighted sequence was compared to a rapid single echo T2-weighted sequence. Funct ional and general health status were measured at baseline and at 3 months. The clinicians answered aseries of questions for assessment of the diagnostic and therapeutic effects of the imaging studies . Results: Most examinations (77 %) revealed no abnormality. Both CT and MR showed abnormalities in 10% of the patients but MR showed more abnormalities in 50% of them . MR showed abnormalities while CT remained normal in 12% of the patients . Five patients could not undergo MR because of e1austrophobia (n = 2) or a ferromagnetic implant (n = 3). Conclusion: There is a growing press ure for outcome stud ies of diagnostic tests. We compared MR imaging with CT and found that CT was satisfactory in more than 80% of the cases. MR imaging had a therapeutic impact in 2 patients by providing more information than CT. The rapid T2-weighted sequence provided the same information as the routine T2-weighted sequence. Measures of the decision-mak ing process and patient outcome will be discussed. (1), Klippel-Weber Trainaut (1), Walker-Warburg (2) and conatal CMV infection in 2 children. Conclusion: High resolution US is sufficient modality in assessment of widespread cortical dysgenesis as weil as in cases when they are accompanied by other gross anomalies of the brain. MRI was performed in 50 patients with in 7 days after severe head injury after an initial CT had been obtained.Brain stem lesions were depicted in 32 patients (64%). Bilateral pontine lesions proved to be 100% fatal, non-brain stem lesion had a mortality of 10%. In singular cases circumstances allowed for a clear clinical distinction between primary and secondary brain stem lesions. Primary lesions on MRI were mixed hyper-and hypointense after intervals of more than 2 days after the injury. In one cleary scondary and fatal brain stem lesion there were no traces of blood. It is concluded that brain stem lesions are more frequent in severe head injury than previously reported from studies based on neuropathological or CT data. Early MRI after head injury is of higher predictive value than CT and possibly allows for differentiation between primary and secondary brain stem lesions. Purpose: To analyze brain CT and MRI findings of subacute stages of methanol intoxicated patients, as weil as clinical relevance of these features. Methods and Materials: Four patients intoxicated accidentally with alcoholic beverage (30-33% of methyl alcohol), admitted to MMA during a single outbreak were studied by enhanced brain MRI and CT. Two patients presented with coma, one with psychoorganic syndrome, and one with visual disturbances. Neurophysiological and toxicological analyses were done and one fatal case was underwent patologic correlation. Results: Brain CT predominantly showed necrosis and haemorrhage of bilateral putamina, globus pallidus and claustrum and post-contrast enhancement of corpus striatum. Subcortical white matter necrosis of frontal lobes and postcontrast gyral enhancement was noted. Preferential localization of methanol-induced lesions on enhanced MRI within the putamina, globus pallidus and c1austrum was observed in three cases too. Globus pallidus and putamen enhanced after Gd contrast. Subcortical and deep white matter necrosis of variable extent in frontal and occipital and less in parietal regions was seen, as weil as its postcontrast enhancement. Conclusion: Characteristic enhanced CT findings are helpful in the diagnosis of methanol poisoning and specific pattern of brain lesions on enhanced MRI is valuable tool in toxicological surveillance. Acute lead encephalopathy (ALE) is increasingly reported in Europe and North America among immigrants from the Middle East and Indian Subcontinent, where lead is used in folk medicine. Purpose: To present the c1inico-radiological manifestations of ALE and the role of radiology in its management. Methods and Patients: Prospective study of 45 children with ALE, aged 11 days-8 years. We analysed indications for lead prescriptions, clinico-radiological characteristics and final outcome of ALE. Results: Lead preparations contained 3.87-93% lead by weight. They were prescribed by parents and traditional healers for colics, ablation of umbilical cordstumps, constipation, diarrhoea, intercurrent illnesses. teething pain, against devils and facial make-up. Patients presented with anaemia, abdominal pain, irritability, hyperreflexia, seizures, stupor and coma. Whole blood lead levels were 2.2.-46 mmols/l. 3% had lead gum-lines, 13% basophilic stippled RBCs. All had skeletal lead lines. CT-brain findings: 11% normal, 11% hydrocephalus with posterior fossa pseudotumour, 11% subdural hygromas, 13% calcifications, 33% atrophy, 44% oedema. All were treated conservatively except 2 who were shunted for acute hydrocephalus. Conclusion: ALE is a cultural-iatrogenic problem with high mortality and neuro-behavioural sequelae. Methods and Materials: A retrospective analysis of imaging study in 64 children affected by craniofacial abnormalities (25 plagiocephaly. 14 scaphocephaly, 12 trigonocephaly, 8 brachycephaly, 3 Kleeblattschädel, 2 acrocephaly) was carried out using 3D spiral CT. Scan parameters were: 3-5 mm slice thickness ; table feed 5 mm/sec; image reconstructions at 2 mm interval ; 120 kV, 165 mAs. Results: Skull base abnormalities were present in all patients. Skull base angles were abnormal in all patients affected by plagiocephaly. Complex craniosynostosis showed alterations of occipital synchondrosis.Conclusion: A wide range of CT abnormalities are present in the craniofacial synostosis. Some of these are c1early primary, whereas others appear to be related to the small skull base and sutural synostosis . Skull base deformities can playa role in the etiopathogenes is of craniosynostosis. These anomalies were especially common in patients affected by plagiocephaly. Purpose: Primitive neuroectodermal tumours (PNET) are highly malignant, undifferentiated supratentorial neoplasms which frequently seed in the central nervous system. PNET occur primarily in young children; in adults they are extremely rare. Previous reports on the neuroradiological findings refer solely to PNET in children.Methods and Materials: The CT scans and MR images of five adults (three males, two females) with histologically proven PNET of the cerebra l hemispheres were reviewed retrospectively. Results: In this series, PNET were rather large, heterogeneous masses w ilh eyslic and neerolie areas, inlralumoral haemorrhage and focal calcification. In 4/5 patients , the tumour showed well-defined margins by CT as weil as MR with only a thin rim of oedema . In 315 patients, the tumour mass was iso-or hyperdense on NECT scans which is presumably due to the high nuclear to cytoplasm ic ratio found in PNET. MR images showed the tumour to be mildly hypoinlense on Tl W images and hyperintense on T2W images. The prominent contrast enhancement on both CT and MR scans reflects the increased vascularity of PNET. Conclusion: Understanding PNET is important for the radiologist 00cause certain neuroradiological features may suggest their diagnosis. Because of their prospensity to spread throughout the cerebrospinal fluid pathways, an MR examination of the spinal cana l should be performed If a PNET is suspected .
